2 lj~A^ * , inf. n. talojiy^apN, He forced a person to do a thing against his will: (S, K:) or, to do a thing which was contrary to what it appeared to be. (AHeyth.) ― -b2- talojiy^apN is also explained as signifying The leaving one's property to some one or more of his heirs, in preference to, or to the exclusion of, the other or others. lj~A^ He so left his property. (ISh.) ― -b3- See 4.

4 AljA^h A_ilY $aYo'K *
He constrained, compelled, forced, drove, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or to betake himself to, or to repair to, or to do, a thing; he impelled him, or drove him, against his will, to it, or to do it; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K, * TA;) as also A_ilayohi ↓ lj~Ahu. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- AljA^ A^amorahu A_ilaY All~`hi, (S, K,) and [A_ilaY All~`hi] ↓ lajaA^a, and ↓ AltjA^, and ↓ tlj~A^ (TA,) He referred, or committed, his affair to God. (S, K.) ― -b3- AljA^h He protected him, defended him. (K.) Also said of a place, [It protected him; afforded him refuge.] (K, art. Hrz.) ― -b4- AljA^h A_ilaY $aYo'K is also said when one has defended another, [as] in a place of refuge; [and app. may be rendered He caused him to have recourse to a thing, as to a place of refuge]. (TA.)
5 talaj~aAa see 1 and 4.
8 A_ilotajaAa see 1 and 4.

lajaA^N * and ↓ malojaA^N (S, K) and ↓ mulotajaA^N (K, art. lHd; &c.) A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; a place of refuge; an asylum; a refuge. (S, K.) The hemzeh of the ↓ second is sometimes elided; and this is done to assimilate the word to manojaA, when it is used therewith; like as mnjA is written with hemzeh to assimilate it in the like case to malojaA^N. ― -b2- [↓ mljA^N is often applied to a man: and you say also,] fulaAnN Hasanu ↓ AlmalojaA_i [Such a one is a good person to whom to have recourse for protection or concealment]. The pl. of lajaA^N is A^alojaA='N. (TA.) ― -b3- lajaA^N (assumed tropical:) A wife. (L.) ― -b4- An heir. (ISh.) [See 2.] -A2- The frog: (K:) or a kind of tortoise, that lives on the land and in the sea: (M:) fem. with p. (K.) The ljA^p of the sea (All~ajaA^apu AlbaHoriy~apu) is asserted to have a tongue in its breast, and to kill the animal that it strikes. (Dmr.)
malojaA^N * and mulotajaA^N: see lajaA^N.

1 lajiba * , aor.
lajaba , inf. n. lajabN, It [a number of men] cried out, or vociferated; raised a clamour, or confused noise. (S, K.) See also art. jlb. ― -b2- lajiba, inf. n. lajabN, It (a clamour, or confused noise,) rose. (TA.) ― -b3- lajiba, inf. n. lajabN, It (the sea) was agitated, or in commotion; its waves conflicting, or dashing together. (K.) -A2- lajubato, aor.
lajuba , (inf. n. lujuwbapN, TA;) and ↓ lj~bt, inf. n. talojiybN; She (a sheep or goat) had little milk; (S, K:) or her milk dried up, in consequence of her having passed four months since bringing forth. (S.) See lajobapN. -A3- In a trad. respecting Moses and the stone, occur the words, falajabahu valaAva lajabaAtK, which IAth says he cannot
explain, unless the right reading be falaHatahu vlAv laHataAtK [And he struck it three blows]. (TA.)

lajabN *
A crying, or vociferation; a clamour, or confused noise. (S, K.) The sound, or noise, of soldiers; and the neighing of horses. (TA.) Agitation, or commotion, of the waves of the sea. (K.) The rising of a clamour, or confused noise. (TA.) ― -b2- baHorN *uw lajabK A roaring, tumultuous, or boisterous, sea. (S.)

jayo$N lajibN *
A clamourous, or noisy, army. (S, K.) ― -b2- In like manner this epithet is applied to thunder, and to a cloud or rain accompanied with thunder; in each case after the manner of a rel. n. (TA.)

lajobapN * and ↓ lujobapN and ↓ lijobapN (S, K) and ↓ lajabapN [but see what is said respecting the last of the pls. mentioned below] and ↓ lajibapN and ↓ lijabapN (K) the last two from Th. (TA.) A sheep or goat ($Ap, K), or a sheep only, not a goat, (ISk, S,) of which the milk has become little in quantity: (S, K:) or a sheep or goat ($Ap) which has passed four months since her bringing forth, and of which the milk has in consequence dried up: (As, S:) or it is an epithet applied specially to a goat: (K:) a poet (Muhelhil, TA,) says,
Eajibato A^abonaAw^unaA mino fiEolinaA
A_i*o nabiyEu Alxayola biAlmiEozaY All~ijaAbo
[Our sons wondered at our action, in our selling horses for goats of which the milk had become little, or dried up]: (S:) and contr., abounding with milk: (K:) a poet applies the two epithets lajobap and HaA$ikap to the same sheep or goat; but he may mean that her milk was little at one time, and abundant at another. (TA.) Pl. [of lajobapN] lijaAbN (S, K) and lajobaAtN (this being allowed by Mbr, agreeably with analogy, TA) and lajabaAtN (S, K): the last dev. with respect to rule; for by rule it should be lajobaAtN; unless it be originally a subst. used as an epithet, like as one says A_imoraA^apN kalobapN; or unless ↓ lajabapN be a syn. of the sing. (S.) Sb says, that lajabaAtN is used as pl. because some of the Arabs used ↓ lajabapN as sing. (TA.) ― -b2- All~jb [app. All~ajabu, a quasi-pl. n.,], occurring in the following words of a trad., fayaboduw A^amovaAlu Alljbi mina Al*~ahabi, is said to be pl. of lajobapN: or it is All~ijabu, like as qiSaEN is pl. of qaSoEapN. (TA.) -A2- In a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, according to one reading, occur the words, bljbtY AlbAbi: but Aboo-Moosà says, that the right reading is with f [instead of the b, and with Y before it: i. e. bilajiyfataY AlbAb: see art. ljf]. (TA.)
lujobapN * : see lajobapN.
lijobapN * : see lajobapN.
lajabapN * : see lajobapN.
lajibapN * : see lajobapN.
lajabapN * : see lajobapN.

milojaAbN *
An arrow feathered, but without the point: (K:) pl. malaAjiybu. (TA.) minojaAbN is the more common word; and the l appears to be substituted for the n. (ISd.)

lujoHN *
A thing in the lower part of a well, and of a valley, like what is called a daHol: (S, K:) or, in the lower part of a well, and of a mountain, like a naqob: (L:) originally luHojN, from which it is formed by transposition: (T:) pl. A^alojaAHN. (L.)

1 laja*a * , (L, K,) aor.
laju*a , (K,) inf. n. lajo*N; (L, K;) and laji*a, aor.
laja*a ; (K;) He ate (L, K) food. (L.) ― -b2- He (a beast) began to pasture. (L, K.) ― -b3- He (a beast) ate herbage: (L:) you say, when beasts have eaten herbage, luji*a AlkalaA^u: (S, L:) or ate it with the extremity of his tongue, (L, K,) it being such as did not allow him to take it with his teeth: (L:) accord. to As, laja*ahu signifies i. q. las~ahu [he plucked it with the fore part of his mouth.] (S, L.) ― -b4- He licked: in this sense, the inf. n. is lajo*N and laja*N: (K:) you say, laji*a Alkalobu AlA_inaA='a, inf. n. lajo*N and laja*N, the dog licked the vessel (AHát, S, K) inside: (L:) [J says,] I have transcribed it from the Kitáb el-Abwáb, without having heard it: (S:) and laji*a Alkalobu the dog put his tongue into a vessel and lapped; as also lajida and lajina. (AA, L.) ― -b5- He took little. (L, K.) ― -b6- He asked often after having been given once: (K:) laja*aniY, aor.
laju*a , inf. n. lajo*N, signifies he asked me, and did so much, after I had given him: (S:) or he asked me after he had asked me and I had given him: (AZ, L:) or he asked me, and did so much, after he had asked me and I had given him. (As, L.) ― -b7- He instigated; incited; excited. (K.)

lijaA*N *
Glue; syn. giraA='N [for which Freytag seems to have read A_igoraA='N]. (K.)

daAb~apN milojaA*N *
A beast of carriage that takes the leguminous herbage with the fore part of its mouth, (K,) and the extremities of its teeth. (TA.)

nbotN majoluw*N *
A plant which the teeth cannot crop, by reason of its shortness, and which the camels therefore pluck with the fore part of the mouth. (L.)
See Supplement

1 laHiHato Eayonuhu * , (S, L, K,) aor. taloHaHu, inf. n. laHaHN; (L;) and laH~ato; (L;) [as also laxixato:] His eyelids stuck together, by reason of a white thick matter collected in their corners: (S, L, K:) or, by reason of pain: or, by reason of many tears: (L:) the former is one of those verbs which retain their original forms, like Dabiba in the phrase Dabiba Albaladu, with the reduplication distinct: (S:) also, laH~ato Eayonuhu his eye shed many tears, and its lids became thick, or rough; like lax~ato. (L.) ― -b2- laH~ati AlqaraAbapu bayonanaA, inf. n. laH~N, The relationship between us was close. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.) See laH~N.

4 AlH~ * , (inf. n. A_iloHaAHN, Msb,) It [a cloud) rained continually, or incessantly. (S, Msb, K) Hence the phrase AlH~ ElY $Y [q. v. infra]. (Msb) ― -b2- AlH~ Ealoyhi, (inf. n. A_iloHaAHN, L,) He importuned him; plied him; plied him hard; pressed him; pressed upon him; pressed him hard; was urgent with him; persecuted, or harassed, him, (L,) biA@lomasoA^alapi, (S, L,) or fiY Als~aw^aAli, (K,) in asking, begging, or petitioning; like A^aloHafa. (S, L, K.) AlH~ ElY gariymihi He pressed his creditor perseveringly, assiduously, or constantly. (L.) And A^aloHaHotu EalaY fulaAnK fiY AlAit~ibaAEi Hat~aY A@xotalafotuh, i. e. [I pressed upon such a one in following] until I made him to be behind me. (ISk, TA in art. xlf.) AlH~ EalaY $aYo'K [and fiY $aYo'K] He applied himself to a thing perseveringly, persistently, assiduously, or constantly, (Msb,) or incessantly. (L.) AlH~ fiY $aYo'K He asked, begged, or petitioned, for a thing much, or frequently; as though he stuck to it. (L.) AlH~ EalaY gay~ihi [and fY gay~ihi He persevered, or persisted, in his error]. (Msb, art. mdY.) ― -b3- It (a cloud) remained, or stayed, bimakaAnK in a place; like A^alav~a. (As, S.) ― -b4- AlH~ (tropical:) He (a camel) was restive, or refractory, and would not move from his place; (S, L, K;) like as you say of a she-camel xalaA^ato, (As, S,) and of a horse and the like Hazana: (As:) and AlH~t she (a camel) did the same; (L, K;) accord. to some, and so used in a trad. (TA.) ― -b5- AlH~ti AlmaTiY~u (tropical:) The beasts of carriage, or the
camels, were fatigued, and became slow, or tardy. (K.) ― -b6- AlH~ (tropical:) It (a saddle of the kind called qatab, L, K, and a raHol, and a horse's saddle, L) wounded the back. (L, K.) See miloHaAHN.

R. Q. 1 laHolaHuwA * , (K,) and ↓ talaHolaHuwA, (S, K,) They remained fixed, or firm, in their place; did not quit it. (S, K.) ― -b2- ↓ talaHolaHa He (a camel) stayed, and remained fixed, or firm. (L.) ― -b3- Also ↓ tlHlHwA They became dispersed; formed by transposition from tHlHlwA. (L.)

R. Q. 2
See R. Q. 1.

huwa A@bonu Eam~iY laH~FA * [He is my cousin on the father's side,] closely related: (S, K:) from the phrase laHiHato Eayonuhu. (S.) Here lH~A is put in the acc. case as a denotative of state, because what precedes it is determinate. (S.) And you say huwa A@bonu Eam~K laH~K [He is a cousin on the father's side,] closely related, (S, K,) in an indeterminate phrase employing laH~K as an epithet to Eam~K. (S.) You say the same in the case of the fem. and dual and pl.; (S;) making no difference between the sing. and dual and pl. and fem. (L.) Lh says, that one says, [of two persons who are cousins, one to the other,] humaA A@bonaA Eam~K laH~K, and laH~FA; and in like manner hmA AbnA xaAlapK; but not hmA AbnA xaAlK laH~FA, nor AbnA Eam~apK laH~FA. (L.) When the Abn Em~ is not in the state termed laH~, but is of the Ea$iyrap, you say huwa A@bonu Eam~i AlkalaAlapi, and Abnu Eam~K kalaAlapN. (S, K.) [See also dinoyFA; and the contr., ZohrFA.]
laHiHN * and laHolaHN: see laAH~N.

laAH~N * (S, K) and ↓ laHiHN and ↓ laHolaHN (K) A strait, or confined, place. (S, K.) Also, laAH~N, A valley with tangled, confused, intertwined, or complicated, trees, which stick together: or strait, or confined, and abounding with tangled trees, and stones. In both senses, applied to a place and a valley, it is also written laAx~N, with x. (L.) [See laAx~N.]
A^alaH~u * [More, and most, importunate, pressing, persevering, &c.]. (TA, art. xnfs; see the same article in the present work.)
muliH~N * That stands still by reason of fatigue, and will not move from its place. (TA.) ― -b2- A beast of carriage which, when it lies down, remains immovable, and will not be roused up. (L.)

miloHaAHN * A cloud continually, or incessantly, raining. (L.) ― -b2- A man [very] importunate, pressing, persevering, assiduous, or constant, in asking, begging, petitioning, or seeking. (L.) ― -b3- raHFY miloHaAHN EalaY maA taToHanuhu (S) A mill-stone that presses hard upon that which it grinds. (A.) ― -b4- miloHaAHN (tropical:) A saddle of the kind called qatab that wounds the back; (K;) that wounds the camel's withers; (S;) that sticks close to the camel's back, and wounds it; and in like manner a saddle of the kind called raHol, and a horse's saddle. (L.) ― -b5- Whatever is slow, or tardy. (L.)

1 laHaba * , aor.
laHaba , (S, K,) inf. n. laHobN; (S;) and ↓ AltHb; (K;) He trod, and passed along, a road, such as is termed laHobN, (S, K,) or simply, a road. (TA.) So also AltHm. Lth.) -A2- laHabahu and ↓ lH~bh He smote him with a sword: (K:) or wounded him with it. (Th.) ― -b2- laHabahu and ↓ lH~bh He made a mark, or impression, upon it. (K.) ― -b3- He flogged him with whips, and made marks, or scars, upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- laHabahu, (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He cut it (i. e. flesh-meat) lengthwise. (K.) ― -b5- laHaba (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He stripped off meat from the bone. (S, K.) ― -b6- He (a butcher) took what was on the back of the slaughtered camel. (TA.) ― -b7- He peeled a stick or the like, (S,) or anything. (TA.) ― -b8- It (the portion next the back-bone, on either side, of a horse, (K,) or his rump, TA) was smooth, and sloping downwards: syn. A_imolaA^as~a fiY HuduwrK. (K.) ― -b9- laHaba, aor.
laHaba , inf. n. luHuwbN, It (a road) became conspicuous, clear, or open: (K:) as though it peeled [the surface of] the ground. (TA.) ― -b10- laHaba, inf. n. laHobN, He made a road conspicuous, or clear. (K, TA.) So in the saying of Umm-Selmeh to 'Othmán, laA tuEaf~i TariyqFA kaAna rasuwlu All~`hi SlEm laHabahaA Do not thou efface a road which the Apostle of God, &c., made conspicuous, or clear. (TA.) -A3- laHaba (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Inivit feminam. (K.) See laxaba. ― -b2- laHaba bih AlA^aroDa He threw him down prostrate upon the ground. (K.) ― -b3- laHaba, (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He (a man) passed, or went along, through the land: (TA:) or he went right on, or straight on: (S, K:) or he hastened in his pace; went quickly. (K.) -A4- laHiba, aor.
laHaba , [inf. n. laHabN,] He (a man) became emaciated by reason of old age, (S, K,) and weakness. (TA.)
2 laH~aba see 1.
8 A_ilotaHaba see 1.

laHobN * and ↓ laAHibN (S, K: the latter word of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: i. e. maloHuwbN: S) and ↓ mulaH~abN (K) A conspicuous road: (S, K:) a wide, extended, road, that is not interrupted. (TA.)

laHiybN * A she-camel having little flesh in her back: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) originally, it seems, in the sense of maloHuwb, as though meaning “ peeled ” by travel; and afterwards, its original attributive character being forgotten among a people, used without p [when not preceded by the noun which it qualifies, as when preceded by that noun]. (TA.)
laAHibN * : see laHobN.

miloHabN *
Anything with which a thing is cut or peeled: (S, K:) cutting, or sharp, iron. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A great reviler, or vilifier, of obscene tongue. (S, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A chaste, or an eloquent, tongue. (T.)

maloHuwbN *
Smooth, and sloping downwards: an epithet applied to the portion next the back-bone, on either side, [or to the rump,] of a horse. (TA.) [See an ex. voce quSobN.] ― -b2- A man of little flesh; emaciated: as though peeled. (TA.)

mulaH~abN *
Cut in pieces: syn. muqaT~aEN. (S.) ― -b2- See laHobN.

1 laHata * , aor.
laHata , (inf. n. laHotN, TA,) He beat, struck, or smote, a person with a staff, or stick. (K.) -A2- laHata, aor.
laHata , (inf. n. laHotN, TA,) He peeled, or unbarked, a staff, or stick: (K:) or sawed it, and peeled, or unbarked it: as also naHata. (IAar.) ― -b2- h`*aA rajulN laA yaDiyruka Ealayohi naHotFA walaHotFA expl. by mA yzydk Elyh nHtA All$Er wlHtA lh (tropical:) [This is a man than whom none will be more useful to thee in the trimming of verses: yDyrk, which is written without the syll. points, is probably a mistake for yaDur~uka: see art. Dr]. (IAar.) ― -b3- laHatahu biAlEa*oli, aor.
laHata , inf. n. laHotN, [He trimmed him with reproof]: a phrase similar to that immediately preceding. (TA, app. from IAar.) ― -b4- laHatahu, aor.
laHata , inf. n. laHotN, (assumed tropical:) He took what he had, leaving him nothing; as also lataHahu. (TA.) -A3- laHata Inivit puellam: as also naHata, but this latter is not so well known. (TA, art. nHt.)

barodN baHotN laHotN *
i. q. SaAdiqN; (Sgh, K;) [i.e., Vehement, or intense, cold: see baHotN: and see also laxotN]. laHotN is here a mere imitative sequent. (TA.)

1 laHija * aor.
laHaja , (inf. n. laHajN, S,) It (a sword, S, K, or other thing, S) stuck fast in the scabbard, (S, K,) and would not come forth; like laSiba. (S.) ― -b2- laHija AlxaAtamu fiY AlA_iSobaEi The sealring stuck fast upon his finger. (A.) ― -b3- laHija bayonahumu Al$~ar~u Evil stuck fast between, or among, them. (TA.) ― -b4- laHija bimakaAnK He clave fast to a place; kept fast, or close, to it. (TA.) ― -b5- laHija fiY AlA^amori
He entered into an affair and became entangled in it so that he could not extricate himself. (TA.) ― -b6- laHaja A_ilayohi, aor.
laHaja , inf. n. laHojN; and ↓ AltHj; He inclined to him, or it. (TA.) By the following words of Ru-beh,
A^awo taloHaju AlA^alosunu min~aA maloHajaA
is meant, Or tongues speak of us, and incline from what is good to that which is bad. (L.) [For mnhA, in the L, I have substituted mn~A. mlHj seems to be an inf. n.] ― -b7- laHaja A_ilayohi, [and ↓ AltHj, Golius, from Ibn-Maaroof,] He had recourse to him or it for protection or concealment. (K.) ― -b8- laHija It (a thing) became strait, narrow, or confined. (TA.)

2 lH~j Ealayohi Alxabara * , inf. n. taloHiyjN; and Ealayohi ↓ laHowajahu, inf. n. laHowajapN; He rendered the news, or information, confused to him, and told him something different from that which was in his mind: (S, K:) or the phrase with the former verb signifies he told him news, or a piece of information, different * from that which was in his mind; and that with the latter verb, he rendered the news, or information, confused to him. (Az.) See 5.

4 AlHjhu A_ilayohi * , He caused him to incline to him, or it. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHjhu A_ilayohi, (K,) and ↓ AltHjhu, (S, K,) He constrained, compelled, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or to do, it, (S, K.)
5 tlH~j Ealayohi AlA^amora * , and Elyh ↓ laHowajahu, He represented the affair to him not as it was in his mind. (L.) See 2.
8 A_ilotaHaja see 1 and 4.

10 A_isotaloHaja
AstlHj AlbaAba [app. He found the door stuck fast]: (A:) [but I think it not improbable that the right reading is AlbaAbu; and the meaning, the door stuck fast].
Q. Q. 1 laHowaja * : see 2 and 5.
luHojN * : see lujoHN.
laHijN * A strait, narrow, or confined, place. (S, K.)

maloHajN * (K) and ↓ mulotaHajN (As, S, K) A place to which one has recourse for protection or concealment; a place of refuge; an asylum. (As, S, K.) ― -b2- malaAHiju Strait, narrow, or confined, places. (S, K.) ― -b3- malaAHiyju Narrow roads in mountains. (TA.)

xuT~apN maloHuwjapN *
A confused and crooked business. (L.)

qufolN mulaH~ajN *
A lock that is not [or, app., that cannot be] opened. (A.)
mulotaHajN * see maloHajN.

1 laHada * (A) and ↓ AlHd (L, K) (tropical:) He, or it, (as an arrow, A) declined, or deviated, from the right course: (A, L, K:) and also he, or it, inclined: you say laHada A_ilayohi, (A, L, K,) aor.
laHada ; (L;) and ↓ AlHd (A;) and ↓ AltHd; (S, L, K;) he, or it, inclined to him, or it. (A, L, K.) Some read, [in the Kur xvi. 105,] lisaAnu A@l~a*iY yaloHaduwna A_ilayohi (tropical:) [The tongue of him unto whom they incline]. (S.) ― -b2- fiY Ald~iyni ↓ AlHd; (S, A, L, Msb;) and laHada fiyhi, (S, L, Msb,) aor.
laHada ; (L;) (tropical:) He deviated, or swerved, from the right way, with respect to religion: (S, A, L:) he impugned religion. (Msb.) ― -b3- fiY AlHarami ↓ AlHd (tropical:) He relinquished, or forsook, the right course, with respect to that which he was commanded to do, in the sacred Temple or territory of Mekkeh; (L, K;) and inclined to do wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously: (L:) or he did wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously, therein; (S, L, K;) and so opposed others: (Fr, L:) or he associated others with God, therein; expl. by A^a$oraka biAll~`hi: so in the K and Basáïr; in the latter as on the authority of Zj: or he doubted respecting God, therein: so in the L and other lexicons, as on the authority of Zj: (TA:) or he hoarded up corn in expectation of its becoming dear, therein; (L, K;) a meaning taken from a trad of 'Omar; (L;) but this is merely a kind of wrong-doing: (TA:) or he desecrated it, and violated its sanctity. (Msb.) The origin of the phrase is in the text of the Kur [xx. 26,] wamano yurido fiyhi biA_iloHaAdK biZulomK, i.e. A_iloHaAdFA biZulomK, the b being redundant. (S, L.) -A2- laHada Alqabora, aor.
laHada , (inf. n. laHodN; L,) and ↓ AlHdhu; (A, L, K;) and laHada lahu laHodFA; and lh ↓ AlHd; (S, Msb;) He made a laHod to the grave. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- laHada A@lomay~ita, aor.
laHada , inf. n. laHodN; and ↓ AlHdhu; and laHada lahu; and lh ↓ AlHd; He made a laHod for the corpse: or ↓ AlHdhu has this signification; (L;) and in like manner, laHada lah laHodFA, and ↓ AlHd, he dug a laHod for him: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and laHadahu, he buried him; (L, K;) or put him into a lHd; and so ↓ AlHdhu. (Mgh, Msb.)
3 lAHdhu * (assumed tropical:) He behaved towards him in a crooked, or perverse, manner, the latter doing the same. (K, * TA.)

4 AlHd * : see 1, throughout. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He disputed; altercated; wrangled. (A' Obeyd, L, Msb, K.) ― -b3- AlHd bihi (assumed tropical:) He brought a reproach upon him, or held him in light estimation, or despised him, (A^azoraY bihi,) and said of him what was false: (K:) or he held his clemency, or forbearance, or intellect, (Hilom,) in light estimation; or despised it; as also A^alohada bihi. (L.)
8 AltHd A_ilayohi * (tropical:) He had recourse, or betook himself, to it, or him, for refuge, protection, concealment, covert, or lodging. (A.)

laHodN * (S, A, L, Msb, K) and ↓ luHodN (S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ laHadN (El-Basáïr) and ↓ maloHuwdN, (A, L, K,) which last is an epithet wherein the quality of a subst. is predominant, (L,) A trench or an oblong excavation, in the side of a grave; a lateral hollow of a grave; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) which is the place of the corpse; what is called DariyHN and DariyHapN is in the middle: (L:) pl. (of the first, Msb) luHuwdN and (of the second, Msb) A^aloHaAdN. (L, Msb, K.) Accord. to some, lHd used in this sense is tropical; from laHada and A^aloHada signifying “ he inclined, or declined. ” (MF.) [The reverse, however, is the case accord. to the A.] [See an ex. in a verse cited voce $adiydN.]
luHodN * and laHadN: see laHodN.
laAHidN * : see maloHuwdN.

muloHidN * act. part. n. of 4, q. v.: (tropical:) One who deviates, or swerves, from the truth, and introduces into it that which does not belong to it: (ISk, L:) an impugner of religion: (Msb in art. rndq;) pl. muloHiduwna (Msb) [and malaAHi*apN]. Some apply the appellation of AlmuloHiduwna especially to the Bátinees (AlbaATiniy~ap), who assert that the Kur-án has an outward sense and an inward, the latter differing from the former, and known to them; by which doctrine they have perverted the law. (Msb.)
muloHadN * : see maloHuwdN.
maloHuwdN * (A, K) and ↓ muloHadN, (S, A,) or maloHuwdN lahu and lahu ↓ muloHadN, (L,) and ↓ laAHidN, (K,) A grave having a laHod made to it. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- See laHodN.

mulotaHadN * (tropical:) A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, concealment, covert, or lodging: a place of refuge; an asylum: (S, Msb, K:) so called because one turns aside to it. (S.)

1 laHisahu * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or laHisahu bilisaAnihi, (A,) aor.
laHasa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. laHosN (S, A, Msb, K) and maloHasN (A K) and laHosapN and luHosapN, (Yaakoob, S, K,) the last mentioned by ISk, (TA,) He licked it; (S, A, K, TA;) namely, a bowl, (S, K,) and a vessel: (S:) All~aHosu is with the tongue: (S, K:) or laHsahu
signifies he took what was upon it, (Mgh,) or what adhered to its sides, (Msb,) with his tongue or his finger; (Mgh, Msb;) the suffixed pronoun referring to a bowl (Mgh, Msb) or some other thing: (Mgh:) and he took it (a thing) with his tongue. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, A^asoraEu mino laHosi Alkalobi A^anofahu [Quicker than the dog's licking his nose]. (S, A.) See also maloHasN, below. ― -b2- laHisa Ald~uwdu AlS~uwfa, (A, Mgh, Msb,) in measure like labisa, (Mgh,) or laHasa, like manaEa, (K,) inf. n. laHosN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) The worms ate the wool: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and in like manner, lHs AljaraAdu AlxuDara (A, K) and Al$~ajara, (TA,) the locusts ate the green plants (K) and the trees. (TA.)

4 AlHst AlA^aroDu * (tropical:) The land produced plants, or herbage: (S:) or began to produce leguminous plants: (K:) or produced the first of the herbage, so that the beasts saw it and desired it and licked it, not being able to eat of it anything: (TA:) or produced what the beasts of carriage might lick or eat (maA taloHasuhu): (A, TA:) or [became in such a state that] the beasts of carriage licked or ate (laHasato) its plants, or herbage. (Sgh, K.) -A2- AlHs AlmaA$iyapa (tropical:) He pastured the camels or sheep or goats with the least pasturing. (K.)
8 AltHs minohu Haq~ahu * (tropical:) He took from him his (the former's, A) right, or due. (A, K.)
laHosapN * : see 1. [Accord. to analogy, it is an inf. n. of un.]
luHosapN * [The quantity that one takes by one lick with the tongue. Hence the saying,] maA laka EinodiY luHosapN I have not anything for thee, or belonging to thee. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.
laHuwsN * : see miloHasN.
laHowasN * : see miloHasN.
laH~aAsN * A man who licks much what comes to him. (TA.) ― -b2- laH~aAsapN A moth-worm, that eats wool; syn. Euv~apN. (TA.) ― -b3- A lioness. (K.)

sanapN laA HisapN * (tropical:) A distressful, or calamitous, year; (K;) a year that consumes all the herbage: (A, TA:) and lawaAHisu, [the pl., sinuwnN, being understood,] distressful, or calamitous, years. (A, TA.)
laA HuwsN * : see miloHasN.

maloHasN * is a noun of place; [signifying A place of licking; &c;] as well as an inf. n.: and in both cases it has malaAHisu for pl. (IJ.) You say, tarakotuhu bimalaA Hisi Albaqari, (S, A, K,) or bimalaAHisi Albaqari A^awolaAdahaA, (TA,) meaning, (tropical:) I left him in the places where the wild cows lick their young ones (S, ISd, A, K) from the membranes in which they are born: (ISd, TA:) or in a desert place, (S,) or in a desert, or waterless desert, (ISd, A, TA,) so that it was not known where he was; (S;) because the wild cows bring forth only in the deserts: (ISd, TA:) the former is like the saying bimabaAHivi Albaqari; (S;) and is that which ISd holds to be the right: (TA:) in the latter, mlAHs is an inf. n., in the pl. form, which is strange; because it governs AwlAd in the accus. case; and a prefixed noun [mawaADiE] is understood before it: (IJ:) some relate the saying differently, thus, bimaloHasi Albaqari A^awolaAdahaA, meaning, bimawoDiEi maloHasi Albaqari A^awolaAdahaA [in the place of the cows' licking their young ones]; (K;) because [some hold that] an inf. n. of the measure mafoEalN has no pl. (TA.)
muloHisN * : see miloHasN.

miloHasN * (tropical:) Greedy; as also ↓ laHowas (K) and ↓ laAHuwsN and ↓ muloHisN: (TA:) and one who takes everything that he can. (K:) or a greedy man, who takes everything that he can: (A:) one who takes everything that appears to him: (TA:) [originally, a lick-dish:] and [in like manner] ↓ laHuwsN (tropical:) a man who seeks after sweets, like the fly. (A, K.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) Courageous: (K:) as though an eater of everything that rose up to him. (TA.)
2 lH~Shu * see lx~Shu.

1 laHaZahu * , (S, K,) or laHaZahu biAlEayoni, (Msb,) and laHaZa A_ilayohi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
laHaZa , inf. n. laHoZN (Msb, K) and laHaZaAnN, (K,) He looked at him from the outer angle of the eye, (S, Msb, K,) to the right or left, (Msb, TA,) with more turning of the face than is denoted by $azorN; (Msb, K;) or without turning the face: (TA:) or he watched him with the eye: (Msb:) and hence ↓ mulaAHaZapN, of the measure mufaAEalapN, (K, TA,) explained by Az as signifying a man's looking from the outer angle of either eye. (TA.)

3 lAHZhu * , (S, Msb,) inf. n. mulaAHaZapN (Msb, K) and liHaAZN, (S, Msb,) [i. q. laHaZahu, q. v. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He regarded him; had regard, or an eye, to him; paid regard, or consideration, to him; he regarded it, [namely, an affair,] or attended to it; syn. raAEaAhu. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) He, or it, had a relation, or an analogy, to him, or it.]

6 tlAHZwA * (TA) They turned their eyes, [each looking from the outer angle of his eye,] one towards another. (K, L.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) They regarded one another; had regard, or an eye, one to another; paid regard, or consideration, one to another. ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) They had a mutual relation, or analogy.]
laHoZN * : see laHaAZN.

laHoZapN *
A look from the outer angle of the eye; a sidelong glance; an ogle; a look from the side next the ear: pl. laHaZaAtN: the dim. is luHayoZapN. (TA.) Hence the saying jalasotu Einodahu laHoZapF I sat with him the like of [the time occupied by] a look from the outer angle of the eye. (TA.) And fiY laHoZapK [In the twinkling of an eye]. (K in art. srE; &c.)

laHaAZN * , (S, Msb, K,) with fet-h, (S, Msb,) like saHaAbN, (K,) or ↓ liHaAZN, (T, IB, Mgh, Msb,) with kesr, (T, IB, Msb,) which latter is the form commonly known, (IB,) or the latter is incorrectly used for the former by some who twist the sides of the mouth in utterance, (MF,) or is [only] an inf. n. of laAxaZa, (S,) The outer angle of the eye, (T, S, Mgh, &c.,) next the part between the eye and the ear; (T, Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ laHoZN: pl. of the former luHuZN: and of the latter A^aloHaAZN. (TA.) You say, fatanatohu bilaHaAZihaA [She captivated his heart with the outer angle of her eye], and biA^aloHaAZihaA [with the outer angles of her eyes]. (TA.)
liHaAZN * : see laHaAZN.
laHiyZN * (assumed tropical:) Like. (K.) You say, huwa laHiyZu fulaAnK. (assumed tropical:) He is the like of such a one. (TA.)
rajulN laH~aAZN * [A man who has a habit of looking from the outer angle of the eye]. (TA.)

maloHaZN *
syn. with [the inf. n.] laHoZN: or it signifies mawoDiEu laHoZK [i.e. the place at which one looks from the outer angle of the eye]: pl. malaAHiZu. (TA.)

[
maloHuwZN * (assumed tropical:) Regarded; had in view.]
A^aHowaAluhumo muta$aAkilapN mutalaAHiZapN * (tropical:) [Their states, or conditions, are similar; such as have mutual relation, or analogy]. (TA.)

1 lax~ato Eayonuhu * , (S, L, K,) aor. talix~N, inf. n. lax~N and laxiyxN, (L,) His eye shed copious tears, (S, L, K,) and its lids became rough. (L.) ― -b2- laxixato Eayonuhu, as also laHiHato, His eyelids stuck together, by reason of a white thick matter collected in their corners. (L.) See lH~. ― -b3- lax~a fiY kalaAmihi, [aor., accord. to analogy,
laxi3a ,] He was obscure and barbarous in his speech. (K.)

8 Altx~ Ealayohimo A^amoruhumo *
Their affair, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to them. (S, K. *) ― -b2- Altx~ It (herbage) became tangled, or luxuriant. (S, K.)

lax~apN *
Obscureness and barbarousness in speech. (TA.) -A2- A dirty, stinking, woman. (K.)

waAdK laAx~N * , (As, Ibn-Ma'een, K,) and laAH~N, (K,) or this is incorrect, (Ibn-Ma'een,) A valley having intricate defiles, or narrow passes: (K:) or, abounding with trees, and intricate; as also ↓ mulotax~N: (L:) or, intricate by reason of its trees: (As:) or it is lAx, without teshdeed, [i. e. laAxN, or, as its derivation presently mentioned implies, laAxK,] (Sh, K,) from A^aloxaY, distorted (L, K) [but in the former written AlxA='] in the mouth. (L.) ― -b2- jawofN lAx~N A deep valley. (IAar.)

laxolaxaAniY~N * , (S, K,) fem. with p, (L,) A man whose speech, or utterance, is characterized by what is termed laxolaxaAniy~ap, or barbarousness, or vitiousness, &c.: (L:) not chaste in speech, or utterance. (S, K.)

laxolaxaAniy~apN *
A barbarousness, or vitiousness, in speech, or utterance; a want of chasteness therein; an - impotence, or impediment, or a difficulty, therein. (AO, S, L, K.) It is a quality of the dial. of the Arabs of the desert of Esh-Shahr and 'Omán; as when they say, for maA $aA='a A@ll~`hu, ma$aA='a A@ll~`hu: (Eth-Tha'álibee:) or is derived from laxolaxaAnu, the name of a tribe: or, as some say, of a place. (L.) naZara fulaAnN naZara All~axaloxaAniy~api Such a one looked with the look of barbarians, or foreigners; or, of those who are barbarous in speech. (As.)

sakoraAnu mulotax~N * , (S, K,) vulg. muloTax~N, (S,) or mulaT~axN, (as in some copies of the S and K,) but this should not be said, (K,) A drunken man confused in his intellect, (S, L,) and not understanding anything: (L:) or, full of drink; (K;) as also murotax~N. (TA in art. rx.) ― -b2- See laAx~N.

1 laxaba *
He slapped a person; struck him with the open hand. (K.) -A2- laxaba, aor.
laxaba and
laxuba , (inf. n. laxobN, TA,) Inivit feminam: (Kr, K:) but the word commonly known, related by Yaakoob and others, is naxaba. (ISd.)
3 lAxbhu * , inf. n. mulaAxabapN (and lixaAbN, TA), He slapped him, being also slapped by him. (K.)
laxabN * The trees which produce what is called muqolN, q. v. (K.)
mulax~abN * One who is slapped much, or violently, in altercations. (K.)

laxotN *
Great, or big, in body: (Lth, Sgh, and some copies of the K:) or great, or big, and corpulent. (So in the other copies of the K.) ― -b2- A woman in whom the division between the vagina and the rectum has been broken through; syn. mufuDaApN. (K.) ― -b3- Har~N saxotN laxotN Vehement, or intense, heat. (Lth, K.) [See also saxotN: and see laHotN.] Thought by ISd to be arabicized. (TA.)

2 lax~aSa
lx~Shu, (A, TA,) inf. n. taloxiySN, (S, A, K,) He explained, expounded, or interpreted, it; (S, A, K;) he made it clear; (A, K;) namely, language: (A:) taloxiySN and taboyiynN and $aroHN and taxoliySN all signify the same: (A:) he went to the utmost point in explaining it, expounding it, interpreting it, and making it plain: namely, a thing; as also lH~Shu. (TA.) You say, lax~iSo liY xabaraka Explain thou to me thy news, or information, thing after thing. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Alee, qaEada litaloxiySi maA A@lotabasa EalaY gayorihi He sat to make clear what was confused and dubious to others. (TA.) ― -b2- He made it near: [the inf. n. being explained in the TA by Altqryb; but I incline to think that this is a mistranscription, for Alt~Eoriybu; and that the meaning is, he made it clear, plain, distinct, or perspicuous:] he abridged it: he restricted, or limited, himself in it, namely, a saying, and abridged of it what was needful. (TA.)
mulax~aSN * The sum or result or conclusion [of a thing]. (TA.)
See Supplement

1 lad~ * , originally ladida, (second pers. ladidota, L,) aor.
lada3a , (L, Msb,) inf. n. ladadN (S, A, L, Msb,) He was violent, or vehement, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (S, A, L, Msb.) ― -b2- lad~ahu, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
lada3a , (S, L, Msb,) inf. n. lad~N, (L, Msb,) He overcame him in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (S, * L, K: *) or he opposed him violently, or vehemently, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (Msb.) ladidota, (in some copies of the K, ladadota,) inf. n. laddN, (IKtt, L: in the K, lad~N:) Thou becamest such as is called A^alad~ [violent, or vehement, in contention, &c.]. (IKtt, L, K.) ― -b3- lad~ahu Eani AlA^amori, (inf. n. lad~N, L,) He restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, or prevented, him from doing the thing: (L, K: *) he made him to return or revert, or turned him back or away, with gentleness, from the thing, or affair; like rad~ahu: (T and L, art. rd:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (L.) -A2- lad~ahu, (K,) or lad~ahu biAll~aduwdi, (M,) aor.
ladu3a , (L,) inf. n. lad~N and luduwdN; (M, K;) and ↓ Ald~hu; (S, L, K;) and lad~ahu All~aduwda; (M, L, K;) He administered to him the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd. (S, * M, L, K. *) The action termed All~ad~u is the taking a child's tongue, and drawing it to one side, and pouring medicine in the other side, between the tongue and the side of the mouth. (Fr, L.) ― -b2- lud~a He had a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd administered to him. (S, L, K.) See also 8. ― -b3- ladadotuhumu Aln~aSiyHapa (tropical:) I administered to them sincere, or faithful, advice, or counsel, like as one administers the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd. (L.)

2 ld~d bihi *
i. q. nd~d bh, (L, K,) i. e., He rendered him notorious, or infamous. (L.)

3 lAd~hu * , inf. n. lidaAdN (A, Msb) and mulaAd~apN, (A,) He contended with him violently, or vehemently, in an altercation; in a dispute; in a litigation. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- maA zilotu A^ulaAd~u Eanoka I ceased not to repel from thee; or, to defend thee. (S.)

4 Ald~hu *
He found him to be such as is called A^alad~ [violent, or vehement, in contention, &c]. (TA.) ― -b2- Ald~ bihi He opposed him in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (TA.) See also 1 and 3.

5 tld~d * (tropical:) He turned his face to the right and left, (S, L, K,) in confusion, perplexity, or amazement: (L, K:) from All~adiydaAni signifying “ the two sides ” of the neck. (S, L.) ― -b2- He tarried, or waited, in expectation. (K, TA.)
8 Altd~ * , (S, L, K,) and Altd~ laduwdFA, (S, L,) He swallowed a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd. (S, * L, * K.) See also lud~D. -A2- Altd~ Eanohu He declined from him, or it. (K.)
lad~N * : see laAd~N. ― -b2- A [sack of the kind called] juwaAliq: (S, L, K:) like labiydN. (TA.)

laduwdN * : see laAd~N. -A2- laduwdN and ↓ ladiydN A medicine (or draught, As, L) that is poured into one of the two sides of the mouth (As, S, L, K) by means of the instrument called musoEuT: (L, K:) pl. A^alid~apN: (S, L, K:) from All~adiydaAni signifying “ the two sides ” of a valley. (S, L.) It is said in a proverb, jaraY minohu majoraY All~aduwdi [It acted upon him, or affected him, like the medicine,
or draught, termed laduwd; i. e., unpleasantly, or disagreeably]. (ISk, S.) See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 282

ladiydN * : see laduwdN. -A2- ladiydaAni The two sides of a valley: (S, A, L:) each of them is called ladiydN: (L:) and the two sides of the neck, (S, A, L, K,) below the ears: (L, K:) or the two lateral muscles of the neck: (M, L:) the two sides of the mouth: (A, L:) and of the penis: (L:) and (as some say, L) of anything: (L, K:) pl. A^alid~apN: (S, L, K:) and ladiydN, accord. to AA, signifies the outside of the neck. (L.) -A3- See laAd~N.

laAd~N * and ↓ laduwdN, (S, L, Msb, K,) the latter having an intensive sense, and ↓ lad~N, which is an inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore also intensive], (Msb,) A man who overcomes in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (S, * L, K: *) or, who opposes violently, or vehemently, and very violently, or vehemently, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (Msb:) and ↓ A^alad~u (S, L, Msb, K) and ↓ A^alanodadN and ↓ yalanodadN (S, L, K) a man violent, or vehement, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (S, L, Msb:) or difficult therein, and vehement in war: (IKtt:) or a contentious, disputatious, or litigious, (L,) and tenacious adversary, who will not incline to the truth: (L, K:) the fem. of ↓ A^lad~u is lad~aA='u: (L, Msb:) and the pl, lud~N (S, L, Msb, K) and lidaAdN: (L, K:) the A^ in ↓ A^alanodadN and the Y in ↓ yalanodadN are letters of quasi-coördination, [i. e., added to render those two words quasi-coordinate to safarojalN,] as is shown by the two dáls being not incorporated by idghám; for it is allowable to add a letter at the beginning of a word for the purpose of quasi-coördination when the word has another augmentative letter: (IJ, L:) the dim. of ↓ A^alnodadN is ↓ A^ulayod~u, because it is originally A^alad~u, the n being added to render it quasi-coördinate to safarojalN. (S, L.) qawomFA lud~FA in the Kur, [xix. 97,] is said to signify A people who are adversaries perverted from the truth: or, who are deaf to the truth. (L.) You say also, huwa $adiydN ladiydN [assimilating the second epithet in form to the first, He is strong, and one who overcomes in contention, &c.] (A.)
A^alad~u * and A^alanodadN and yalanodadN and A^ulayod~u: see laAd~N.
maloduwdN * A man who has had a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd administered to him. (S, L, K.)
Almutalad~adu * (tropical:) The neck. (A, L, K.)

maA liY Eanohu mulotad~N *
I have no way of avoiding, or escaping, it: (S, L, K:) as also muHotad~N. (S, L.)
1 ladVba and 3. ladaba and laAdaba: see la*aba.
See Supplement

1 la*~a * , (T, M, L, Msb, K,) second per. la*i*ota, (Msb,) aor. yala*~u, (T, Msb,) inf. n. la*aA*apN (A, L, Msb) and la*aA*N (Msb) and la*~apN; (A;) and ↓ Alt*~, inf. n. A_iloti*A*N; (A;) It (a thing) was, or became la*iy* [i. e. pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; see la*~apN, below; and see TaAba]; (T, M, L, Msb, K;) an object of desire, or a thing desired. (L.) ― -b2- la*~ahu, (M, L, K,) first pers. la*i*otu, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yala*~u, (T, M, L, Msb,) inf. n. la*~N (M, L) and la*~apN (Msb) and la*aA*N and la*aA*apN, (S, M, L, K,) He found it la*iy* [i. e. pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; he delighted in it; he took pleasure, or delight, in it]; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also la*~a bihi, and ↓ Alt*~hu, and bihi ↓ Alt*~, and ↓ Astl*~hu: (M, K:) or he counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, it pleasant, &c.; (L;) as also la*~a bh, and ↓ Alt*~hu, and bh ↓ Altd~, (A, L,) and ↓ Astl*~hu: (S, L, Msb:) la*i*otu Al$~aYo'a and la*i*otu bh and A_isotalo*a*otuhu are syn.; (En-Nadr, T, L;) and so are bh ↓ A_ilota*a*otu and bh ↓ tala*~a*otu. (S, L, Msb.) ― -b3- *aA mim~aA yalu*~uniY, and ↓ yula*~i*uniY, [and yuli*~uniY, (see an ex. of its act. part. n. voce muri*~N, in art. r*,) This is of the things that please, or delight, me]. (A.)
2 la*~a3a see 1.

3 lA*~ Alr~ajulu A@moraA^atahu * , inf. n. mulaA*~apN and li*aA*N, [The man gave pleasure, or delight, or enjoyment, to his wife, receiving the same from her,] on the occasion of contact in the act of concubitus. (A.) See also 6.
4 A^alo*a3a see 1.
5 tala*~a*otu * [I became pleased, or delighted; or I pleased, or delighted, myself]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 1.
6 talaA*~aA * [They (a husband and his wife) gave each other pleasure, or delight, or enjoyment,] on the occasion of contact in the act of concubitus. (A.) See also 3.
8 A_ilota*a3a see 1.
10 A_isotalo*a3a see 1. ― -b2- [Astl*~ also signifies He experienced pleasure, or delight.]

la*~N *
Sleep. (IAar, T, S, L, K.) ― -b2- See also la*~apN and la*iydN.

la*~apN *
Pleasure; delight; contr. of A^alamN; (M, L, K;) so explained because it happens not save to one who is of sound constitution, free from pains; syn. with $ahowapN [in one of the senses of this latter word], or nearly so: (TA:) pleasantness; delightfulness; deliciousness; lusciousness, sweetness: (the Lexicons passim: see the intrans. v. la*~a, of which it is an inf. n.) pl. la*~aAtN. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- ↓ la*owaY, of the measure faEolaY, also signifies the same as la*~apN, and is formed by the change of one of the two dháls into w; [in the L Y;] a change similar to that in taqaD~aY. (L.) It occurs in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, relating to the present world, qado maDaY la*owaAhaA wabaqiYa balowaAhaA [Its pleasure, or delight, or pleasantness, or delightfulness, hath passed away, and its probation remaineth]. (L.) ― -b3- Also la*~apN and ↓ la*aA*apN and ↓ la*iy*N and ↓ la*owaY The eating and drinking in a state of ease, comfort, or pleasure, and competence. (IAar, T, L.) ― -b4- See la*iy*N.

la*iy*N * and ↓ la*~N are used in the same manner, as epithets, (Lth, T, L,) from the intrans. v. la*~a, (L,) signifying Pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; (the Lexicons passim;) desirable, or desired: (L:) pl. of both, li*aA*N; and of the latter, [or of both,] lu*~N. (M, K.) ― -b2- $araAbN la*iy*N, and ↓ la*~N, (S, M, L,) and kaA^osN la*~apN, (M, L,) and $aYo'N la*iy*N, and ↓ la*~N, (A,) A pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury, beverage, or wine, and cup of beverage, or wine, and thing]. ― -b3- [You say] ↓ lahu Eayo$N la*~N [He has a pleasant, or delightful, life]: and mino ↓ huwa fiY la*~K Eayo$K [He is in a pleasant, or delightful, state of life]. (A.) ― -b4- ↓ rajulN la*~N A man of pleasant, or delightful, conversation, or discourse. (A.) ― -b5- A man in the enjoyment of pleasure, or delight: (M, L:) and A^ali*~apN [pl. of la*~N] Those who take their pleasures, or delights. (K.) ― -b6- All~a*iy*u and ↓ All~a*~apu Wine: pl. lu*~N and li*aA*N. (K.) ― -b7- See la*~apN.
la*aA*apN * : see la*~apN, and 1.
la*owaY * : see la*~apN.
*aA A^aToyabu waA^ala*~u * [This is more. or most. pleasant and delightful, &c.] (A.)

mala*~N *
A place of la*~ap [i. e. pleasure, or delight]: pl. malaA*~u. It is said in a trad. A_i*aA rakiba A^aHadukumu Ald~aAb~apa faloyaHomilohaA EalaY malaA*~ihaA [When any one of you rides the beast of carriage, let him urge it to run upon the places that are pleasant to it]; i. e. let him make it run upon plain, or even, not rugged, ground, (L.)

Aall~a*o * and Aall~a*i [thus written with two láms] dial. forms of Al~a*iY: dual All~a*aA, with the n elided: pl. Al~a*iyna; and sometimes, in the nom. case, Al~a*uwna. (S.) Their proper art. is l*Y. (IB, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce tazab~aY.]

1 la*aba * , aor.
la*uba , inf. n. lu*uwbN; and ↓ laA*aba; He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place: (K:) or correctly written with d, unpointed: but IDrd doubts whether correctly with * or with d. (TA.) See also lazaba.
3 laAo*aba see 1.
See Supplement

1 laz~a Al$~aYo'u biAl$~aYo'i * , (TK,) [aor., app.
lazi3a ,] or laz~ahu, aor.
lazu3a , (so in a copy of the Msb,) inf. n. laz~N, (Msb, K,) The thing clave to the thing: (Msb, K, * TK:) it stuck, or adhered, to it. (TA.) See also 8. ― -b2- [Hence,] lazazota biY yaA fulaAnu (tropical:) [Thou hast importuned me, or wearied me by thine importunity, O such a one]. (A.) -A2- laz~ahu, (S, K,) aor.
lazu3a , (S,) inf. n. laz~N (S, K) and lazazN, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or lazaAzN, (L, and so in a copy of the S,) He fastened it, or made it fast; or he bound it, or tied it; syn. $ad~ahu: and he stuck it, or made it to adhere; (S, K;) as also ↓ Alz~hu, (K,) inf. n. A_ilozaAzN. (TA.) [But it is afterwards said in the TA, that, accord. to the TS, A^alozazotu bihi in the sense of A^aloSaqotu bihi was disallowed by As.]) You say also, laz~ahu bihi, (TK,) inf. n. laz~N, (K,) He made it to cleave to it; (K, * TK;) like the lizaAz of a house or chamber. (Lth, TA.) And luz~aA They (two camels) were tied together: and they (the two shanks of a camel) were straitly connected in the shackles. (TA.) ― -b2- He fastened it, namely a door, with a lizaAz, or bar; he barred it. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He thrust or pierced him [with a spear or the like]. (K, * TK.) ― -b4- laz~ahu A_ilaY ka*aA (tropical:) He necessitated him, or constrained him, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing. (A, TA.)

2 laz~azahu *
He (God) caused him to be compact and strong in make. (S, K.)
3 laA zazotuhu * , (inf. n. lizaAzN, TA,) I associated with him; became his companion. (S, * K, * TA.)
4 Alz~hu * : see 1.

8 Altz~ bihi *
It became coupled with it, and stuck to it. (A.) See also 1.

rajulN kaz~N laz~N *
A niggardly, tenacious, man: (AZ, TA:) or the latter epithet is an imitative sequent. (S, K.) ― -b2- laz~u $ar~K: see lizaAzu $ar~K.
liz~N $ar~K * : see lizaAzu $ar~K.

lazazN * : see lizaAzN. -A2- Straitness, difficulty, distress; or the like; syn. $id~apN. (TA.) ― -b2- A state of crowding together of people in a narrow compass. (Msb.) ― -b3- Eayo$N lazazN A strait, or difficult, life (Msb.)

lizaAzN *
A piece of wood with which a door is fastened; the bar of a door; (A, * K, * TA;) as also ↓ lazazN. (K.) [Said in the S, where it is not explained, to be from lizaAzu xaSomK, q. v. infra.; but accord. to the A, it is proper, not tropical.] -A2- huwa lizaAzu maAlK (tropical:) He is one who [by close and constant attention] takes good care of camels, or other property. (A, TA.) [Hence,] jaEalotuka lizaAzFA lifulaAnK (tropical:) I have made or appointed thee [to be a manager of such a one;] not to suffer such a one to disobey or oppose. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- huwa lizaAzu xaSomK (tropical:) [He is one who cleaves to an adversary in contention or litigation]. (S, A.) ― -b3- A_in~ahu lizaAzu xuSuwmapK (tropical:) Verily he is pertinacious in contention or litigation; commissioned and able to manage it. (TA.) ― -b4- fulaAnN lizaAzu $ar~K, (TA,) and $ar~K ↓ laziyzu, and $ar~K ↓ liz~u, (K,) and laz~u $ar~K, (TA,) (tropical:) Such a one is one who pertinaciously adheres to evil or mischief. (K, TA.)
lazuwzN * an imitative sequent to EajuwzN. (K.)
laziyzu $ar~K * : see lizaAzN.

milaz~N * , applied to a man, and in like manner, without p, to a woman, (tropical:) Vehement, or pertinacious, in adhering. (TA.) ― -b2- Vehement in contention or litigation; (S, K;) pertinacious in adhering to that which he desires, or seeks, to obtain. (S.)

laAzibN *
Adhering, or adhesive, or cohesive, clay or mud. (S.) ― -b2- Being, or remaining, fixed, settled, firm, or constant. (S.) ― -b3- SaAra Al$~aYo'u Darobapa laAzibK The thing became fixed, settled, firm, or constant, (S, K,) and severe: (TA:) [or, a constant infliction:] or, indispensable, or necessary: i. e., the blow of a sword that sticks, or remains fixed, [in the wound]. (Aboo-Bekr, cited in the TA.) lAzb is here the same as lAzm: (K:) the latter is the original word; the m being changed into b; and is also used in this phrase: (TA:) but lAzb, in this in-
stance, is the more chaste. (S.) En-Nábighah says,

1 lazija * , aor.
lazaja , (S, M, K,) inf. n. lazajN and luzuwjapN (M) and luzuwjN; (Msb;) and ↓ tlz~j; (M;) It (a thing, S) stretched out, in a neut. sense: it roped; or drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts: syn. tamaT~aTa and tamad~ada: (S, K:) it was, or became, viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, so as to adhere to the hand and the like. (Msb.) ― -b2- lazija bihi It adhered to him, or it, as glue or the like; syn. gariYa. (S, K.) E. g. A^akalotu $ayoy^FA falazija biA^aSaAbiEiY I ate a thing and it adhered to my fingers. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And] ↓ tlz~j It (food, or ointment,) became [viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, slimy, ropy, or mucilaginous,] like xiTomiY~ [or marsh-mallow]. (M, &c.) ― -b4- Aln~abaAtu ↓ tlz~j i. q. talaj~ana: (S, K:) i. e., The herbage became flaccid, and one part thereof inclined over another: (TA:) [or became flaccid, and of a viscous consistency, or viscous or mucilaginous in its juice; as appears from what here follows]. Ru-beh says, [in the S, El-'Ajjáj,] describing a pair af asses, male and female,
wafaraEaA mino raEoYi maA talaz~ajaA
[And they finished pasturing upon what had become flaccid, and of a viscous consistency]. For, says J, [immediately after citing these words of the poet,] when herbage begins to dry up, its juice thickens, and becomes like the mucilage of the xiTomiY~ [or marsh-mallow]. (TA.) Or the words of the poet, above quoted, signify, And they finished pasturing upon what they had searched after constantly, or time after time: for talaz~ujN also signifies the searching of a beast of carriage after herbage and leguminous plants, constantly, or time after time: and the two asses are here the agents of the verb tlz~jA. (L.)

laZ~N * , (K,) or laZ~N kaZ~N, (T, S, M,) A man hard, or difficult, in disposition; (S, K;) as also ↓ laZolaAZN: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or a man hard, o difficult, in disposition, (T, M;) and treated with severity, or rigour, (T,) or straitened; (M;) as also ↓ milaZ~N and ↓ miloZaAZN: (M:) kZ~ is app. an imitative sequent. (M.) You say, A_in~ahu ↓ laHadiydN laZolaAZN Verily he is [sharp and] evil (zaEir) in disposition. (TA.)
laZolaAZN * : see laZ~N, in two places. ― -b2- It also signifies Chaste in speech; or eloquent. (TA.) ― -b3- And sometimes, (Fr,) A hot day. (Fr, K.)

muliZ~N *
Keeping, cleaving, or adhering; (T;) not quitting. (T, S.) You say, huwa muliZ~N bihi He is keeping, cleaving, or adhering, to him; (T;) not quitting him. (S, T.) ― -b2- A man much attached, addicted, or given, to a thing; (T;) who applies himself perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, (T, S,) to it; as also ↓ miloZaAZN: (T:) or the latter signifies very persevering, assiduous, or constant. (S, K.)

milaZ~N *
Keeping, cleaving, or adhering, fast: applied to a creditor. (TA.) ― -b2- See also laZ~N.
miloZaAZN * : see muliZ~N, and laZ~N.

laZaA^N *
A little (and mean, or contemptible, TA) thing; a little. (K.)

1 laEiba * , aor.
laEaba , inf. n. laEibN (which is the original [and most common] form, TA) and liEobN (S, K: the latter of these inf. ns. contracted from the former, Msb) and laEobN (K: also contracted from the first: not heard by IKt; but authorized by Mekkee, and, accord. to him,
agreeable with a constant rule, applicable in the case of any word of a similar measure having a guttural letter as its medial radical, whether a noun or verb: (TA:) and A^uloEuwbapN (S, K) and taloEaAbN; (K; but this last has an intensive, or a frequentative, signification; S;) and ↓ lE~b (K) and ↓ tlE~b (S, K: but this last has a frequentative [or an intensive] signification; S; [and so too has that immediately preceding it;]) and ↓ tlAEb; (K;) He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked: contr. of jad~a, which signifies “ he was serious, or in earnest. ” (K.) [You say] bayonahumo A^uloEuwbapN Between them is playing, sporting, or the like. (K.) [And so] ↓ laAEabahaA, (inf. n. mulaAEabapN and liEaAbN, TA,) He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked, with her: (K:) [he toyed, dallied, or wantoned, with her:] and laAEabotu Alr~ajula, inf. n. mlAEbp, I played, &c., with the man. (S) ― -b2- laEibati Alr~iyHu biAlmanozili, and ↓ talaAEabat, (tropical:) [The wind sported with the lighting-place, or place of abode]: i. e., obliterated the traces of it. (TA.) ― -b3- laEiba binaA Almawoju [The waves sported with us]: the commotion of the waves is called “ sporting ” because it does not convey the voyagers to the quarter whither they desire to go. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- laEaba, (and laEiba, K,) aor.
laEaba , inf. n. laEobN; (S, K;) and ↓ AlEb; (K;) He (a child, S) slavered; drivelled; emitted a flow of slaver or drivel from his mouth. (S, K.) The first word is the most approved: (TA:) or AlS~abiY~u ↓ AlEb signifies the child became slavering, or drivelling. (S.)
3 laAoEaba see 1.

4 A^aloEabahaA *
He made her to play, sport, or game, &c., (with him: accord. to the CK:) or he brought her a thing with which to play, &c. (K.) -A2- See 1.

5 tlE~b *
He played time after time. (S.) See 1.
6 talaAoEaba see 1.

10 AstlEbt Aln~axolapu *
The palm-tree produced some unripe dates after its other we had been cut off: (K:) or produced, or put forth, a spadix or more, having yet upon it some remains of its first produce of fruit. (Aboo-Sa'eed.)
laEobN * for EalobN: see the latter.
liEobN * : see laEibN

laEibN * and ↓ liEibN (with two kesrehs, agreeably with a constant rule obtaining in cases of this kind, [whereby the measure faEilN is changed into fiEilN, the medial radical letter being a guttural,] TA, [but in the CK and a MS. copy, ↓ liEobN, which is also regularly changed from the first,]) and ↓ A^uloEubaAnN and ↓ luEabapN (K) and ↓ luEobapN (TA, as from the K, [but not found by me in any copy of the latter work,]) and ↓ tiloEiybapN and ↓ tiloEaAbN (K) and ↓ tiloEaAbapN (S, K) and ↓ taloEaAbN and ↓ taloEaAbapN and ↓ tiliE~aAbN and ↓ tiliE~aAbapN (K: the last like tiliq~aAmapN: the p is added to give [additional] intensiveness to the signification, as in the cases of Eal~aAmapN and nas~aAbapN: it is also used by En-Nábighah El-Jaadee in the place of an inf. n.: TA) and ↓ laEuwbN [which is common to both genders] and ↓ laE~aAbN (A, &c.) One who plays, sports, games, jests, or jokes, much, or often; a great player, sporter, &c. (S, K.)
liEibN * : see laEibN.

laEobapN * (Th, S) and ↓ luEobapN (ISk, S, K) A turn in play, in a game, &c.; a single act of a play or game &c. (S, K, &c.) [You say] ↓ limana All~uEobapu [Whose turn is it to play?] with dammeh to the l, because it is a subst.; (ISk;) [and] A^uqoEudo A^aforuga mino ↓ h`*ihi All~uEobapi [Sit until I finish this turn of the game]: but accord. to Th, it is better to say mn h*h All~aEobapi, with fet-hah; because what is meant is a single turn in the game. (S.) ― -b2- laEibotu laEobapF waAHidapF [I played one game]. (Fr.) -A2- All~aEobapu Albarobariy~apu (in some copies of the K, ↓ All~uEobapu) A certain medicine, resembling what is called Als~uwranojaAnu, which fattens. (K.)

luEobapN *
Anything with which one plays, as $iToranoj and the like, (S, K,) and narod. (S.) See also laEobapN. ― -b2- A man with whom one plays, sports, or jests: (K:) one who is a laughing-stock: (TA:) a stupid fellow, or fool, whom one mocks, laughs at, or ridicules; a stupid laughing-stock (K.) ― -b3- An image or effigy [with which to play: a puppet: so the word signifies in the present day]. (K.) [It was probably sometimes applied to A crucifix. And hence, or perhaps from its resemblance to a man with outstretched arms, it is applied by some post-classical writers to A cross; and anything in the form of a cross.] ― -b4- The image that is seen in the black of the eye when a thing faces it; also called EayorN. (Aboo-Tálib, in L, art. Eyr.) ― -b5- See laEibN.

liEobapN *
A mode, or manner, of playing, sporting, gaming, &c. You say, fulaAnN Hasanu All~iEobapi [Such a one has a good manner of playing, &c. (S.)
luEabapN * : see laEibN.

luEaAbN *
What flows from the mouth; slaver; drivel. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Mucilage of plants. See S, art. lzj &c.] ― -b3- luEaAbu Aln~axoli (tropical:) The honey of the date-palm. (S, K.) ― -b4- luEaAbu Al$~amosi (tropical:) A thing (that one sees, TA) as though descending from the sky, at the time of the mid-day heat; (K;) what one sees in a time of intense heat, resembling cobwebs: [i. e. gossamer:] also said to be the saraAb, or mirage: (S:) it is what is called muxaATu Al$~ayoTaAni, and sahaAmN, and riyqu Al$~amosi, resembling threads, seen in the air when the heat is intense and the air calm: and he who asserts the lEAb Al$ms to be the srAb says what is false; for that is the srAb that is seen at mid-day resembling running water: only he knows these things who has been constantly in the deserts, and has journeyed during the mid-day heats. (Az.) [In Egypt, in very hot and calm weather, I have seen, though very rarely, great quantities of the filmy substances above mentioned, resembling delicate and silky white cobwebs, generally of stringy forms, floating in the air.]

jaAriyapN laEuwbN *
A playful, sportive, or gamesome, damsel: (S:) one who coquets prettily, with affected coyness: (K:) pl. laEaAy^ibu. (TA.) See also laEibN.

laE~aAbN *
One whose business or occupation is playing, gaming, or the like; a player by profession. (TA.) See also laEibN.

laAEibN *
Playing, sporting, gaming, jesting, or joking. (TA.) See also laEibN. ― -b2- laA yaA^oxu*an~a A^aHadukumo mataAEa A^axiyhi laAEibFA jaAd~FA [By no means shall any one of you take the property of his brother in play (and) in earnest]: by this is meant taking a thing without meaning to steal it, but meaning to vex and anger the owner; so that the taker is in play with respect to theft, but in earnest in annoying. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- A_in~amaA A^anota laAEibN [Thou art only playing]: said to anyone who does what is unprofitable. (TA.)

A^uloEuwbapN *
A thing with which one plays (Mz, 40th nwE.) [See also luEobapN.] ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of laEiba. (S, K.)
A^uloEabaAnN * : see laEibN.

maloEabN *
A place of playing, sporting, gaming, or the like; a place where plays, games, or sports, are performed: (S, K:) pl. malaAEibu. (TA.) ― -b2- malaAEibu Alr~iyHi [pl. (tropical:) The sporting-places of the wind;] places where the wind blows, or has blown, vehemently: syn. madaArijuhaA. (K.) ― -b3- tarakotuhu fiY malaAEibi Aljin~i (tropical:) [I left him in the sporting-places of the Jinn, or genii]: i. e., in such a place that he did not know where he was. (TA.)
muloEibapN * and (as in the CK and a MS. copy) ↓ miloEabapN A garment without sleeves, in which a boy plays. (K.)
mulaE~ibN * [Exuding mucilage]; applied to a plant: likened to a foolish person slavering: (TA, in art. Hmq.) [See Albaqolapu AlHamoqaA'u in art. Hmq.]

mulaAEibu Zil~ihi *
A certain bird; (S, K;) found in the desert; (TA;) sometimes called xaATifu Zil~ihi, (S, Msb,) [see art. xTf,] because of the swiftness with which it pounces down: it has a green (or gray, A^axoDar,) back, white belly, long wings, and short neck. (Msb.) Of two you say
mulaAEibaA Zil~ayohimaA; and of three, mulaAEibaAtu A^aZolaAlihin~a; because the appellation becomes determinate. (TA. [But see Zil~N.])

vagorN maloEuwbN *
Teeth, or fore teeth, &c., having slaver or drivel, upon or about them. (S, K.)
talEaAbN * and tiloEaAbN, taloEaAbapN and tiloEaAbapN, tiloEiybapN, tiliE~aAbN and tiliE~aAbapN, see laEibN.

laEava , (inf. n. laEavN, TA,) He (a man, TA) was heavy and slow. (K.)
A^aloEavu * A man (TA) heavy and slow. (K)

laEaja , (inf. n. laEojN, TA) It (a beating, TA) burned the skin: it pained the body: (K:) it (a beating) pained a person, and burned the skin: (S:) it (anything burning) pained: it (love, or grief,) burned his heart. He kindled fire in the fire-wood. (K.)

laAEijN * : see 1. ― -b2- Ardour of love, or desire, or the like; syn. lawoEapN. (TA.) ― -b3- Burning or ardent, love: (L:) love that burns the heart. (S.) [See Hub~N.] ― -b4- bihi laAEiju Al$~awoqi, and lawaAEijuhu, He suffers the burning pain, and pains, of longing desire. (A.)
mutalaE~ijapN * A woman who burns with lust. (K.)

1 laEisa * , aor.
laEasa , (K,) inf. n. laEasN, (TA,) [He vas, or became, characterized, by what is termed laEasN and luEosapN; (see the former of these words below;)] he had a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip. (K.)

laEasN * The colour of the lip when it inclines a little to blackness; which is deemed beautiful: (S:) or a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip (As, A, K, TA) and in the gum; (As, TA;) as also ↓ luEosapN [which is likewise syn. with the former word in the other senses here explained]: (A:) or blackness [blending] with redness: and, accord. to El-'Ajjáj, ↓ luEosapN is in the whole of the person: Az says, that laEasN of the complexion is a blackness thereof. (TA.) See also A^aloEasu.
luEosapN * : see laEasN.

A^aloEasu *
Having a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip: fem. laEosaA='u: pl. luEosN: (K:) the pl., applied to girls and to women, signifies [as above; or] having a blackness in their lips; (TA;) or having lips of a colour inclining a little to blackness, which is deemed beautiful: (S:) the fem. is also applied to a lip, ($afap,) signifying of a colour inclining a little to blackness, which is deemed beautiful; (S;) or having a blackness, deemed beautiful; and in like manner the pl. to lips: (A:) and the masc. to the external skin, (ba$ar); so applied by El-'Ajjáj: (TA:) and the fem. to a girl, as signifying having in her complexion the least degree of blackness, and tinged with redness, (A, K, TA,) not of a clear hue: (TA:) and the pl. to girls, as signifying having a blackness in their complexions. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- You also say, (S, K,) sometimes, (S,) nabaAtN A^aloEasu, meaning Abundant and dense herbage; (S, K;) because such inclines to blackness. (S.)

laguba (S,) and
lagaba (K); and lagiba, aor
lagaba ; (S, K;) but this latter is of weak authority; (S;) and laguba, aor.
laguba ; (Lb, K;) inf. n. lagobN, (K,) which is said to be inf. n. of lagaba, aor.
laguba , (TA,) and luguwbN, (S, K,) inf. n. of lagaba, aor.
laguba , and of lagiba, (S,) and laguwbN, (K,) which deviates from constant rule, like waDuw'N and qabuwlN, (TA,) and lagabN, which is said to be inf. n. of lagiba, agreeably with analogy; (TA;) He was fatigued, tired, or wearied, (S, &c.,) in the greatest degree, or to the utmost: (M, K:) or he was languid in consequence of fatigue: or he was fatigued, tired, or wearied, in spirit, or mind: but most agree, as to the signification, with the S and K. (TA.) ― -b2- lagaAbapN (S, K: in the CK, and app. in most MS. copies of the K, expressly said to be lugaAbapN, with dammeh:) and luguwbapN (K) [app. inf. ns., of which the verb is laguba, aor.
laguba ,] The being stupid, and weak: or [if substs.] stupidity, and weakness. (S, K.) ― -b3- lagaba Ealayohimo, aor.
lagaba , (inf. n. lagobN, S,) He spoiled, or marred, their affair, scheme, plot, or the like: syn. A^afosada Ealayohimo: [A^amorahumo, or the like, being understood]. (El-Umawee and S.) ― -b4- lagaba Alqawoma He spoke ill, or corruptly, to the people: syn. Had~avahumo HadiyvFA xalofFA. (K.) -A2- lagaba He (a dog) lapped, or drank by lapping. (K.)

2 lg~b daAb~atahu *
He laded his beast with more than it was able to bear. (TA.) See 4 and 5.

4 A^alogabahu *
He fatigued, tired, or wearied him. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ tlg~bhu and ↓ lg~bhu, It (journeying, or travel,) fatigued, tired, or wearied, him in the greatest degree, or to the utmost. (K.) -A2- Algb Als~ahoma He made the feathers of the arrow to be what are termed lugaAb. (K.)

5 tlg~b * : see 4. ― -b2- He chased, hunted, or pursued, long: syn. of the inf. n. Tuwlu AlT~arodi. (S, K.) ― -b3- A poet says,
talag~abaniY dahorN falam~aA galabotuhu
gazaAniY biA^awolaAdiY faA^adorakaniY Ald~ahoru
[Fortune long pursued me; and when I overcame him, he attacked me with my children; and so fortune overtook me]. (S.) ― -b4- tlg~bhu He undertook the management of it, and did it, and was not unequal to it. (TA.) ― -b5- tlg~b Ald~aAb~apa He found the beast of carriage to be fatigued, tired, or weary; or so in the utmost degree. (TA.) See 2.

lagobN * (S, K; for which El-Kumeyt has used ↓ lagabN, like as naharN is used for nahorN, because of the guttural letter; S) and ↓ lugaAbN (S) and ↓ lagiybN (as in the S and the CK and a MS. copy of the K) or ↓ lagibN (as in the TA, from the K) Bad, disordered, or illcomposed, feathers [of an arrow]: syn. riy$N faAsidN: (S, K:) as the longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers (buTonaAn) [when they have not the shorter, or narrower, lateral halves interposed between two of them]: contr. of luw^aAmN: (S:) or the feathers termed ↓ lugaAb are the longer [or wider] lateral halves; and a single one of them is called lugaAbapN; [accord. to which explanation, lgAb is a coll. gen. n.;] contr. of lw^Am: or the feathers of an arrow, when not equal, even, or uniform, are thus termed; and when equal, even, or uniform, they are termed lw^Am: (TA:) lw^Am and lgAb are terms applied to two descriptions of feathers; the former, to those whereof a longer [or wider] lateral half is next to a shorter [or narrower] lateral half; and this is the best that can be; and lgAb and lgb are terms applied to those whereof two longer [or wider] lateral halves, or two shorter [or narrower] lateral halves, are next each other. (As.) ― -b2- lagobN and ↓ lugaAbN An arrow badly trimmed, or shaped; (K;) badly made: or one of which [all] the wings consist of the longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers: or one which has two longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers, or two shorter [or narrower] lateral halves, next each other: or one of which the feathers are incongruous; one in the contr. case being termed luw^aAmN: or one that does not go far. (TA.) ― -b3- riy$a bilagobK [It (an arrow) was feathered with bad feathers]. ― -b4- A surname of a man, brother
of Taäbbata-Sharran: (TA:) incorrectly written by J riy$u lagobK. (K.) ― -b5- lagobN (tropical:) Corrupt, or vitious, speech, or discourse; (K;) not rightly aimed, directed, or disposed; evil, bad, foul. (TA.) ― -b6- kuf~a Ean~aA lagobaka Turn away from us thine evil, corrupt, or foul, speech. (TA.) ― -b7- lagobN (like wagobN, TA) and ↓ laguwbN (tropical:) A weak, stupid, man. (S, K.) See an ex. voce kitaAbN. ― -b8- lagobN The flesh that is between the vanaAyaA, or four front teeth. (K.)
lagabN * : see lagobN. ― -b2- A^axa*a bilagabi raqabatihi He overtook him. (K.)
lagibN * : see lagobN.

laAgibN * and ↓ lagobaAnu Fatigued, tired, or wearied; or so in the utmost degree. ― -b2- saAgibN laAgibN and sagobaAnu lagobaAnu: see art. sgb. (TA, art. sgb.) riyaAHN lawaAgibu (tropical:) [Languid winds.]. (TA.)
lugaAbN * : see lagobN.
lagiybN * : see lagobN.
lugaAbapN * : see 1.
lugobaAnu * : see laAgib.
malogabapN * [A cause of fatigue, tiring, or weariness]: from [All~agobu as signifying] AlA_iEobaA'u: pl. malaAgibu. (TA.)

lagiyvN *
i. q. galiyvN, (from which it is formed by transposition, TA,) in its two meanings: (K:) wheat mixed with barley; like bagiyvN: (TA:) [and food mixed with poison, by which vultures are killed].
lug~aAvN * [pl. of laAgivN] Sellers of wheat mixed with barley; as also bug~aAvN. (L.)

1 lagada * , (aor.
lagada , T, L, K, inf. n. lagodN, T, L,) He made camels to turn back to the right way, or road: (S, L, K:) or he made camels to keep to the road, or, to the right way. (T, L.) ― -b2- lagadahu, inf. n. lagodN, He hit, or hurt, his lugoduwd. (IKtt.)

lugodN * and ↓ lugoduwdN and ↓ ligodiydN A certain portion of flesh in the Haloq [or fauces]: or what resembles redundant portions of flesh within the ear [more fully described below]: or the flesh which surrounds the furthest part of the mouth, towards the Haloq [or fauces]: (K:) pl. (of lgd, S) A^alogaAdN; and (of lgdwd, S, and lgdyd, TA) lagaAdiydu: (S, K:) or the AlgAd are portions of flesh by the lahaAp; also called lagaAniynu [and lgAdyd]: (A'Obeyd, L:) or the ↓ lgAdyd are what resemble redundant portions of flesh within the two ears, inside the mouth; also called the nagaAnig, and the lagaAniyn: (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán:) [see Alfunadobapu:] or the portions of flesh that are between the Hanak [here app. signifying the soft palate] and the side of the neck; as also the AlgAd: (S:) or outer part of the lgAnyn, which is a name given to the flesh between the nakafataAni and the tongue, internally: (AZ, L:) or the lgd is in the place of the nkftAn, at the root of the neck; also called ↓ lgdwd and ↓ lgdyd: (TA:) or the interior of the naSiyl [or part between the neck and head, beneath the jaw-bone,] between the Hanak [here app. meaning as explained above] and the side of the neck; as also ↓ lgdyd, and ↓ lgdwdAni, (JK,) for this description applies to two parts [corresponding each to the other, on the right and left]: (L:) [in the present day it is applied, with apparent correctness, to the gill, or gills, or flesh beneath the lower jaw, of a man or woman, whether in the middle or on either side, and more especially when large:] or the place where ends, at its lower part, the lobe of the ear; (AZ, L, K;) and also called the nakafap: (AZ, L:) or the AlgAd and ↓ lgAdyd are the roots of the two jaw-bones. (L.) ― -b2- EilojN Daxomu All~agaAdiydi, and AlA^alogaAdi, [A sturdy, and big, or coarse, man, large in the gills]. (A.) ― -b3- sab~aniY Hat~aY A^aHomaY lugodahu [He reviled me until he heated his gills; i. e.,] until he became hot (AiHotamaY) by reason of anger. (A.)
lugoduwdN * and ligodiydN: see lugodN throughout.

jaA='a mutalag~idFA *
He came in a state of rage. (S, K. *)

1 lagazahu * , aor.
laguza , (TK,) inf. n. lagozN, (IF, A, Msb, K,) He turned it from its proper mode or manner; distorted it. (IF, A, Msb, K, TA, TK.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lagaza jiHaratahu, and ↓ A^alogazahaA, He (a jerboa) made his burrows winding, or tortuous, and perplexing to the enterer thereof. And lagaza fiY Haforihi, and ↓ A^alogaza, He pursued a winding, or tortuous, course in his burrowing. (A.)
2 lag~aza see 4.

3 raA^ayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmizuhu * (tropical:) [I saw him talking enigmatically, or obscurely, with him, or to him, and making signs with him, or to him.] (A, TA.) [See also 3 in arts. Hjw and EY.]

4 A^alogaza see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Algz kalaAmahu, (A, K,) and Algz fiY kalaAmihi, (S, A, Msb, K,) signify alike: (K:) or the former, (tropical:) He made his speech, or language, enigmatical, or obscure; not plain: (A:) and the latter, (S, A,) or both, (K,) he made his meaning enigmatical, or obscure, in his speech, or language; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ lg~z: (A:) or the second, he used parabolical language: (Msb:) or both, he concealed a meaning different from that which he made apparent: or he was equivocal, or ambiguous, in his speech, or language, for the purpose of concealment: as in the following verse, cited by Fr:
walam~aA raA^ayotu Aln~asora Eaz~a A^abona daA^uyapa
waEa$~a$a fiY wakorayohi jaA$ato lahu nafosiY
(tropical:) [And when I saw that the vulture had overcome the raven, and nested in his nest, (lit., in his two nests,) my soul, or stomach, heaved thereat]: the poet likens hoariness to the vulture, because of its whiteness [or grayness]; and youthfulness to the black raven, because the hair of youth is black. (TA.) You say also, Algz fiY yamiynihi (tropical:) He practised [equivocation, or ambiguity, (see lug~ayozaY,) or] concealment, [by a mental reservation, or otherwise,] towards the person sworn to, in his oath: the doing of which is forbidden. (A.)
lagozN * : see lugazN, throughout.
lugazN * : see lugazN, throughout.
lagazN * : see lugazN, throughout.

lugazN * (S, A, K) and ↓ lugozN and ↓ lagozN (K) and ↓ lagazN and ↓ lugayozaA='u (TA) A winding, or tortuous, excavation or burrow: this is the primary signification: (IAar, in explanation of lugozN:) the burrow of a jerboa, which he makes between the qaASiEaA=' and naAfiqaA=', burrowing strait downwards, and then turning crosswise to the right and left, so that his place becomes concealed: (S, K, * TA:) or the burrow of the [lizard called] Dab~, and of the jerboa, (A, K,) and of the rat or mouse: (K:) pl. [of the first four] A^alogaAzN. (S, A.) ― -b2- Hence, (K,) A^alogaAzN (tropical:) Winding, or tortuous, roads, or ways, perplexing to him who pursues them. (A, * K.) You say, A_ilozami AljaAd~apa waA_iy~aAka waAlA^alogaAza (tropical:) [Keep thou to the main road, and avoid the winding, or tortuous, by-ways, which perplex him who pursues them]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (S,) lugazN (S, A, Sgh, Msb, K [omitted in the copies of the K consulted by the author of the TA, through inadvertence, as he observes, but mentioned in the CK,]) and ↓ lugozN [which is now the most common form] and ↓ luguzN and ↓ lagazN (Sgh, K) and ↓ lug~ayozaY, (S, K,) with teshdeed to the g, and not a dim., because the Y of the dim. does not occupy a fourth place, but like xuD~aAraY and $uq~aAraY, (S,) and ↓ lugayozaA='u, (Az, K,) like HumayoraA='u, (K,) [and app. ↓ lug~ayozaA='u also, with teshdeed, (see what follows,)] and ↓ A^uloguwzapN, (K,) (tropical:) An enigma; a riddle; enigmatical, or obscure, language: (S, A, K:) or parabolical language: (Msb:) pl. (of the first four, K, TA) A^alogaAzN. (S, A, Msb, K.) And in like manner, yamiynN ↓ lug~ayozaA='u, accord. to Z, with teshdeed to the g mentioned by Sb with xul~ayoTaA='u, or, accord. to Az, without teshdeed, [lugayozaA='u,] which he regards as the dim. of the form with teshdeed, like as
sukayotN is of suk~ayotN, (tropical:) An oath in which is equivocation, or ambiguity, and concealment [by mental reservation or otherwise]. (TA.)
luguzN * : see lugazN.
lag~aAzN * (tropical:) One who often, or habitually, speaks evil of others in their absence; (K, TA;) as though he did so in equivocal or ambiguous language. (TA.)
lugayozaA='u * : see lugazN, in three places.
lug~ayozaY * and lug~ayozaA='u: see lugazN; the second in two places.
A^uloguwzapN * : see lugazN.

1 lagaTa * , aor.
lagaTa , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. lagoTN (S, Msb, TA) and lagaTN, (TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and ligaATN; (S, TA;) and ↓ lg~T; (K;) and ↓ AlgT, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. AilogaATN; (S, Mgh;) He spoke clamorously, confusedly, and indistinctly: (Msb:) or, said of a number of men, (S, Mgh, K,) they uttered a sound, noise, or cry; and a clamour, confused noise, or mixture of voices or cries: (S, K:) or they uttered indistinct, and unintelligible sounds or noises or cries. (Mgh, K.) And lagaTa, aor.
lagaTa , inf. n. lagoTN and lagiyTN, is said of the pigeon, and of the [bird called] qaTaA, [meaning, It uttered its cry, or cries;] (K;) or of each of these you say, lagaTa biSawotihi, and ↓ AlgT. (TA.) [Hence,] A^atayotuhu qabola lagiyTi AlqaTaA, and lagoTihi, [I came to him before the crying of the katà,] meaning, early in the morning. (TA.) [See also laAgiTN.]
2 lag~aTa see 1.
4 A^alogaTa see 1, in two places. -A2- AlgT labanahu, (L, K,) inf. n. as above, (L,) He threw heated stones into his milk, and so caused it to make the sound termed na$iy$. (L, K.)
lagoTN * : see what next follows.

lagaTN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ lagoTN (Ks, K) Clamorous, confused, and indistinct, speech: (Msb:) or sound, noise, or cry; and clamour, confused noise, or a mixture of voices or cries: (S, K:) or indistinct and unintelligible sounds or noises or cries: (Mgh, K:) pl. A^alogaATN, (K,) of the latter as well as of the former. (TA.) You say, samiEotu lagaZa Alqawomi [I heard the clamorous, and confused, and indistinct speech, &c., of the people, or company of men]. (TA.)
laAgiTN * [part. n. of 1]. You say, A^atayotuhu qabola AlqaTaA All~aAgiTi [I came to him before the crying katà], meaning, early in the morning: pl. lug~aTN. (TA.) [See also 1.]

1 lafaA^a * , aor.
lafaAa , inf. n. lafo'N and lafaA='N; and ↓ AltfA^; He stripped off, or peeled off, (K,) meat from a bone. (AZ, S.) ― -b2- lafaA^ati Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba Eano wajohi Als~amaA='i (assumed tropical:) [The wind stripped off the clouds from the face of the sky]. (S.) ― -b3- lafaA^a, inf. n. lafo'N, He peeled a bone (TA) or a stick. (S.) ― -b4- lafaA^a He beat (S, K) with a staff or stick. (S.) ― -b5- He turned a person back, or away, from his purpose. (K.) ― -b6- lafaA^a i. q. A_igotaAba; (assumed tropical:) He traduced a person behind his back, or in his absence, but saying of him what was true. (K.) Thought to be tropical, from the same verb signifying “ he peeled. ” (TA.) -A2- lafiY'a, aor.
lafaAa , He, or it remained, or endured. (K.) -A3- lafaA^ahu Haq~ahu He gave him the whole of what was due to him: (like lakaA^ahu: T:) or lfA^h signifies he gave him less than his due. (K.) Accord. to Aboo-Turab, the verb is used in these two contr. senses. (TA.)

4 AlfA^ *
He caused to remain, or endure. (K.)
8 A_ilotafaAa see 1.

lafaA='N *
Deficiency: (IAth:) raDiytu mina AlwafaA='i biAll~afaA='i [I was content with a deficiency instead of full payment]: from a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- Less than what is just, or right. (K.) ― -b3- A little thing; a little. (K.) ― -b4- Dust; earth. (K.) ― -b5- Small bits of rubbish on the ground. (TA.)

lafiyoy^apN *
A piece of meat stripped off, or peeled off, from a bone: (TA:) a piece of meat in which is no bone: (S:) pl. lafiYo'N [but this is rather a coll. gen. n., or it is doubtful] and lafaAyaA. (TA.)

1 lafatahu * , aor.
lafita , (K,) inf. n. lafotN, (S,) He twisted, wrung, or turned, him, or it, (S, K), in a way different from his, or its, [proper] direction: as when you grasp a man's throat, and twist or wring it.
