(TA.) ― -b2- tilofitu Albaqarapu AlxalaY bilisaAnihaA [The cow turns about the fresh herb with her tongue]. (S, from a trad.) [For AlxalaA, as in copies of the S, I have substituted AlxalaY. To this action is likened a hypocrite's reading of the Kur-án.] ― -b3- lafatahu He twisted, or wrung, his neck, and broke it; as also Eafatahu and Hafatahu. (Az, in TA, art. Hft.) ― -b4- lafatahu Almawotu Death took him away suddenly; as also falatahu. (T, TA, art. flt) ― -b5- lafatahu, aor.
lafita , inf. n. lafotN, He turned him aside, to the right or left. (Msb.) ― -b6- lafatahu Eini Al$~aYo'i aor.
lafita , inf. n. lafotN, He turned away, averted, or diverted, him from the thing. (TA.) So in the Kur, x., 79. (Fr.) ― -b7- maA lafataka Eano fulaAnK What hath turned thee away, or averted thee, or diverted thee, from such a one (Fr.) ― -b8- lafatahu Eano raA^oyihi (tropical:) He turned him from his opinion. (S, K.) ― -b9- lafata wajohahu Ean~iY He turned away, or averted, his face from me. (S.) ― -b10- lafata AlmaA$iyapa, aor.
lafita , (inf. n. lafotN, TA,) He beat the camels or sheep or goats, not caring which of them he struck. (K.) ― -b11- lafata AlokalaAma, aor.
lafita , inf. n. lafotN, (tropical:) He sent forth, or uttered, words, without caring what might be the meaning. (TA.) -A2- lafata $ayoy^FA, [aor.
lafita ,] inf. n. lafotN, He stirred a thing about and over, like as flour is stirred about and over with clarified butter, &c. (TA.) [See lafiytapN.] ― -b2- lafata All~iHaA='a Eani Al$~ajari He removed, or pulled off, the peel, or rind, from the trees: (K:) or, accord. to the A, Eani AlEuwdi from the twig, or branch. (TA.) ― -b3- lafata Alr~iy$a EalaY Als~ahomi He put the feathers upon the arrow not so that they were well-composed, or equal, or even, or uniform, (gayora mutalaAy^imK [i. e., not so that they were what is termed luw^aAm,]) but as they happened to be. (K.)
5 talaf~ata see 8.

8 Altft * and ↓ tlf~t, (S, K,) [He looked aside, or about,] the latter of which signifies more than the former, (S,) are from lafatahu Eano raA^oyihi: (K:) you say, Altft A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i, and A_ilayohi ↓ tlf~t, He turned his face towards the thing. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, mA Altft A_ilayohi He regarded not him or it; he paid no regard, or attention, to him or it. (The lexicons, &c., passim.)] ― -b3- Altft biwajohihi yamiynFA wa$imaAlFA He turned his face to the right and left. (Msb.)

lifotN * The half of a thing; syn. $q~N: and its side; syn. SigowN: (S, K;) i. e., jaAnibN. (TA.) ― -b2- laA talotafito lifota fulaAnK Look not towards such a one. (S.) -A2- A cow, or bull; syn. baqarapN. (K.) -A3- A woman who is stupid, foolish, or of little sense. (K.) See also A^alofatu. -A4- The vulva of a lioness. (K.) -A5- [A name now given in Egypt to the Brassica napus of Linn., a edulis; (Delile, Flor. Aeg., No. 597;) the rape;] i. q. salojamN [a name given in Egypt to the Brassica napus of Linn., β oleifera: (Delile, ubi supra, No. 598:)] (S, K:) Az. says, “ I have not heard it from any person confided in for accuracy, and know not whether it be Arabic or not: ” (TA:) Ibn-El-Kubbee asserts it to be a Nabathean word. (MF.)
lafatN * The having one of his horns twisted upon, or over, the other. Said of a he-goat. (S.)
lufatapN * A man who beats (much TA) his camels or sheep or goats, not caring which of them he strikes. (K.)
lafaAtN * : see A^alofatu.

lafuwtN * A woman who looks aside much, or often, at things. (TA.) ― -b2- A woman who, when she hears a man speak, looks aside towards him. ('Abd-el-Melik Ibn-'Omar.) ― -b3- A woman whose eye does not remain fixed towards one place, the object of whose care is that thou shouldst be heedless of her, and that she may make signs with her eyes, or the like, to another. (Th, K.) ― -b4- A woman who has a husband, and who has a child by another husband, (S, K,) and who therefore turns her regard much towards her child, (S,) and is occupied by him so as to be diverted from her husband. (TA.) ― -b5- A she-camel that is unquiet (DajuwrN) on the occasion of her being milked, (K,) that looks aside at the milker, and bites him; wherefore he strikes her with his hand, and thereupon she yields her milk: this is the case when her young one has died: whence this epithet is proverbially applied to him who is disobedient. (TA.) ― -b6- Difficult, or stubborn, of disposition. (K.) But in the S is said what is at variance with this. (TA.) See lafaAtN, mentioned with A^alofatu, ― -b7- Accord. to some, A woman in whom is crookedness and contraction; expl. by AltY fyhA AltwA' wAnqbAD. (TA.) ― -b8- A woman went to calumniate, or slander. (A in art. xft.)

lafiytapN * [A certain kind of gruel] made by straining water [or juice, or a decoction,] of the white colocynth, then putting it into a stone cookingpot, and cooking it until it has become thoroughly done and thickened, and then sprinkling flour upon it: (AHn:) or thickened EaSiydap: (IAth, K:) or thick ESydp (S) of habiyd, i. e. HanoZal, [or colocynth]: (TA:) so called because it is stirred about and over liA^an~ahaA tulofatu A^aYo tulowaY: (S:) [see lafata $ayoy^FA:] or broth resembling Hayos: (K:) i. q. EafiytapN. (TA, art. Eft.) [See also waTiyy^ap.]

A^alofatu *
Strong-handed, who hoists, or wrings, him who strives, or grapples, with him. (TA.) ― -b2- A he-goat having crooked horns. (TA.) lafotaA'u A she-goat having crooked horns. (K.) ― -b3- A he-goat having one of his horns twisted (S, K) upon, or over the other. (S.) ― -b4- lafotaA'u A woman having distorted eyes; syn. HawolaA'u. (K.) ― -b5- A^alofatu (in the dial. of Keys, S) Stupid; foolish; of little sense; (S, K;) like A^aEofatu (S) [and A^aEofaku]: fem. lafotaA'u: [see also lifotN:] so too ↓ lafaAtN: (K:) or this signifies stupid, foolish, or of little sense, and of difficult, or stubborn disposition: (S:) [see also lafuwtN:] or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, as mentioned in a marginal note in a copy of the S, ↓ lafaAtN and its syn. hafaAtN are correctly written lafaApN and hafaApN, for in a case of pause they are pronounced lafaAho and hafaAho: see hafaAtN. (TA.) ― -b6- (In the dial. of Temeem, S,) Left-handed; who works with the left hand; (S, K;) as also A^alofaku. (TA.)

Almutalaf~itapu *
The highest bone in the place where the head joins the neck. (L.)

10 Astlfv maA Einodahu *
He elicited, and exhausted, (A_isotanobaTa waA@sotaqoSaY,) what [information, &c.] he had, or possessed. (K.) ― -b2- Astlfv Alr~iEoYa He consumed the whole of the pasture, leaving nothing of it. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Astlfv HaAjatahu He accomplished his want. (K.) ― -b4- Astlfv Alxabara He concealed the news. (K.)

A^alofavu *
Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (K:) like A^alofatu. (TA.)

4 A^alofaja * and A^ulofija
He (a man) clave to the ground by reason of sorrow, grief, or solicitude, or of want. (L.) ― -b2- Alfj, inf. n. A_ilofaAjN, He, or it, constrained, compelled, or necessitated, a person, to have recourse to one, or to others, not of his family; (K;) constrained him to beg of such. (L.) ― -b3- A^alofajaniY A_ilaY *`lika AlA_iDoTiraAru Necessity constrained me to have recourse to that. (AZ.) ― -b4- A^alofaja, [not A^ulofija, as might be thought from the signification of the part. n. mulofajN,] (inf. n. A_ilofaAjN; S;) and ↓ Astlfj; (L:) He became a bankrupt; syn. A^afolasa: (S, K:) he was, or became, poor: (TA:) he became destitute, possessing nothing. (A 'Obeyd.)
10 Astlfj * : see 4. ― -b2- Also, He was, or became, constrained to have recourse to a thing: or was in need. (TA.)

lafojN *
Abasement; abjectness. (IAar, K.)
lufojN * The channel of a torrent. (L.)

mulofajN * (S, K) and ↓ mulofijN (ISk) and ↓ musotalofajN (K) or musotalofijN (as in the L.) A man in a state of bankruptcy: a bankrupt; syn. mufolisN: (S, K:) or the former, poor: (ISk:) or a bankrupt and in debt: (IAth:) or destitute; possessing nothing: (A 'Obeyd:) the first extr. [with respect to rule], (S, K,) like muHoSanN from A^aHoSana, and musohaba from A^asohaba. (S.) [See musohabN.]
mulofijN * : see mulofajN.

musotalofajN * , (as in the K,) or ↓ musotalofijN, (as in the L [and this latter I think the correct mode of writing the word in all the senses here explained, for I do not find it noted as extr. with respect to rule like mulofajN,]) [part. n. of 10, q. v.: and] i. q. mulofajN, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- One whose heart forsakes him, or fails him, by reason of fear, or fright. (K.) ― -b3- Cleaving to the ground by reason of emaciation, (K,) or of sorrow, grief, or solicitude, or of want; as also mlfj [i. e. mulofijN and mulofajN: see 4]. (TA.)
musotalofijN * : see musotalofajN.

1 lafaHatohu Aln~aAru * , (S, M, K,) aor.
lafaHa , (M,) inf. n. lafoHN and lafaHaAnN, (M, K,) The fire smote, or hurt, his face; as also lfHt wajohahu: (M, O:) the fire burned him; (TA;) as also nfHth AlnAr biHar~ihaA; (S, K;) and in like manner the hot wind called samuwm: (S:) lafaHato and nafaHato are syn., except that the effect of Aln~afoH is greater than that of All~afoH: (Zj:) or lafoHN relates to a hot wind; and nafoHN, to a cold, or cool, wind: (As, S:) you also say lfHth Als~amuwm meaning the smwm blew in his face. (L.) ― -b2- Also lafaHahu, aor.
lafaHa , He smote, or struck, him, with a sword, (S, K,) lightly, or slightly: you say lafaHotuhu biAls~ayofi lafoHapF I struck him with the sword a light, or slight, blow. (S.)

A^aSaAbaha lfoHN mino HaruwrK wasamuwmK *
A burning gust of hot night-wind, and of hot day-wind, smote him. (L.) ― -b2- A^aSaAbahu mina AlHar~i lafoHN wamina Albarodi nafoHN [A blast of heat smote him, and a blast of cold]. (A.) ― -b3- You say also lawaAfiHu Als~amuwim [pl. of ↓ laAfiHapN, and meaning Burning blasts of the smwm]. (S, K in art. sfE.)

lafoHapN *
A light, or slight, blow with a sword. (S.)

luq~aAHN *
A certain well known plant, (K,) of the kind termed yaqoTiyniY~N, (L,) which people smell, (S.) yellow, and of sweet odour, (A, L,) resembling the baA*inojaAn (S, A, K,) when it becomes yellow; (S, A;) [accord. to Golius, app. on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, the same which the Syrians and Egyptians call $am~aAmN, q. v.]. ― -b2- Also, The fruit, or produce, (vamarap,) of the yaboruwH [or mandrake, which is called by this name (ybrwH) in the present day]; (K;) thus correctly written, with the Y before the b [not bbrwH, as in the CK and some MS. copies]. (TA.) [It seems that the application of the term lf~AH to both the mandrake and the $m~Am has led to confusion, and occasioned Linnæus to call the latter “ cucumis dudaim. ” See also yaboruwHN, and magodN.]
laAfiHapN * : see lafoHN.

1 lafaZahu * , (S, M, Msb, K,) and lafaZa bihi, (M, K,) aor.
lafiZa , (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. lafoZN; (T, S, M, Msb;) and lafiZahu, and lafiZa bihi, aor.
lafiZa ; (Ibn-
Abbád, K.) but the former is that which is commonly known; (TA;) He ejected it; cast it forth; [disgorged it;] (T, S, M, Msb, K;) namely a thing that was in his mouth; (T;) his spittle, &c.; (Msb;) from (mino) his mouth. (S, TA.) And lafaZa alone, [elliptically,] He ejected what had entered between his teeth, of food. (TA.) You say also, lafaZati AlHay~apu sam~ahaA (tropical:) [The serpent ejected its poison.] (TA.) And lafaZa EaSobahu, lit. He ejected his spittle that stuck and dried in his mouth; meaning (tropical:) he died; (T, TA;) as also lafaZa nafosahu, aor.
lafiZa , inf. n. as above; (M, TA;) and lafaZa alone. (M, K.) And jaA='a waqado lafaZa lijaAmahu, [as to the letter and the meaning like jaA='a waqado dalaqa lijaAmahu,] (tropical:) He came harassed, or distressed, by thirst and fatigue. (Ibn-'Abbád, M, Z, K.) And lafaZati Alr~aHimu maA='a AlfaHoli (tropical:) The womb ejected the seminal fluid of the stallion. (TA.) And lafaZahu AlbaHoru (assumed tropical:) The sea cast it forth upon the shore; (Msb, TA;) namely a fish; (TA;) or a beast. (Msb.) And lafaZa AlbaHoru bimaA fiyhi A_ilaY Al$~uTuwTi (assumed tropical:) The sea cast forth what was within it to the shores. (M.) And qaA='ati AlA^aroDu A^ukolahaA walafaZato xabiyoy^ahaA (tropical:) The earth disclosed her vegetables, and revealed her hidden things. (TA in this art. and in art. qyA^.) And lafaZati AlA^aroDu Almay~ita (assumed tropical:) The earth cast forth the dead; (T, Msb;) did not receive, or admit, the dead. (M.) And lafaZati AlbilaAdu A^aholahaA (tropical:) [The countries cast forth their inhabitants]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lafaZa biAlkalaAmi, (S, K,) and biqawolK, (Msb,) and biAl$~aYo'i, (M,) and lafaZa Alqawola, (TA,) aor.
lafiZa , inf. n. lafoZN, (M,) He uttered, spoke forth, or pronounced, (S, M, Msb, K,) the saying, (S, K,) and a saying, (Msb,) and the thing; (M;) as also bihi ↓ tlf~Z. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur, [l. 17,] maA yalofiZu mino qawolK (tropical:) [He doth not utter a saying]: where Kh. reads mA yalofaZu: both forms of the verb being used in this sense [as is implied in the K.]. (TA.)
5 talaf~aZa see 1, last signification.

lafoZN * , originally an inf. n., (S, Msb,) is used as a subst., (Msb,) signifying (tropical:) An expression; i. e. a word; [more precisely termed ↓ lafoZapN;] and also a collection of words, a phrase, or sentence; (I'Ak &c.;) [each considered as such, without regard to its meaning; a word itself; and a phrase itself;] the latter also called lafoZN murak~abN, a compound expression, an expression composed of two or more words: (Expos. of the Ajroomeeyeh, by the sheykh Khálid; &c.:) and ↓ malofaZN signifies the same (TA:) pl. of the former A^alofaAZN; (S, Msb;) dim. A^ulayofaAZN: (Har., p. 593) and of the latter malaAfiZ. (TA.) [Hence, lafoZFA wamaEonFY (tropical:) With respect to the word, or words, or wording, and the meaning: and with respect to the actual order of the words; and the order of the sense. And lafoZFA warutobapF (tropical:) With respect to the actual order of the words, and the order of the proper relative places. And lafoZFA wataqodiyrFA (tropical:) Literally and virtually. And laA waAHida lahu mino lafoZihi (tropical:) It has no singular formed of the same radical letter: i. e., it has no proper singular: said of a word such as qawomN and rahoTN &c.] ― -b2- See also lufaAZN.
lafoZapN * : see lafoZN.
lafoZiY~N * [Of, or relating to, a word, or collection of words, verbal:] opposed to maEonawiY~N.

lafaZaAnN *
Loquacious; a great talker: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)

lufoAZN * [app. a coll. gen. n., of which ↓ lufaAZapN, q. v., is the n. un., as seems to be indicated in the S, TA,] What is cast, or thrown, away; (M, TA;) as also ↓ lafoZN: the latter on the authority of IB. (TA.)
lifaAZN * (assumed tropical:) Leguminous plants [put forth by the earth]. (Sgh, K.)
lafiyZN * and ↓ malofuwZN Ejected; cast forth. (M, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) [Uttered, spoken forth, or pronounced.]

lufaAZapN *
What is ejected, or cast forth, from the mouth: (S, K:) such as particles of the toothstick, or stick with which the teeth are cleaned: (TA:) and what is cast, or thrown, away, of food: pl. lufaAZaAtN: (Har, p. ??.:) see also lufaAZN. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A remain, remainder, or residue, of a thing, (K, TA,) little in quality. (TA.)

laAfiZN * [act. part. n. of 1: fem. with p]. You say, fulAanN laAfiZN (tropical:) Such a one is dying. (TA.) ― -b2- All~aAfiZapN The she-goat, (T, S, M, K,) or ewe; (M, K;) because she is called to be milked, while ruminating, and thereupon ejects her cud, and comes joyfully to be milked: (T, * S, M, * K: *) or the bird that feeds her young one from her beak; because she puts forth what is in her inside and gives it for food: (S, K *:) or the domestic cock; (S, K;) because he takes the grain with his beak, and does not eat it, but throws it to the hen: (K:) or (tropical:) the mill; (T, S, M, K;) because it casts forth what it grinds, (T, TA,) of the flour: (TA:) or (tropical:) the sea; (S, M, K;) as also laAfiZapu, determinate [as a proper name]; (K;) because it casts forth (S, M) what is in it, (M,) [namely] ambergris and jewels: (S:) in this last sense, and as applied to the cock, (Sgh,) the p is to give intensiveness to the signification. (S, Sgh.) It has one or another of these significations in the saying, AsomaHu mino laAfiZapK [More liberal, or bountiful, than a she-goat, &c.,] (T, S, K,) and A^asoxaY mino laAfiZapK (M, TA) and A^ajowadu mino laAfiZapK [which mean the same]. (TA.) laAfiZapN also signifies Any bird that feeds his female, (T,) or that feeds his young bird, (M, K,) from his beak. (T, M, K.) And All~aAfiZapu (tropical:) The earth; because it casts forth the dead. (TA.) And (tropical:) The present world; because it casts forth those who are in it to the world to come. (T, K, TA.)
malofaZN * : see lafoZN.
malofuwZN * : see lafiyZN.
See Supplement

2 lq~bhu bika*aA * , inf. n. taloqiybN, He called him, or named him, by such a by-name, or surname, or nickname; he surnamed him, or nicknamed him, so. (S, K.) See laqabN. ― -b2- lq~b AlA_isoma biAlfiEoli [i. e., biAlfaA'i waAlEayoni waAll~aAmi] He called the noun by an appellation in which its radical letters were represented by f, E, and l; this appellation being its measure; as when jaworabN is called fawoEalN. (TA.) [But this signification belongs to the conventional language of lexicology and grammar.]

5 tlq~b bika*aA *
He was by-named, surnamed, or nicknamed, so. (S, K.) See laqabN.
3 laAqabahu * , inf. n. mulaAqabapN, He called him by a byname, surname, or nickname; the latter doing to him the like. (TA.)

6 talaAqabuwA *
They called one another by by-names, surnames, or nicknames. (TA.)

laqabN *
A by-name; a surname; a nickname; syn. nabazN: (S, K:) a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: in this sense forbidden: (Msb:) it is said in the Kur, xlix., 11, laA tanaAbazuwA biA@loA^aloqaAbi Call not one another by nicknames; i. e., let not one of you call another by a name which he dislikes: (Jel:) also a by-name, or surname, which is not one of reproach: such are the surnames given to certain Imáms; AlA^anoma$u and
AlA^axofa$u and AlA~aEoraju and the like; and such are not forbidden, because by them is not meant reproach, or disparagement, but they are meant as mere appellations given with the approval of the persons to whom they are applied. (Msb.) [A laqab is distinguished from a kunoyap, q. v.] Pl. A^aloqaAbN. (S, K.) ― -b2- [laqabu A@somK The appellation given to a noun by substituting f, E, and l for its radical letters. See 2.]

1 laqava * , [aor.
laquva ,] inf. n. laqovN; and ↓ lq~v, inf. n. taloqiyvN; He mixed [a thing]. (K.) [The former verb is as above accord. to the TK: but it seems to be implied in the K that it is laqiva, aor. laqiva, as well in the above sense as in that here following.] ― -b2- laqiva, aor.
laqiva , inf. n. laqovN, He took [a thing] quickly, and altogether. (K.) But this is not of established authority. (TA.)
2 laq~ava see 1.

1 laqiHato * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
laqaHa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. laqaHN (S, Msb, K,) and laqoHN (K) and laqaAHN; (S, K;) and luqiHato biAlowaladi, in the pass. form; (Msb;) She (a camel) conceived, or became pregnant; (Msb, TA;) received [into her womb] the seed of the stallion. (K.) ― -b2- laqiHato (inf. n. laqaHN, syn. HabalN, K, TA: in the CK jabalN:) (tropical:) She (a woman) conceived, or became pregnant. (Sh, T, L.) ― -b3- AimoraA^apN sariyEapu All~aqaHi A woman quick in conceiving, or becoming pregnant. The like is said with respect to any female. Perhaps the word thus used has this signification properly, or perhaps tropically. (TA.) ― -b4- A^asar~ato laqaHFA, and laqaAHFA, She (a camel) concealed her having conceived, or become pregnant: i. e., she did not show signs of her having conceived by raising her tail and elevating her nose. (L.) ― -b5- laqiHati Aln~axiylu, or luqiHat, (as in different copies of the S,) (tropical:) [The palm-trees became fecundated by the process termed A_iloqaAHN: see 4]: and of a single palm-tree (naxolapN) you say laqiHato, or luqiHato, without teshdeed; (so, again, in different copies of the S;) and ↓ talaq~aHato. (S, art. A^br) ― -b6- laqiHa AlEijaAfu, inf. n. laqaHN, (tropical:) The lands in which was no good became fecundated. (L.) [See also A^aEojafu.] ― -b7- laqiHati AlHarobu: see a verse cited voce En.
2 laq~aHa see 4.

4 AlqH AlfaHolu Aln~aAqapa * , (S, Msb,) inf. n. A_iloqaAHN; (Msb;) and ↓ lq~HhA, (A,) [inf. n. taloqiyHN;] The stallion-camel made the she-camel to conceive, or become pregnant; impregnated her; got her with young. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlqH Aln~axolapa, inf. n. A_iloqaAHN, [and quasi-inf. n. laqaAHN, q. v.; et vide infra;] and ↓ lq~HhA, inf. n. taloqiyHN; (S, Msb, A, K;) and ↓ laqaHahaA, inf. n. laqoHN; (K;) (tropical:) He fecundated the palm-tree by means of the ↓ laqaAH, or spadix of the male tree, which is bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled [upon the spadix of the female]: (A:) or, by inserting a stalk of a raceme of the male tree into the spathe [of the female, after shaking off the pollen of the former upon the spadix of the female; for such is the general practice]: this is done in the following manner: you leave the spathe of the [female] palm-tree two or three nights after its bursting open: then you take a stalk of a raceme of the male tree, which is best if old, of the preceding year, and insert it into the spadix [of the female, after shaking off the pollen, as above mentioned]; and this you do according to a certain measure: it should not be done but by a man acquainted with the manner of proceeding in this case; for if he be ignorant, and do too much, he turns the spathe, and mars it; and if he do too little, many of the dates produced will be without stones; and if he do it not at all to the palm-tree, he will derive no advantage from the spadix thereof that year: (L:) ↓ laqaHN is the name of that which is taken from the male palm-tree (AlfuH~aAl: so in the L: in the K, AlfaHol:) to be inserted in the other, [namely the spathe of the female]. (L, K.) [See also laqaAHN. In the CK, for A_isomu maA A^uxi*a Alx, we find Asm mA'K Ax* Alx, giving a different and false meaning.] jaA='anaA zamanu All~aqaAHi, or ↓ Alt~aloqiyHi, The time of the fecundating of the palm-trees has come to us. (L.) ― -b3- A^aloqaHati Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba (S) (tropical:) The wind impregnated, or fecundated, the cloud, or clouds; (L;) and in like manner, AlqHt Alr~iyaAHu Al$~ajara wanaHowahu [The winds fecundated the trees] (K) [and the like]. (TA.) ― -b4- AlqH bayonahumo $ar~FA (tropical:) He engendered, or caused, evil, or mischief, between them. (A.) ― -b5- Eaqolahu ↓ jar~aba AlA^umuwra falaq~aHato (tropical:) [He became experienced in affairs, and they fecundated his intellect]. (A.) ― -b6- Aln~aZaru fiY EawaAqibi A@loA^umwuri A@loEuquwli ↓ taloqiyHu (tropical:) [Consideration of the results, or issues, of things is (a means of) fecundation of the intellects]. (A.) ― -b7- laA tuloqiHo siloEataka biAlA^ayomaAni (tropical:) [Make not thy merchandise productive of a high price by means of oaths]. (A.)

5 tlq~Ht *
She (a camel) pretended that she had conceived, or become pregnant, (by raising her tail, in order that the stallion might not approach her, TA,) when this was not really the case. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b2- See 1.
10 AstlqHt Aln~axolapu * (tropical:) The palm-tree attained to the proper period for its being fecundated by the process termed A_iloqaAHN: [see 4: or required to be so fecundated]. (K.)
laqaHN * : inf. n. of 1. q. v. ― -b2- see A^aloqaHa Aln~axolapa, and see laqaAHN.
laqoHapN * : see liqoHapN and laquwHN.
liqoHapN * (K) and ↓ laqoHapN (TA) (assumed tropical:) A woman suckling; or a woman who suckles. (K.) ― -b2- See laquwHN.

laqaAHN * (tropical:) The thing [namely flowers or pollen] with which a female palm-tree is fecundated, (S, L, K,) taken from a male palm-tree; (L;) the spadix of a male palm-tree, (A, K,) with which a female palm-tree is fecundated, it being bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled [upon the spadix of the female]. (A.) [See also laqaHN, voce A^aloqaHa, and liqaAHN] -A2- HaY~N laqaAHN A tribe that does not submit to kings, (S, K,) and that has not been governed by a king: (L:) or, that has not suffered captivity in the time of paganism. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 1.

liqaAHN * The semen genitale (L, K) of a stallion camel, and horse, and (tropical:) of a man. (L.) I'Ab, being asked respecting a man who had two wives, one of whom suckled a boy, and the other a girl, [not his own children,] whether the boy might marry the girl, answered “ No; because the lqAH [i. e., liqaAH or ↓ laqaAH, as shown below,] is one: ” meaning, says Lth, that the semen genitale which impregnated them both, and which was the source of the milk of both, was one, and that the two sucklings had thus become as though they were the children of the two women's husband: but, says Az, lqAH may here be a quasi-inf. n., syn. with A_iloqaAHN; like EaTaA='N and A_iEoTaA='N &c.: (L:) [and the like is said in the Msb.] ↓ laqaAHN and liqaAHN, with fet-h and kesr, are substs. from A^aloqaHa, [q. v.] syn. with A_iloqaAHN, signifying impregnation, or the getting with young; and so in the answer of I'Ab above mentioned. (Msb.)

laquwHN *
A camel (S, K) itself: (S:) pl. liqaAHN. (S, K.) ― -b2- See laAqiHN. ― -b3- laquwHN and ↓ liqoHapN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ laqoHapN, (Msb, K,) applied to a she-camel, i. q. HaluwbN [meaning Milch, and a milch camel]: (S, Msb, K:) but Az says, that the former only is used as an epithet; you say nAqp laquwHN, and not nAqpN liqoHapN, but h`*ihi liqoHapN fulaAnK: (TA:) or laquwHN is [an epithet] applied to a she-camel during the first two or three months after her having brought forth; and after this she is termed labuwnN: (AA, S, K:) and accord. to some, ↓ liqoHapN signifies a milch camel abounding with
milk: or a she-camel from the time when the hump of her young one becomes fat, until the expiration of seven months, when she weans her young one, and this she does at the [auroral] rising of Canopus: (TA:) [which rising, in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight was between the 30th of July and the 12th of August:] also ↓ liqoHapN and ↓ laqoHapN a she-camel that has lately brought forth: (L:) pl. of laquwHN, liqaAHN (S, Msb, K) and laqaAy^iHu; (ISh;) and pl. of ↓ liqoHapN (and of ↓ laqoHapN, K, TA,) liqaHN (S, Msb, K) and liqaAHN. (ISh, Th, Msb.) ― -b4- The Arabs also said liqaAHaAni A^asowadaAni [Two black herds of milch camels], like as they said qaTiyEaAni; for they said liqaAHN waAHidapN in like manner as they said qaTiyEN waAHidN and A_ibilN waAHidapN. (S.) ― -b5- Almusolimiyna ↓ A^adir~uwA liqoHapa (tropical:) Milk ye the milch camel of the Muslims: occurring in a trad., alluding to the tribute (faYo' and xaraAj) whence were derived the stipends and fixed appointments of the persons addressed, and to the collecting it with equity. (TA.)

laq~aAHN *
A fecundator of palm-trees. (Az, TA in art. jnY.)

lAqiHN * (IAar, S, K) and ↓ laquwHN (K) and ↓ maloquwHapN (Msb) A she-camel having just conceived, or become pregnant; (IAar, K;) as also qaAriHN: afterwards, when her pregnancy has become manifestly apparent, she is termed xalifapN: (IAar:) pl. of the former lawaAqiHu (K) and luq~aHN; (TA;) and of the second, luquHN. (L, K, TA: in the CK luq~aHN.) ― -b2- riyaAHN lawaAqiHu (S, K, &c.,) (tropical:) Pregnant winds; so called because they bear the water and the clouds, and turn the latter over and about, and then cause them to send down rain; (TA;) or because they become pregnant, and then impregnate the clouds: (IJ:) the sing. is riyHN laAqiHN, the contr. of which is termed riyHN EaqiymN [or “ a barren wind ”]: (ISd:) or ryH lAqH signifies *aAtu laqalaAHK [possessing that which impregnates]; like as dirohamN waAzinN signifies *uw wazoni; rajulN raAmiHN, *uw rumoHK: (AHeyth:) or ryAH lwAqH signifies impregnating, or fecundating, winds; (S, K;) as also ↓ malaAqiHu [pl. of muloqiHapN]: (K:) or it is not allowable to say malaAqiHu; (S;) but this is the regular form of the word; because the wind impregnates the clouds; (IJ;) and thus lwAqH is extr.: or, as some say, the proper original word is muloqiHapN; but the winds do not impregnate unless they are themselves pregnant; as though they were pregnant with good, and, when they raised the clouds, transmitted to them that good. (S.) ― -b3- HarobN laAqiHN (K) (tropical:) War pregnant [with great events.] (TA.)

muloqiHN *
A stallion camel: pl. malaAqiHu. (S, K.) ― -b2- See laAqiHN. ― -b3- (tropical:) A man to whom offspring is born. Occurring in a trad. (TA.)

muloqaHapN *
A female camel that has her young one in her belly: pl. malaAqiHu: (S, K:) a pass. part. n. from A^aloqaHa. (Msb.)

maloquwHapN * (IAar, S, K, &c.) and maloquwHN, (IAar,) which latter is also used in a pl. sense, (As,) What is in the belly of a she-camel: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K, &c.:) or what is in the back of the stallion camel; [meaning his progeny in the elemental state;] (Aboo-Sa'eed, K;) but the former, says Az, is the correct signification: (L:) maloquwHapN is for maloquwHN bihi, converted into a subst., (Msb,) from luqiHato, like maHomuwmN from Hum~a, and majonuwnN from jun~a: (S:) pl. malaAqiyHu. (A 'Obeyd, S, K, &c.) The Muslims are forbidden to sell malaAqiyH and maDaAmiyn. (L.) [See the latter of these words.] ― -b2- AlmalaAqiyHu is also used (sometimes, TA) to signify The mothers: and its sing. is maloquwHapN. (K.) ― -b3- See laAqiHN.

1 laqisato nafosuhu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
laqasa , (S, K,) inf. n. laqasN, (S, TA,) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; or became heavy; syn. gavato, [q. v.,] (S, A, K,) and xabuvato; (S, K;) mina Al$~aYo'i in consequence of the thing. (S, K.) Mohammad desired his followers to use this expression instead of xabuvato nafosuhu, which he disliked. (K, TA.) ― -b2- With A_ilY Al$~aYo'i following it, His soul strove with him to incline him to the thing, (K,) and became greedy for it. (TA.) [But Az seems to disapprove of this explanation.]
laqisapN * , as an epithet applied to nafosN, is the part. n. of laqisato in the [first and] second of the senses explained above. (TA.)

1 laqaTahu * , (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) aor.
laquTa , inf. n. laqoTN, (Msb, TA,) He picked it up, took it up, raised it, (Mgh,) or took it, (S, K,) from the ground, (S, Mgh, K,) without trouble or fatigue; as also ↓ AltqThu: (S:) or both signify he took it from a place where it was not thought to be; this being the primary signification: and hence, he took it. (Msb.) It is said of a man: and you say also, laqaTa AlT~aAy^iru AlHab~a [The bird picked up from the ground the grains]. (Msb.) The Arabs say to a calumniator, ↓ A_in~a Einodaka diykFA yalotaqiTu AlHaSaY [Verily thou hast a cock that picks up pebbles]. (TA.) And it is said in a proverb, A^aSayoda Alqunofu*i A^amo laqoTahu [Is it by the hunting of the hedgehog or the picking up thereof from the ground?] applied to a poor man who becomes rich suddenly. (TA.) [In Freytag's Arab. Prov. (i. 726,) A^aSayodu Alqunofu*i A^amo luqaTapN: and there asserted to be said of him who finds a thing which he had not sought: or, accord. to Sharafed-Deen, of a thing of the nature of which we may be uncertain.] You say also, laqaTotu AlEilomi mina Alkutubi (assumed tropical:) [I picked up science, or knowledge, from books;] I acquired science, or knowledge, from this and that book. (Msb.) And laqaTotu A^aSaAbiEahu (assumed tropical:) I took off his fingers, by cutting, without [the main part of] the hand. (Msb.)

3 mulaAqaTapN * A horse's lifting the legs all together in the pace called taqoriyb: (AO, K: *) or, in the pace called xabab, of a horse, it is similar to munaAqalapN. (JK.) -A2- Also, (K,) and ↓ liqaATN, (TA,) The being over against, or facing. (K, TA.) You say, daAruhu biliqaATi daAriY His house is over against, or faces, my house. (Lh, K.) And laqiytuhu liqaATAF I met him face to face. (IAar.)

5 tlq~T fulaAnN Alt~amora * , or Alv~amara, (S, accord. to different copies, and K, *) Such a one, [picked up, or] took up from the ground, from this and that place, the dates, or the fruits. (S, K. *)

8 AltqThu * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also, He collected it. (Msb.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) He stumbled upon it, or lighted on it, (K, TA,) unexpectedly, (TA,) without seeking; (K, TA;) such a thing, for instance, as a well, and herbage. (TA.) You say also, waradotu Al$~aYo'a A@lotiqaATFA (tropical:) I came upon the thing unexpectedly, or unawares; (S, TA:) and laqiytuhu A@lotiqaATFA (tropical:) I met him unexpectedly: (TA:) AltqATA in this sense being one of those inf. ns. which are used as denotatives of state. (Sb, TA.)

laqaTN *
What is picked up, or taken from the ground, (S, Msb, K,) of a thing; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ luqoTapN and ↓ luqaTapN and ↓ luqaATapN: (K:) or ↓ this last signifies what one picks up, of lost property; as also ↓ luqaATN, with the p elided; and ↓ luqaTapN like ruTabapN: (Msb:) or ↓ luqaATapN signifies also what falls, or drops, of a thing that is worthless, (K, TA,) or paltry, and is taken by any one who chooses to take it: (TA:) and the same, what is picked up from the stumps of the branches of palm-trees, [app. meaning dates picked up thence,] after the cutting off of the dates: (TA:) IAth says, that ↓ luqaTapN, with damm to the l and fet-h to the q, is often mentioned in trads., and signifies property which is found: (TA:) Az says, that luqaTapN, with fet-h to the q, signifies a thing which one finds dropped, or thrown down, and takes; (Mgh, Msb;) and that all the lexicologists and skilful grammarians say so; (Msb;) and in like
manner, A 'Obeyd, on the authority of As and of El-Ahmar; (TA;) only Lth, of all whom he has heard, saying that it is ↓ luqoTapN, with sukoon; (Mgh, Msb;) and Fr: (TA:) IF and ElFárábee and others mention only ↓ luqaTapN; and some reckon the pronunciation with sukoon as an error of the vulgar; and the reason is this; that the original word is ↓ luqaATapN, which, in consequence of its being in frequent use, as applied to what is picked up in plundering, is contracted, sometimes, by the elision of the p, into ↓ luqaATN, and sometimes, by the elision of the A into ↓ luqaTapN; and if they made the q quiescent, there would be two alterations in the word, and such double alteration does not exist in chaste language: (Msb:) IB, however, says that ↓ luqoTapN is correct; and he approves it; because fuEolapN has the sense of a pass. part. n., as in the instance of DuHokapN; and fuEalapN has the sense of an act. part. n., as in the instance of DuHakapN; and that it occurs in poetry: and IAth observes, that some say thus; but that ↓ luqaTapN is more common and more correct. (TA.) Anything that is scattered, of ears of corn, or of fruit; n. un. with p: (TA:) what is picked up, or taken from the ground, (S, Msb, K,) by men, (S,) of ears of corn; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ luqaATN, with damm: (S:) and ↓ laqaATN, like saHaAbN, the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks miss, (AHn, K,) and which men pick up. (AHn.) What is picked up from a mine: (Msb:) pieces of gold found in a mine; (K;) or such are termed laqaTu maEodinK: (S:) or laqaTN signifies pieces of gold, or of silver, like what are termed $a*or, and larger, in mines; which are the best thereof: and one says *ahabN laqaTN: (Lth:) and ↓ mulotaqaTN, also, signifies gold found in a mine. (TA.) You say also, fiY h`*aA AlmakaAni laqaTN mina AlmarotaEi In this place is some small quantity of pasturage. (S.) And fiY AlA^aroDi laqaTN lilomaAli In the land is pasturage not much in quantity for the beasts. (TA.) The pl. is A^aloqaATN. (TA.)

luqoTapN * : see laqaTN, throughout the first sentence. ― -b2- Accord. to Lth, it [also] signifies A man who repeatedly and perseveringly seeks after things to be picked up, and picks them up: (TA:) and some say, that ↓ luqaTapN signifies one who picks up: but the more common and correct signification of this latter is “ property which is found, ” as before stated. (IAth.)
luqaTapN * : see laqaTN, throughout the first sentence: — and see luqoTapN.
laqaATN * : see laqaTN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
luqaATN * : see laqaTN, in three places.

liqaATN * : see 3. ― -b2- [The act of picking up the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks miss;] the act denoted in the explanation of laqaATN. (JK, K, TA.) You say, huwa yataEay~a$u biAlil~qaATi Eani All~aqaATi [He constrains himself to obtain the means of life, or he obtains what is barely sufficient for his sustenance, by picking up, or gleaning, from the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks have missed]. (TK: but there given without any syll. signs.) [If the reading intended be biAll~aqaATi Eani All~iqaATi, the meaning of liqaATN is The act of missing ears of corn with the reapinghook; as is implied in the K, where laqaATN is imperfectly explained: but this I think improbable.] laqaATN and liqaATN are [respectively] like HaSaAdN [as signifying what is “ reaped ”] and HiSaAdN [as signifying the act of “ reaping ”]. (TA.)

laqiyTN *
i. q. ↓ maloquwTN; (Msb, K;) i. e. A thing that is picked up, taken up, raised, (Mgh,) or taken, (Msb, K,) from the ground, (Mgh, K,) or from a place where it was not thought to be. (Msb.) ― -b2- And, generally, (Mgh,) A foundling; or child that is cast out, (Az, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and found by a man, (Az, TA,) or picked up; (S;) or because it is cast out with the object of its being picked up: (Mgh:) not what Lth asserts it to be; i. e. a child that is cast out in the roads, and there found, whose father and mother are unknown: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Az, TA:) and ↓ maloquwTN signifies the same: (K:) [pl. of the former, luqaTaA='u.] ― -b3- Also, A well upon which one lights unexpectedly, or unawares, (Lth, K,) without seeking it. (Lth.)
luqaATapN * : see laqaTN, first sentence, in four places.

laqiyTapN * applied to a man, and to a woman, (tropical:) Low, ignoble, base, vile, or mean; (K, TA;) as also ↓ laAqiTapN applied to a man; (TA;) and so ↓ saAqiTN maAqiTN laAqiTN, used together. (L in art. sqT.) It occurs in this sense preceded by saqiyTapN; but you say saqiyTN when alone. (TA.)
laq~aATN * : see laAqiTN.
laq~aATapN * : see laAqiTN.

laAqiTN * and in an intensive sense ↓ laq~aATN and [in a doubly intensive sense] ↓ laq~aATapN A man [who picks up things from the ground; and the second, who does so much, or often; and the third, who does so very much, or very often: or] who takes things from places where they were not thought to be: (Msb:) and all signify a man who picks up the ears of corn [that fall] when the crop is reaped, and [the fruit that falls] when the ripe dates are cut from the raceme: (TA:) and the first and second, a bird that picks up grains. (Msb.) ― -b2- ↓ likul~i saAqiTapK laAqiTapN For every saying that falls from one, there is a person who will take it up: (Msb in art. sqT:) or for every word that falls from the mouth of the speaker, there is a person who will hear it and pick it up and publish it: (S, * K:) a proverb, (TA,) relating to the guarding of the tongue: (K:) the p in lAqTp is to give intensiveness to the meaning, (Msb, in art. sqT,) or for the purpose of assimilation: (Msb in that art., and in the present one:) if you say likul~i DaAy^iEK, or the like, you say laAqiTN. (Msb in the present art.) ― -b3- AlHaSaY ↓ laAqiTapN The qaAniSap [meaning stomach, &c.,] of a bird, (S, K,) in which pebbles become collected: (S:) or the omasum (qib~p) of a sheep or goat [and the corresponding ventricle of a camel, as is shown in the TA in art. HSl; also called laq~aATapu AlHaSaY (see qurayoHaA='u);] because it conveys thereinto whatever it eats of earth and pebbles; (A, TA;) as also All~aAqiTapN [alone]. (TA.) -A2- laAqiTN also signifies (tropical:) Any freedman, or emancipated slave: (K:) or the slave of a freedman. (S in art. mqT, and TA in art. sqT:) the slave of the lAqT is called maAqiTN; and the slave of the mAqT is called saAqiTN: and hence the saying, huwa saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK. (K, TA [but in the CK, for huwa we find banuw, with the necessary difference in what follows it.]) See art. sqT. ― -b2- See also laqiyTapN: and see A^aloqaATN, which may be a pl. of laAqiTN; as in luq~aATN, which is explained with A^aloqaATN.
laAqiTapN * : see laAqiTN, in two places: -A2- and see also laqiyTapN.

A^aloqaATN * pl. of laqaTN, q. v. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A small number of men, separated, or scattered, or dispersed. (S.) ― -b3- [Also, perhaps as pl. of laAqiTN, like as A^aSoHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN,] (tropical:) The refuse, or lowest, or basest, or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ luq~aATN [which is doubtless a pl. of laAqiTN, like as suq~aATK is of saAqiTN, and muq~aATN of maAqiTN]. (IAar, in TA, art. x$r.)

maloqaTN * [A place where a thing is picked up:] a place where a thing is sought, or to be sought: a mine: (TA:) [pl. malAqiTu.] ― -b2- A^aSobaHato maraAEiynaA malaAqiTa mina Aljadobi Our places of pasturage became dried up, and destitute of herbage, by reason of the drought. (As.)

miloqaTN *
A thing with which, (K,) or in which, (Jm,) one picks up, or takes up, from the ground: (Jm, K;) as also ↓ miloqaATN. (TA.)
miloqaATN * : see miloqaTN. ― -b2- The [instrument called] minoqaA$, (K, TA,) with which hair is plucked up. (TA.)
maloquwTN * : see laqiyTN, in two places. IAth explains maAlN maloquwTN as signifying property found. (TA.)
mulotaqaTN * : see laqaTN, last sentence but two. ― -b2- Also, applied to a thing, i. q. saAqiTN (assumed tropical:) [Vile, mean, or paltry]. (TA.)

div2.n: lqE lqf lqm lqn lqY lk

head.foreign: lqE lqf lqm lqn lqY lk

div2.entryFree: See Supplement

1 lakaA^a * , aor.
lakaAa , (K,) inf. n. lako'N, (TA,) He beat a person (K) with a whip. (TA.) ― -b2- lakaA^a bihi AlA^aroDa He cast him upon the ground. (AZ, S.) [See zakaA^a, and lataA^a.] ― -b3- lakaA^ahu He prostrated him. (K.) -A2- lakaA^ahu He gave him the whole of what was due to him: (K:) like lafaA^ahu. (T.) -A3- lakiy^a, aor.
lakaAa , He stayed, dwelt, or abode, (K,) in a place: like lakiYa. (TA.) lky^ bimawoDiEK He kept, or remained fixed, in a place. (K, * TA.)

5 tlk~A^ Ealayohi *
He excused himself to him; he pleaded an excuse to him. (K.) ― -b2- tlk~A^ Eanohu He was slow to do it; delayed to do it; (S, K, TA;) excused himself, or pleaded an excuse, for not doing it; refused to do it, or abstained from doing it. (TA.)
malokabapN * A she-camel compact in flesh: (K:) or abounding with fat, and compact in flesh. (AA, T.) ― -b2- The conduct of a pimp: syn. qiyaAdapN (L.)

1 lakava * , [aor.
lakuva ,] inf. n. lakovN (and likaAvN, IAar), He struck, or smote; (K;) accord. to IAar, who does not particularize the hand, nor the foot: (TA:) or, with his hand, or his foot, accord. to some: (TA:) or, with [perhaps a mistake for upon] the mouth. (Kr.) [See also lkd.] ― -b2- lakatahu, [aor.
lakuva ,] He overburdened him. (K.) ― -b3- lakiva, aor.
lakava , [inf. n. lakavN,] He (a camel) was affected with the disorder called lakavN, or lukaAvN. (K.) ― -b4- lakiva bihi, aor.
lakava , It (dirt [see lakovN]) adhered to it; (K;) i. e., to the vessel. (TA.) [See also lakida and lakiEa.]
lakovN * The dirt of milk, which congeals upon the edge of the vessel, and is removed with the hand. (TA.)

lakavN * and ↓ lukaAvN (as also nukaAvN, TA,) A disorder in the mouths of camels, resembling pustules. (Lh, K.) ― -b2- ↓ lukaAvapN, A disorder that attacks sheep or goats in the sides of the mouth and in the lips, resembling an ulcer; happening on their first cropping plants when they are short, with small branches. (L.)

naAqapN lakivapN *
A fat she-camel. (K.)

lukaAvN *
A shining stone in gypsum. (Fr, K.) -A2- See lakavN.
lukaAvapN * : see lakavN.
luk~aAvN * [pl. of laAkivN?] Preparers of gypsum: (K:) not those who traffick therein. (TA.)
lukaAviY~N * A man (TA) very white: (K:) from lukaAvN as signifying a shining stone in gypsum. (TA.)

1 lakida Ealayohi * , (As, S, L, K,) and bihi, (L,) aor.
lakada , (K,) inf. n. lakadN; (As, S, L;) and bh ↓ tlk~d; (A;) It (dirt) clave, or stuck, to him, or it. (As, S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- lakida bifiyhi It (a glutinous thing that had been eaten of) left part of its substance, or its colour, sticking to his (the eater's) mouth. (L.) ― -b3- lakida It (his hair) became compacted together, or matted, (L,) by reason of dirt. (A.) ― -b4- lakida bihi, and ↓ Altkd, He kept to, or clave to, and did not quit, him, or it. (L.) See also 3.

3 lAkdhu *
He kept, clave, or clung, to him. (L.)

5 talak~ada
tlk~d It (a thing) clave together, one part to another. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- He became thick (and compact, TA,) in his flesh. (K.) ― -b3- See 1. ― -b4- tlk~dhu He embraced him; put his arms round his neck. (As, L, K.)
8 A_ilotakada see 1.

milokadN *
A thing resembling a muduq~ [or pestle], with which one bruises, brays, or pounds. (S, L, K.)

1 lakazahu * , aor.
lakuza , (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. lakozN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He struck him upon the breast (AO, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) with the fist: (AO, S, Mgh, Msb:) and upon the Hanak [or part beneath the chin]: (A, K:) and upon the neck: (K:) or upon any part of the body with the fist: (AZ, S, Msb:) or with the extremities of the fingers: (TA, art. lqz:) he pushed, or impelled, or repelled, him: (TA, ibid.:) he thrust or pierced him [with a spear or the like]: (TA, art. lz:) lakozN is also syn. with wakozN [which has several significations, some of which are indentical with some explained above]. (K.) You say also, lakazahu bijumoEi kaf~ihi He struck him upon the breast, or the part called Hanak, with his fist. (A.)
3 lAkzhu * , inf. n. mulaAkazapN, [He contended with him in striking upon the breast, or the part beneath the chin, &c., with the fists.] (A, TA.)
6 tlAkzA * [They two contended in striking each other upon the breast, or the part beneath the chin, &c., with their fists]. (A, TA.)

lakozapN *
A blow upon the breast, (A, Mgh,) and upon the part beneath the chin, [&c.,] (A,) with the fist. (Mgh.)
mulak~azN * (tropical:) A low, an abject, or a despicable, man, who is repelled (A, TA) from the doors. (TA.)
See Supplement
lawolabN * : see art. lb.

mulawolabN *
i. q. mirowadN (S, K) and the like. (S.) Of the measure mufawoEalN: (S, K:) or, accord. to some, faEawoEalN. (TA.)
see Supplement.

1 lamaA^ahu * , and lamaA^a Ealayohi, aor.
lamaAa , He smote his hand upon it, [or laid his hand upon it, or seized it,] openly or secretly. (K.) ― -b2- lamaA^a Al$~aYo'a He took the whole thing; took it entirely. (K.) ― -b3- lamaA^a Al$~aYo'a, (K,) inf. n. lamo'N, (TA,) He glanced, or took a slight look at the thing; beheld it quickly: like lamaHahu. (K.)

4 AlmA^ Ealayohi *
He (a thief, TA) took it away privily. (K.) [See also A^alomaY.] ― -b2- AlmA^ EalaY~a Haq~iY He denied me my right, or due. (K.) ― -b3- AlmA^t Ald~awaAb~u AlmakaAna (S) [in the K, biAlamkaAni; but this appears, from what is said in the S and the TA, to be wrong;] The beasts of carriage left the place bare of pasture. (S, K.) ― -b4- AlmA^ Elyh, (K,) or bihi, (S, L,) He took, or got, possession of it; took it, got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession: syn. A_i$otamala Ealayohi: (S, K:) or the latter signifies he took it away; went away with it. (K.) AlmA^ EalaY Al$~aYo'i He got possession of the thing. (L.) *ahaba vawobiY famaA A^adoriY mano AlmA^ bh [My garment is gone, and I know not who has taken, or got, possession of it; or who has taken it away]. (S.) The phrase without negation is also used. (ISk, S.) [See also 8.]
5 tlm~A^t AlA^aroDu bihi * , (K,) and Ealayohi, (S, K,) The earth enclosed him; was made even over him: and concealed him. (S, K.) See 8.

8 AltmA^ bimaA fiY Aljafonapi * , and ↓ AlmA^, and ↓ tlm~A^, He took to himself the contents of the bowl. (K, TA.) [See also AltmE and AlmE and tlm~E.] -A2- A^ulotumiY'a lawonuhu His colour altered, or became altered. (S,
K.) A_ilotamaA^a is also mentioned as having the same signification. (TA.) [See also AltmE and AltmY.]

malomuw^apN *
A place in which a thing is taken (yuw^oxa*u, as in some copies of the K) or found (yuwjadu, as in other copies of the K). ― -b2- A sportsman's, or hunter's, or fowler's, or fisherman's net. (K, TA.)

1 lamaja * , (aor.
lamuja , S, M,) inf. n. lamojN, (S, K,) He ate: or he ate with the extremity of the mouth: (M:) or he ate with the extremities of his mouth: (S, K:) or he took fodder, or dry herbage, with the extremity of his mouth: (T:) AZ says, I know not All~amoj except as the act of asses, and it is like All~amos, [probably a mistake for All~ahos, or its syn. All~aHos,] or signifies more than this latter word. (AHn.) ― -b2- lamaja, inf. n. lamojN, Inivit feminam. (K.)

2 lam~ajahu * , inf. n. talomiyjN, He fed him with something whereby to content, or divert, him [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaA': see lumojapN. (TA.) And see lamaZ~ahu: and Eaj~alotumo: and Eas~ala. ― -b2- maA lam~ajuwA Dayofahumo bi$aYo'K They did not feed their guest with anything whereby to allay the craving of his stomach before the morning-meal. (S.)

5 tlm~j *
He ate something whereby to content, or satisfy, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaA'. (K.) [See lumojapN: and see also lamaAjN.] ― -b2- Accord. to AA, it is like talam~aZa; [He searched repeatedly, with his tongue, after the remains of food in his mouth, and put forth his tongue and licked his lips with it;] and one says, raA^ayotuhu yatalam~aju biAlT~aEaAmi, i. e. ytlm~Z [I saw him searching repeatedly, with his tongue, after the remains of the food in his mouth, &c.]; and As says the like. (S.)

samojN lamojN * , (K,) or $aYo'N samojN lamojN (S,) and ↓ samijN lamijN, and ↓ samiyjN lamiyjN: (S, K:) in each of these expressions, the latter word is an imitative sequent: (AO, S, K:) [app. Very ugly: in the TA it is said, that these epithets are applied to a man, and signify *aw~aAqN, app. meaning one who tastes much: and in the L it is said, that ↓ rajulN lamijN, after the manner of a relative noun, signifies *aw~aAqN]. See lamoHN.
lamijN * : see lamojN.

lumojapN * : see lamaAjN. ― -b2- Also [An early portion of food, being] That with which one contents, or diverts, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaA'. (K.) See sulofapN.

lamaAjN * The least (A^adonaY) [kind, or quantity,] of food, or of what is eaten: (S, K:) and sometimes, of beverage. (TA.) ― -b2- maA talam~ajotu Einodahu bilamaAjK, (S, L,) and ↓ lamuwjK, and ↓ lumojapK, (L,) I ate not anything at his abode: (L:) and maA *uqotu $amaAjAF walaA lamaAjFA, (S, L,) I tasted not anything. (S, L.)
lamuwjN * : see lamaAjN.
lamiyjN * One who eats much; a great eater. (K.) ― -b2- Is qui multum coït: as also ↓ laAmijN. (K.) ― -b3- See also lamojN.
laAmijN * : see lamiyjN.
malaAmiju * : i. q. malaAgima: (i. e., S;) The parts around the mouth. (S, K.)

rumoHN mulam~ajN *
A smoothed spear. (K.)

1 lamaHahu * , (S,) or lamaHa A_ilayohi, aor.
lamaHa , (L, Msb, K), inf. n. lamoHN; (Msb;) and ↓ AlmH, (L, K,) or ↓ AlmHhu, (S, Msb,) and ↓ AltmHhu; (S;) He glanced, or took a light, or slight, look, at him or it; (S;) like lamaA^ahu; (Nh;) snatched a sight of him or it unawares: (L, Msb, K;) or, accord. to some, lamaHa signifies he looked; and ↓ AlmHhu, he made him to look; but the former explanation is the more correct: or lamaHa is only said of one looking from a distance. (L.) ― -b2- lamaHotuhu biAlbaSari I directed (Saw~abotu) my sight towards him. (Msb.) ― -b3- lamaHa AlbaSaru The sight extended to a thing. (Msb.) ― -b4- lamaHa, aor.
lamaHa , inf. n. lamoHN (S, K) and lamaHaAnN and talomaAHN, (K,) It (lightning, and a star,) shone; gleamed; glistened; i. q. lamaEa. (S, K.)
3 laAmaHahu * , inf. n. mulaAmaHapN, [He glanced at him, or viewed him lightly, or slightly, or snatched sights of him unawares, reciprocally]. (A.)

4 AlmHhu *
He made him to glance, or to take a light, or slight, look; expl. by jaEalahu yalomaHa, (K,) and jaEalahu mim~ano yalomaHu. (TA.) ― -b2- See 1. ― -b3- A^alomaHati AlmaroA^apu mino wajohihaA, (inf. n. A_ilomaAHN, TA,) The woman allowed herself [or her face] to be glanced at, or to be viewed lightly, or slightly: so does a beautiful woman, displaying, and then concealing, her beauties. (T, K.)

8 A^alotumiHa baSaruhu *
His sight was taken away. (K.) ― -b2- See 1.

fulaAnN samoHN lamoHN * , and ↓ samiyHN lamiyHN: see art. smH. [lamoHN and lamiyHN in these cases seem to be merely imitative sequents.] ― -b2- laA^uriyan~aka lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) I will assuredly show thee a manifest, or an evident, thing, matter, or affair. (S, A, K.) [See also art. bSr.]

lamoHapN * , subst. from lamaHa, (S, L,) A glance, or light or slight look. (L.) ― -b2- lamoHapN A shining, gleaming, or glistening, of lightning. (S.) ― -b3- fiY fulaAnK lamoHapN mino A^abiyhi In such a one is a likeness, or point of resemblance, to his father: then they said mino Abyh ↓ malAmiHu, (S,) signifying likenessess, or points of resemblance; forming an extr. pl., (S, K,) as though from another word than lamoHapN: (S:) they did not say malomaHapN. (TA.) ― -b4- ↓ malaAmiHu also signifies What appear of the beauties and defects of the face (K) of a human being: or the parts thereof that are glanced at, or viewed lightly or quickly. (TA.)
lamuwHN * : see laAmiHN.
lamiyHN * : see lamoHN.
lam~aAHN * : see laAmiHN.

lum~aAHN *
Sharp hawks; syn. SuquwrN *akiy~apN. (IAar, T, K, [in the CK, zakiy~ap].)

laAmiHN * and ↓ lamuwHN and ↓ lam~aAHN Lightning, and a star, shining; gleaming; glistening: (K:) [but the second and third are intensive epithets, signifying shining much; &c.] ― -b2- ↓ A^aboyaDu lam~aAHN (tropical:) Intensely white. (A.) ― -b3- laAmiHu EiTofayohi A self-admiring man, who looks at his sides. (M, F.)
A^alomaHiY~N * A man (TA) who glances much, or frequently takes light, or slight looks. (K.)
malaAmiHu * : see lamoHapN.

1 lamazahu * , aor.
lamiza and
lamuza , inf. n. lamozN, He made a sign to him with the eye, or the like, (S, A, * Msb, K,) as the head, and the lip, with low speech. (TA.) This is the original signification. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, Msb, TA,) He blamed, upbraided, or reproached, him; he found fault with him: (S, Msb, K:) or he did so in his face: (TA:) or he met him with blaming, upbraiding, reproaching or finding fault: (IKtt, TA:) or he spoke evil of him, or spoke of him in a manner that he disliked, mentioning vices or faults as chargeable to him, either behind his back or before his face, though it might be with truth; syn. A_igotaAbahu. (TA.) The two forms of the aor. occur in readings of the words of the Kur., [ix. 58,] waminohumo mano yalomizuka fiY AlS~adaqaAti and yalomuzuka, (S, TA,) And of them are those who blame thee with respect to the division of the alms: (Bd, Jel:) and Ibn-Ketheer reads ↓ yulaAmizuka. (Bd.) -A2- lamazahu, (Ks, S,) aor
lamiza , (S,)
inf. n. lamozN, (S, A, K,) He pushed him, or impelled him, or repelled him: (Ks, T, S, A, K:) said by AM to be the primary signification: (TA:) and he struck him, or beat him. (S, A, K.)

3 raA^ayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmiruhu * [means I saw him talking enigmatically with him, or to him, and making signs with him, or to him: or, accord. to the TA, mulaAmazapN is syn. with mulaAgazapN]. (A, in art. lgz.)

lumazapN * One who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually; (S, K;) as also ↓ lam~aAzN, (so in two copies of the S, and in a copy of the A,) or ↓ lamaAzN, like saHaAbN: (K:) lumazapN is applied to a man and to a woman; for its p is to denote intensiveness, and not the fem. gender: (TA:) humazapN and lumazapN signify the same; (ISk, Zj, K;) i. e., one who speaks evil of others, or does so in their absence, though it may be with truth; (yagotaAbuhumo; and this may mean [who detracts by making signs] with the side of the mouth, or with the eye, or with the head; TA;) and defames them; (ISk, Zj, TA;) or one who often goes about with calumny, a separater of companions and friends: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) and ↓ lam~aAzN, like $ad~aAdN, a frequent, or habitual, calumniator, or slanderer: (TA:) or humazapN and lumazapN differ in signification; the latter signifying one who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, thee to thy face; and the former, one who does so in thine absence; (K;) and Lth says the like: (TA:) or the latter, one who speaks evil of others, though it may be with truth, (mugotaAbN,) behind the back; and the former, one who does so to the face: or the latter, one who speaks against the lineages of men; and the former, one who speaks against the characters of men: or the latter, [one who reproaches] with the tongue; and the former, with the eye: or the reverse: (K [but omitted in the CK], TA:) or the latter signifies one who excites discord, or animosity, between two persons. (TA.) See also humazapN. And see the Ksh and Bd in civ. 1.
lamaAzN * : see lumazapN.
lam~aAzN * [One who makes frequent signs with the eye, or the like: fem. with p: see one ex. voce ram~aAzN]. ― -b2- See also lumazapN, in two places.
laAmizN * act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- lum~aAzN [its pl.] Persons who speak evil of others, though it may be with truth, (mugotaAbuwna,) in their presence. (IAar, TA.)

1 lamasahu * , (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
lamusa (S, M, Msb, K) and
lamisa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. lamosN, (S, M, Msb,) He felt it; or touched it; syn. mas~ahu: (IAar, Az, IDrd, El-Fárábee, A, Msb, TA:) or he felt it, or touched it, (mas~ahu,) with his hand: (S, Msb, K:) or he put his hand to it: (Msb:) or he felt it with his hand for the purpose of testing it, that he might form a judgment of it; syn. jas~ahu: (M, TA:) and ↓ laAmasahu is syn. with lamasahu, (M, TA,) or maAs~ahu: (A:) lamosN and mas~N both signify the perceiving by means of the exterior of the external skin: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or they are nearly alike: (TA:) [generally, like the English words feeling and touching, respectively:] or the former is, originally, [the feeling] with the hand for the purpose of knowing the feel (mas~) of a thing: (IDrd, Msb:) or, with the hand, it is the seeking for [or feeling for] a thing here and there: (Lth, TA:) mulaAmasapN is the same as mumaAs~apN (K, TA) with the hand; as also lamosN: (TA:) or a distinction is to be made between them; for it is said that lamosN is sometimes the feeling, or touching a thing with a thing; and is sometimes [for] the knowledge of a thing, though there be no touching (mas~) of substance upon substance; whereas mlAmsp is mostly mutual feeling or touching, &c., being] the act of two. (IAar in TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lamasahaA, (M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
lamusa (M) [and
lamisa , as implied in the K], inf. n. lamosN, (S, M,) (tropical:) Inivit eam; (I'Ab, S, M, A, Msb, K;) scil. mulierem; (A, Msb;) puellam; (K;) as also ↓ laAmasahaA, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. mulaAmasapN (I'Ab, S, Msb, K) and limaAsN: (I'Ab, Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) he kissed her; by doing which, as well as by the former, one renders necessary the performance of the ablution termed wDw'. ('Abd-Allah Ibn- 'Amr, Ibn-Mes'ood.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] lamasahu, aor.
lamusa [and
lamisa ], (A, TA,) inf. n. lamosN, (IDrd, Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He sought, [as though by feeling,] or sought for or after, it, namely, a thing, (IDrd, Msb, TA,) in any manner; (IDrd, Msb;) [as, for instance, by asking, or demanding;] as also ↓ Altmshu, (S, M, A, * K, TA,) [which is more common,] and ↓ tlm~shu: (M, TA:) or this last signifies he sought it, or sought for or after it, repeatedly, or time after time. (S, K, TA.) You say, A^ulomuso liY fulaAnFA (A, TA) (tropical:) Seek thou for me such a one. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [lxxii. 8,] relating the words of the jinn, or genii, A_in~aA lamasonaA Als~amaA='a, (K, * TA, *) (tropical:) Verily we sought to reach heaven: or to learn the news thereof: (Bd:) or to hear by stealth what was said therein: (Jel:) or we laboured, or strove, after (EaAlajonaA) the secrets of heaven, and sought to hear them by stealth. (K.) And in a trad., bihi EilomFA ↓ mano salaka TariyqFA yalotamisu (tropical:) Whoso pursueth a way whereby he seeketh after knowledge, or science. (TA.) And in another, of 'Áïsheh, EiqodiY ↓ faA@lotamasotu (tropical:) And I sought for my necklace. (TA.) ― -b4- lamasa AlbaSara, aor.
lamusa , (tropical:) It took away the sight. (A, TA.) And the same, or, accord. to one relation of a trad., ↓ Altmshu, (assumed tropical:) It took away quickly, and destroyed, the sight; said there of certain serpents: or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) it aimed at the eye with its bite: and lamasa Eayonahu is said to signify [(assumed tropical:) he, or it, put out his eye,] the same as samala. (TA.)

3 lAmshu * , inf. n. mulaAmasapN and limaAsN: for its proper signification, see 1, in three places. [Hence,] bayoEu AlmulaAmasapi, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) and bayoEu All~imaAsi, (Mgh,) or AlmulaAmasapu fiY AlbayoEi, (K,) A mode of bargaining, which consists in saying, When thou feelest, or touchest, my garment, or I feel, or touch, thy garment, (A, K,) or when, (Mgh,) or if, (Msb,) I feel, or touch, thy garment, and thou feelest, or touchest, my garment, (Mgh, Msb,) or when I feel, or touch, the thing to be sold, (S,) the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) between us, (S, Msb,) for such a sum: (S, Msb, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh, in thy saying, I will sell to thee this commodity for such a sum, and when I feel, or touch, thee, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded; or in the purchaser's saying the like: (Mgh:) or, (M, Mgh, K,) as in the Sunan of Aboo-Dáwood, (Mgh,) in purchasing a commodity on the condition of feeling it (M, Mgh, * K, *) behind a garment or piece of cloth, (K,) without seeing it, (M, K,) or spreading it out and turning it over and examining it: (Mgh:) or on the condition that the feeling it with the hand shall cut one off from the choice of returning it: (TA:) the mode of bargaining thus termed is forbidden. (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- For a tropical signification of the verb, see 1.

4 A^alomisoniY AljaAriyapa *
Permit thou me to feel, or touch, the girl. (A, TA.) ― -b2- A^alomisoniY A@moraA^aopF (tropical:) Marry thou to me a woman. (A, TA.)
5 talam~asa see 1, in two places.
8 A_ilotamasa see 1, in four places.

lamuwsN * A she-camel of whose fatness one doubts; (O, TS, K;) on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád; (TA;) i. q. $akuwkN and DabuwvN: (A, TA:) or of whose hump one doubts, whether there be in her fat or not; wherefore it is felt: (M, L:) pl. lumusN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; syn. daEiY~N: (K:) or in whose grounds of pretention to respect is a fault, or taint. (A, K.)
lamiysN * A woman soft to the feel, or touch; lay~inapu Almalomasi. (K.)
lamaAsapN * , (M,) lumaAsapN, (S,) or both, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A want: (IAar, Sgh:) or a moderate, or middling, want. (S, M, O, L.)

lamuwsapN *
A road, or way: so called because he who has lost his way seeks it in order to find the track of the travellers. (K, * TA.)

laAmisN * act. part. n. of 1. (Msb, &c.) One says, of a woman who commits adultery, or fornication, or acts viciously, falaAnapu laA tarud~u yada laAmisK, (A, TA,) or laA tamonaEu yada laAmisK, (K,) but the latter is at variance with the written authorities, the former being the phrase commonly known, (TA,) [properly signifying, Such a woman does not repel the hand of a feeler;] meaning, (tropical:) such a woman commits adultery, or fornication, and acts viciously, (K, TA,) not repelling from herself any one who desires of her that he may lie with her; (TA;) and she is suspected of easiness, or compliance, (K, TA,) towards him who desires of her that he may lie with her: (TA:) or the meaning is, such a woman gives, of her husband's property, what is sought, or demanded, from her; and this is more probably meant in a trad. in which a man is related to have said thus of his wife; because Mohammad directed him to retain her, and did not require him to divorce her. (TA.) The like said of a man, (K,) fulaAnN laA yarud~u yada laAmisK, (A, Msb,) means, (tropical:) Such a man has in him no force of resistance, (A, Msb, K,) nor care of what is sacred, or inviolable. (TA.)
malomasN * [A place that is felt, or touched: and it may also be an inf. n.: see lamiysN]. (K.)

A_ikaAfN malomuwsu AlA^aHonaA='i * (tropical:) An ass's saddle, or pad, of which the curved pieces of wood have been felt with the hands until they have become even: (M:) or of which any unevenness and prominence that was therein has been pared off (Lth, T, A, K) by the passing of the hand over it, (Lth, T,) or of the hands. (A.)

1 lamaZa * , (S, K,) aor.
lamuZa , (S,) inf. n. lamoZN, (S, M,) He sought leisurely and gradually, with his tongue, after the remains of the food in his mouth, (S, K, TA,) after eating: (TA:) and he put forth his tongue, and wiped with it his lips: (S, K:) as also ↓ tlm~Z, (S, K,) in both senses: (K:) you say also AlHay~apu ↓ tlm~Zt (tropical:) The serpent put forth its tongue, (S, K, TA,) like as the eater puts it forth and wipes with it his lip: (S, TA:) or the former verb and ↓ the latter signify he took with his tongue what remained in the mouth after eating: (M:) or he sought leisurely and gradually after the taste, and tasted time after time: (M, K:) or ↓ the latter signifies he tasted time after time; as also tmT~q: or he moved about his tongue in his mouth after eating, as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains of the food between his teeth; whereas tmT~q signifies he smacked his lips: (T:) or ↓ tlm~Z signifies he sought leisurely and gradually, with his tongue, after the remains of the food between his teeth after eating: or he put forth his tongue, and wiped with it his lips. (Mgh.) [Hence the saying bi*ikorihi ↓ maA zaAla fulaAnN yatalam~aZu (tropical:) [Such a one ceased not to busy his tongue with mentioning him, or it]. (TA.) -A2- lamaZa AlmaA='a, inf. n. lamoZN, He tasted the water with the extremity of his tongue. (TA.) -A3- See also 2, in two places.

2 lm~Zhu * , inf. n. talomiyZN; (TA;) or ↓ lamaZahu; (M as quoted in the TT [being there written without teshdeed; and both seem to be correct;]) He gave him something to taste; he fed him with something whereby to content or divert, him [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the morning-meal; syn. *aw~aqahu and lam~ajahu, (M, TA,) both of which are alike. (TA.) You say also, lam~iZo fulaAnFA lumaAZapF [Give thou to such a one, to eat,] something which he may taste time after time, or after eating which he may move about his tongue in his mouth as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains thereof between his teeth. (T.) ― -b2- And [hence,] lm~Zhu, (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ lamaZahu; (M, K;) (tropical:) He gave to him (M, K, TA) somewhat (M, TA) of his right, or due. (M, K, TA.)

4 AlmZhu *
He put the water upon the edge of his lips, (M,) or upon his lips, or lip. (K, accord. to different copies.) ― -b2- And hence A_ilomaAZN is used to signify (tropical:) The act of piercing, or thrusting, feebly [with a spear or the like]. (M, * TA.)
5 talam~aZa see 1, in six places.

8 AltmZhu *
He ate it: (ISk, S, M, A:) or he threw it quickly into his mouth. (O, K.)
9 AlmZ~ * , inf. n. A_ilomiZaAZN, He (a horse) had a lumoZap, or whiteness upon his lower lip. (S, K.)
lamaZN * : see lumoZapN, in two places.

lumoZapN *
A whiteness in the lower lip of a horse, (S, M, K,) not being a part of the [whiteness termed] gur~ap; (M;) as also ↓ lamaZN: (M, K:) also the former, a gur~ap which descends so that it enters into the mouth of a horse, and so that he removes with it what has remained in his mouth after eating: and ↓ the latter, somewhat white in the lip of a beast of carriage, not passing beyond the place where the lip closes: (M:) or the former, a whiteness upon both the lips, only. (M, K.) Also, Somewhat of whiteness in the fore leg of a horse, or in his hind leg, upon the A^a$oEar [or hair which surrounds the hoof.] (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) And A small spot (As, T, S, M, K) of white: (As, T, S, K:) and contr. of black, in the heart. (K.) It is said in a trad., that faith begins like a lumoZap in the heart; (T, S;) and as faith increases, so the latter increases. (T.) And that hypocrisy in the heart is a black lmZp, and faith is a white lmZp; and as either increases, so the lmZp increases. (M. TA.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A small quantity of clarified butter, which one takes with the finger, (K, TA,) like a walnut: mentioned by Z and Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

lamaAZN *
A thing which one tastes, (K, TA), and with which one moves about the tongue in the mouth. (TA.) You say, maA lahu lamaAZN He has not anything to taste, (K, TA,) &c. (TA.) And maA *uqotu lamaAZFA I have not tasted anything. (S) And $ariba AlmaA='a lamaAZFA He tasted the water with the extremity of his tongue. (S, M, K. *) [See also what next follows.]

lumaAZapN *
What remains in the mouth, (S, M, K,) of food, (S, M,) after eating: (TA:) or something which one may taste time after time, or after eating which one may move about his tongue in his mouth as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains thereof between his teeth. (T.) [See also what next precedes.] ― -b2- Also, A remain, remainder, or residue, of something little in quantity. (TA.)
A^alomaZu * A horse having a lumoZap, or whiteness, upon his lower lip: when it is upon the upper lip. he is termed A^arovamu: (S, K:) or a horse whose lower lip is white. (Mgh.)
malaAmiZu * The part around the lips of a man: (M, K:) because he tastes therewith. (M.)

mutalam~aZN * The part of the face by which smiling is expressed; syn. mutabas~amN. (K. TA) [in the CK, erroneously, mutabas~im.]) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu Almutalam~aZi [Verily he is goodly in respect of the part of the face by which smiling is expressed]. (TA.)
See Supplement

1 lahiba * , aor.
lahaba , (inf. n. lahabN, S,) (tropical:) He thirsted; was thirsty: (S, K:) [probably, burned with thirst].

2 lh~b Aln~aAra * [same as ↓ A^alohabahaA, except that it has an intensive signification; He made the fire to flame, or blaze, fiercely, or intensely: or, to flame, or blaze, without smoke, fiercely, or intensely.] (K.)

4 Alhb Aln~aAra *
He made the fire to flame, or blaze: (S:) or made it to flame, or blaze, free from smoke. (K.) ― -b2- Alhb It (lightning) flashed uninterruptedly. (K.) See also A^aholaba. ― -b3- Alhb, inf. n. A_ilohaAbN, He (a horse, As, or other thing that runs, Lh,) was ardent, or impetuous, in his
course, or running; (As, S;) as also Ahlb: (As:) or he ran with energy, or effort, so as to raise the dust: (K:) or he ran violently, raising the lahaba, or dust. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence, Alhb fiY AlkalaAmi (tropical:) He spoke rapidly [and with vehemence]. (TA.) ― -b5- Alhbhu AlA^amoru (tropical:) The thing, or affair, excited him, and inflamed him. (TA.)

5 tlh~bt Aln~aAru * , quasi-pass. of lah~aba, (K,) [same as ↓ A_ilotahabato, except that it has an intensive signification;] The fire flamed, or blazed, (S,) [fiercely, or intensely, or flamed, or blazed, burned without smoke, fiercely, or intensely].― -b2- tlh~b juwEFA, and jwEA ↓ Althb, (tropical:) He burned with hunger. (TA.) ― -b3- tlh~b gayoZFA He burned, and was or became hot, with wrath, or rage. (TA, art. wgr.) See 8.

8 Althbt Aln~aAru * , quasi-pass. of A^alohaba, (K,) The fire flamed, or blazed: (S:) or flamed, or blazed, free from smoke. (K.) ― -b2- Althb Ealayohi (tropical:) He was incensed, or inflamed with anger, against him. (TA.) ― -b3- Althb and ↓ tlh~b [It (any part of the body) became inflamed]. ― -b4- See 5.
lahobN * : see lahabN.

lihobN *
A gap, or space, between two mountains: (S, K:) or a cleft, or fissure, in a mountain: (Lh, K:) or a small gap, or ravine, such as is termed $iEobN, in a mountain: (K:) or a cleft in a mountain, afterwards widening like a road: a liSob and a $aq~ are smaller than a lhb; like a small road: (Aboo-Sa'eed-Es-Sukkaree:) or a face of a mountain, resembling a wall, that cannot be ascended: (K:) and similar to this is the lhb of the sky at the horizon: or, as some say, a subterranean excavation, or habitation: syn. sarabN fiY AlA^aroDi: (TA:) pl. A^alohaAbN and luhuwbN and lihaAbN (S, K) and lihaAbapN. (K.) See an ex. voce karabap.

lahabN * and ↓ lahobN (K) and ↓ lahiybN and ↓ luhaAbN and ↓ lahabaAnN (S, K), [inf. ns., of which the verb, lahiba, aor.
lahaba , does not appear to have been used in the classical ages,] The flaming, or blazing, of fire: (S:) or its flaming, or blazing, free from smoke: (T, K:) or lahabN signifies the flame, or blaze, of fire: (S, K:) and ↓ lahiybN, its heat. (K.) ― -b2- lahabN Dust rising (K) like smoke. (TA.)

luhobapN *
A clear white colour: (K:) brightness of the complexion, or colour of the skin. (TA.) ― -b2- luhobapN (in two copies of the S, lahobapN; but in the K expressly said to be with dammeh;) and ↓ luhaAbN and ↓ lahabaAnN (K) (tropical:) Thirst: (S, K:) [probably burning thirst].

lahabaAnN * : see lahabN and luhobapN. ― -b2- Also, The burning of coals, or embers, without blazing. (T.) ― -b3- The burning of heat upon heated ground. (TA.) ― -b4- Vehemence of heat (K) upon heated ground and the like. (ISd.) ― -b5- A hot day. (K.)
lahobaAnu * , fem. lahobaY, (tropical:) Thirsty: (S, K:) [probably burning with thirst:] an epithet applied to a man or woman: (S:) pl. lihaAbN. (K.)
luhaAbN * : see lahabN and luhobapN.
lahiybN * : see lahabN.

luhaAbapN *
A garment (kisaA'N) in which a stone is put, and with which one side of the kind of camel-litter called hawodaj, or one side of a load, is balanced. (Th.)

A^ulohuwbN * , a subst., The ardour, or impetuosity, of a horse (&c., Lh) in his course, or running: (S:) or his energy, or effort, in his course, so that he raises the dust: or a violent run, by which the dust (All~ahabu) is raised: (TA:) or the commencement of a horse's course, or run. (K.) ― -b2- lahu A^ulohuwbN He runs violently, raising the dust. (TA.) See also A^uholuwbN. ― -b3- Also used as an epithet: you say $ad~N A^ulohuwbN [A violent run, in which the dust is raised]. (TA.)

milohabN *
Pleasing in beauty: (IAar, K:) and having much hair: an epithet applied to a man. (IAar.)
mulah~abN * (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, not saturated with red dye: (K:) imperfectly dyed. (TA.)

laAhuwtN *
Divinity; divine nature. Mentioned here agreeably with the assertion of some, that the t is a radical letter: but this is a point that requires consideration. (TA.)

1 lahiva * , aor.
lahava , inf. n. lahavN and lahaAvN and lahavaAnN, He thirsted; was thirsty: (S, K:) or thirst heated his belly, or inside. (L.) ― -b2- lahava, aor.
lahava , inf. n. lahovN and luhaAvN; (S, K;) and lahiva, aor.
lahava ; (TA;) and ↓ Althv; (K;) He (a dog, S, and a man, and, in the case of the second verb, a bird also, TA) put forth his tongue, by reason of thirst, or fatigue, or weariness: (S, K:) or lahava signifies his breath (nfs) rose, by reason of fatigue, or weariness: or he (a dog) put forth his tongue, by reason of thirst: and he (a man) was fatigued, or weary. (TA.)
8 A_ilotahava see 1.

luhovapN *
Thirst. (K.) ― -b2- Fatigue. (AA, K.) ― -b3- The red speck in a palm-leaf, (K,) which you see when you split it. (TA.) ― -b4- luhaAvN [for lihaAvN, pl. of luhovapN,] The specks in palmleaves: (Fr, K:) the red specks in palm-leaves, when they are split: (Fr, TA:) accord. to rule, it should be lihaAvN, like niqaATN. (K.)

lahovaAnu *
Thirsty: (S, K:) fem. lahovaY. (S.)
luhaAvN * The heat, or burning, of thirst; (S, K;) vehemence of thirst. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The severity, or vehemence, of death. (K, TA.) -A2- See luhovapN.
luhaAviY~N * (assumed tropical:) A man (TA) having many red moles (xiylaAn) on his face: (Fr, K:) from luhaAvN, signifying the “ specks in palm-leaves. ” (Fr.)
luh~aAvN * [pl. of laAhivN?] Manufacturers, with palm-leaves, of the kind of baskets called dawaAxil~u, (K,) pl. of dawoxal~ahN, in which dates are put. (AA.)

fiY sakorapK malohavapN *
In intoxication is a cause, or an occasion, of lhv [i. e., thirst; or putting forth the tongue by reason of thirst]. (TA, from a trad.)

1 lahija bihi * , aor.
lahaja , (S, K,) inf. n. lahajN; (S;) and ↓ A^alohaja, and ↓ lahowaja; (TA;) He became devoted, addicted, or attached, to it, (i. e., to an affair, TA,) and kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, persistently, or assiduously, to it; was intent upon it; (S, K;) and accustomed, or habituated, himself to it. (TA.)
2 lah~ajahumo * , inf. n. talohiyjN, He fed them with something whereby to ally the craving of their stomachs before the morning-meal called AlgadaA='. (El-Umawee, S, K.) [See luhojapN.]

4 Alhjhu bihi *
He made him to become devoted, addicted, or attached, to it, (an affair,) and to keep, attend, or apply himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it; to be intent upon it; and to accustom himself to it. (TA.) See 1. ― -b2- Alhj He (a man) had young weaned camels intent upon sucking their mothers, and persevering therein, (S, K,) and therefore made wooden pins, and tied them to the udders, that the young ones might not be able to suck: (S:) this form of the verb signifies the depriving the object of the quality denoted by the unaugmented verb: (L:) or he (a pastor) had young weaned camels intent upon sucking their mothers, and persevering therein, and it became necessary for him to perforate the tongue of each, and to insert in it a falokap, which is a round thing, like the falokap of a spindle, made of coarse hair (hulob), and [probably meaning or] to slit the tongue; each of which operations is performed to prevent its sucking; for the same purpose, also, a wooden pin is stuck over the nose of the young camel: the pastor in this case is termed ↓ mulohijN: and one does
not say A^alohajotu AlfaSiyla, but simply A^alohaja Alr~aAEiY. (T.)

11 AlhAj~ * , inf. n. A_ilohiyjaAjN, It (anything, S) became mixed, or confused. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (milk) thickened so that parts thereof became mixed together, but it did not become completely thick. (S, K.) ― -b3- AlhAj~t Eayonuhu His eye became infused (lit. mixed) with drowsiness. (S, K,) ― -b4- [See also mulohaAj~N.]

Q. Q. 1 lahowaja A^amorahu * (inf. n. lahowajapN, S) (tropical:) He performed, executed, or managed, his affairs in an unsound manner. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b2- lahowaja He cooked roast meat insufficiently, or not thoroughly: (K:) or he cooked roast meat, (K,) or flesh-meat, (S,) not well; (S, K;) as also ↓ talahowaja. (S.) See 1.

Q. Q. 2
see Q. Q. 1.

[
lahijN biA^amorK *
Devoted, addicted, or attached, to an affair, and keeping, attending, or applying himself, constantly, perseveringly, persistently, or assiduously, to it; intent upon it; and accustoming himself to it: part. n. of 1.] You say, rajulN lahijN bi$aYo'K [A man devoted, &c., to a thing]. (M in art. bl.)

lahojapN * and ↓ lahajapN The tongue: (S, K:) or the tip, or extremity, of the tongue. (L.) ― -b2- The tongue, or dialect, or language, which a person speaks by nature and custom and education. (L.) ― -b3- fulaAnN faSiyHu All~ahojapi, and ↓ All~ahajapi, Such a one is of chaste tongue: (S:) or, chaste in the dialect, or language, which he speaks by nature and custom and education. (L.) ― -b4- Also, (assumed tropical:) both words, but the former is the more approved, The sound of speech. (L.)

luhojapN *
That with which one allays the craving of his stomach before the morning-meal called AlgadaA='. (K.)
lahajapN * : see lahojapN.
mulohijN * : see 4.

mulahowajN * Roast meat insufficiently cooked. (S.) ― -b2- raA^oyN mulahowajN (tropical:) An unsound opinion. (A.) ― -b3- HadiyvN mulahowajN (tropical:) An unsound story, narration, or tradition. (A.)

mulohaAj~N *
Mixed; confused. (TA.) ― -b2- Milk thickened so that parts thereof are mixed together, but not completely thick. (TA.) ― -b3- raA^ayotu A^amora baniY fulaAnK mulohaAj~FA I saw the affair, or case, of the sons of such a one to be confused. (S.)
mulah~ajN * One who sleeps, and lacks power, or ability, to work. (K.)
