1 lahadahu * , (aor.
lahada , L, K, inf. n. lahodN, L,) It (a load) oppressed him, (a camel, L,) by its weight, (S, L, K,) and squeezed him: (L:) it (a heavy load) squeezed it, (namely, a camel's back or side,) or bruised it so that it swelled, and became galled: in which case, a hollow is made at the proper place in the stuffed lining of the saddle, to prevent farther injury. (L.) ― -b2- lahada He jaded his beast of carriage, and rendered it emaciated, or lean, by journeying upon it. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- lahadahu, aor.
lahada , L, K, inf. n. lahodN, L, and lahodapN; Kr;) and ↓ lh~dhu, (inf. n. talohiydN; TA;) but the latter denotes frequency of the action; (S, L;) He pushed, pushed away, or repelled, him: or pushed him violently upon the chest: (L:) or he pushed him, pushed him away, or repelled him, on account of his baseness, or despicableness: (S, L, K:) or he struck him in the breasts, (L,) or in the bases of the breasts, (K,) and in the bases of the shoulder-blades: (L, K:) or he pressed, or squeezed, him; syn. gamazahu. (L, K.)
2 lah~ada see 1.

4 Alhd bihi *
He instigated against him; and aided against him; and acted wrongfully, or injuriously, towards him. (JK.) ― -b2- Alhd He did, or acted, wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (L, K;) [as also AlHd]. ― -b3- Alhd bihi is said of a man, with respect to another, when the former withholds one of two men and leaves the other at liberty, fighting him. [The object is, app., the former of these two, as he is the injured one.] (AA, S, L, K.) ― -b4- It is also said of a man, with respect to another, when the former acquaints one of the men with the contention or dispute of the other, or with that which the other would say to him, and makes known to him a matter which he understands from him, but which is obscure to others, and informs him of the other's argument. [The object is, app., the latter of these two, as he is the injured one.] (AA, L.) ― -b5- Also, waA@ll~`hi maA qulotahaA A_il~aA A^ano tulohida EalaY~a By God, thou saidst it not save that thou mightest aid against me, is said when a man has acquainted one of the two men with that which the other would say. [It is, app., said by the latter of these two, as he is the injured one.] (AA, S, L.) ― -b6- Alhd He made, or prepared, the kind of food called lahiydap. (IKtt.) ― -b7- Alhd bihi, (inf. n. A_ilohaAdN, L,) He held him in light estimation, or despised him: (S, L, K:) or he held his clemency, or forbearance, or intellect, (Hilom,) in light estimation, or despised it; as also AlHd bh. (L, art. lHd.)

lahodN *
A certain disease which affects camels in the chest; (T:) an opening, or parting asunder, (A_inofiraAjN,) in the chest of a camel, [app., next to either, or both, of the arms,] by reason of a push. or collision, (L, K,) or the like, (K,) or by reason of the squeezing of a load: (L:) or (so in the L: in the K, and) a tumour in the farySap [or portion of flesh between the shoulder-blade and the side], (L, K,) by reason of the pressure of a bag or the like upon the camel's back. (L.) ― -b2- Also, A certain disease, like an opening, or parting asunder, [app., in the part where the thighs unite,] (kaAlA_inofiraAji,) which befalls men in the legs and thighs. (L, K)

lahiydN * A beast of carriage jaded, or fatigued, (S, L,) and rendered emaciated, or lean, by being ridden. (L.) ― -b2- A she-camel pressed, or squeezed, and having her flesh bruised, by her load. (Lh, L.) ― -b3- lahiydN and ↓ malohuwdN A camel oppressed by the weight of a load, and squeezed: having his back or side squeezed by a heavy load, or bruised so that it is swollen, and galled: having his side squeezed by a heavy load so that a disease has been the consequence, which has disordered his lungs. (L.)

lahiydapN *
A kind of food of the Arabs; (L;) thin EaSiydap; (S, L, K;) not thin so as to be supped, nor thick so as to be formed into mouthfuls; thicker than Hariyqap and saxiynap, but thinner than EaSiydap [properly so called]. (S, L.)

malohuwdN * : see lahiydN. ― -b2- malohuwdN and ↓ mulah~adN, but the latter denotes frequency of the action, A man pushed, pushed away, or repelled, on account of his baseness, or despicableness. (S, L.) See also lahadahu.
mulah~adN * : see malohuwdN. ― -b2- Also, Base, or despicable, held weak, (El-Hawázinee, L,) and frequently repelled from doors. (El-Hawázinee, TA.)
A^alozamahu laho*abFA waAHidFA * , i. e. lizaAzFA walizaAmFA; in the CK, lazaAzFA; (Kr, K;) [app. meaning He made him to adhere with one adhesion].

div2.n: lhz lhs lhT lhE lhf lhq

head.foreign: lhz lhs lhT lhE lhf lhq

div2.entryFree: See Supplement

Q. 2 talaholaA^a *
He desisted through timidity, and was cowardly. (T, K. Mentioned in the T among the class of quinqueliterals, TA.)
See Supplement

1 laA='a * , aor. yaluwo'u, inf. n. lawo'apN, app., He was foul, ugly, or deformed, in countenance.] lawo'apN, accord. to the K, is the same as sawo'apN; but this is probably a mistake for $awo'apN, The being foul, ugly, or deformed, in countenance; [which is the signification of law~apN]. (TA.) [See art. lwY.] ― -b2- h`*aA waAll~`hi Al$~awo'apu waAll~awo'apu, and All~aw~apu, [app., This, by Allah, is foulness and ugliness!] (TA [app. from the T.])

2 lw~A^ *
He looked malignantly with his eyes or countenance. (TA: app. from the T.) ― -b2- lw~A^ All~`hu bika May God render thee foul, or ugly! (T.)

1 laAba * , aor. yaluwbu, inf. n. lawobN and luwbN and luw^uwbN and luwaAbN (S, K) and luw^aAbN (K) and lawabaAnN (K, accord. to the TA) or luwbaAnN (S, CK) He thirsted; was thirsty; (S, K;) or he, thirsting, went round about the water, not reaching it: (K:) or he went round about the water, by reason of thirst. (ISk.) ― -b2- lawobN signifies The camels' going round about the tank, or cistern, and not being able to get at the water, on account of the crowding, or pressing. (As, K.)

2 lw~bhu *
He mixed it with the perfume called malaAb: or he smeared it therewith. (K.)

4 AlAb *
His camels were thirsty: (K:) his camels went round about the water, by reason of thirst. (TA.)

luwbN * and ↓ lawaAy^ibu Camels, or palm-trees, thirsty; far from water. (K.) You say, tarakotuhaA EalaY AlHawoDi ↓ lawaAy^iba I left them (the camels) going round about the tank, or cistern, unable to get at the water, on account of the crowding, or pressing. (As, S.) [lwAy^b is pl. of laAy^ibapN.] ― -b2- luwbN A piece of meat that turns round in the cooking-pot. (K.) -A2- luwbN Bees: (K:) accord. to some, originally nuwbN. (MF.) In some copies of the K, nxl is erroneously put for nHl. (TA.)
laAbapN * (tropical:) A number of black camels collected together: (K:) likened to the tract so called, covered with black stones. (TA.) [See mafotuwnapN.] ― -b2- See luwbapN.

luwbapN * and ↓ laAbapN A stony tract, of which the stones are black and worn: syn. Har~apN: (S, K:) luwbapN and nuwbapN signify a tract of land covered, or strewed, with black stones; and hence a negro is called luwbiY~N and nuwbiY~N, [and negroes collectively are called luwbapN and nuwbapN: the former, however, are evidently the Lybians, the latter, the Nubians:] (A 'Obeyd, S or, as in the TA, A 'Obeydeh:) or a lwbp is a very black, rugged, lengthened tract of ground, only at, or by, [so fiY seems here to signify] the projecting part of a mountain, or the lower and thinner, or finer, part of a sand-hill, or the foot (ErD) of a mountain: (Az:) or it may be a difficult ascent, or acclivity, up a mountain, rising to the greatest height: (ISh:) pl. of lwbp and luwbN lAbp and laAbN (S, K) and laAbaAtN: (S:) or luwbN is pl. of lAbp: [not, as implied above, of lwbp:] (Sb:) for a number from three to ten, the pl. used is lAbAt; and more than then are termed lAb and lwb: (TA:) [or these last two words are coll. gen. ns., of which lAbp and lwbp are the ns. un.] ― -b2- maA bayona laAbatayohaA mivolu fulaAnK [Between its two tracts of black stones, there is not the like of such a one: i. e., within its (the city's) limits, there is not, &c.]: only said with reference to El-Medeeneh and El-Koofeh: (RA:) or said originally with reference to El-Medeeneh, and fig. with reference to any other city. (A.) ― -b3- baEiydu maA bayona All~aAbatayoni, said by 'Áïsheh, describing her father, (tropical:) Freehearted; of ample endowments, app. as to wealth, or possessions, and as to mind, or disposition: syn. waAsiEu AlS~adori waAsiEu AlEaTani. (TA.) ― -b4- luwbapN A people that is with another people, but of which advice or counsel is not asked [by the latter] with respect to anything, (K,) whether good or evil. (TA.)

A^asowadu luwbiY~N * (and nuwbiY~N, TA,) [Very black]: derived from luwbapN, as signifying “ a tract covered, or strewed, with black stones ”: (K:) or from All~uwbu as a syn. of Aln~uwbu, meaning [“ the Nubians, ” but see above] “ a certain race, or nation, of the negroes. ” (RA.) ― -b2- luwbY~N: see luwbapN.

luwaAbN *
i. q. luEaAbN; Slaver, or drivel: (K:) a chaste word, not formed by mispronunciation. (TA.)

luwbiyaA='u * (K) and luwbiyaA and luwbiyaAjN (TA) and luwbaA='u (K) [The dolichos lubia of Forskål; a species of kidney-bean]. Accord. to El-Khafájee and ElJawáleekee, not an Arabic word. (TA.) [In Persian, luwbiyaA and luwbiyaho and luwbaA: in Greek, λόβος.]

laAy^ibN *
Thirsting: [but see the verb:] pl. luw^uwbN: like as $uhuwdN is pl. of $aAhidN. (S.) ― -b2- laAy^ibapN: see luwbN.
malaAbN * a Persian word, (TA,) A kind of perfume, (S, K,) like xaluwq (S): or saffron. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- malaAbapN A fascicle, or small bundle, of filaments of saffron; a shive of saffron. (IAar).
muliybN * A man whose camels are thirsty; or whose camels are going round about the water, by reason of thirst. (TA.)
mulaw~abN * A thing mixed with the perfume called malaAb: (TA:) a thing smeared therewith. (S.) ― -b2- mulaw~abo Twisted iron. (K.) Applied as an epithet to a coat of mail. (TA.)

1 laAta * , aor. yaluwtu, He told, narrated, or gave an account of, a thing different from that respecting which he was asked. (K.) [But accord. to some, the aor. is yaliytu, and the verb belongs to art. lyt.] It was said to ElAsadeeyeh, “ What is AlmudaAHalapu ” and she answered A^ano yaliyta AlA_inosaAnu $ayoy^FA qado Ealimahu, i. e., “ The concealing a thing that one knows, and telling, or narrating, something different from it. ” (TA.) ― -b2- laAta Alxabara, aor. yaluwtu, He concealed the news, or information, (K,) and related what was different therefrom. (TA.) [But see above.] ― -b3- laAta Alr~ajula, aor. yaluwtu, He told the man, or narrated to him, a thing in a manner different from the real state of the case: or he expressed the news, or information, to him obscurely, or enigmatically, or obscured it to him, or concealed it from him, telling him, narrating to him, or giving him an account of, a thing different from that respecting which he was asked: but accord. to As., laAtahu, aor. yaliytuhu, [not yaluwtuhu.] inf. n. layotN, signifies “ he expressed to him the news, or information, obscurely, or enigmatically, or obscured it to him, or concealed it from him ”: thus he makes it belong to art. lyt: and the like is said in the L. See also above. (TA.) ― -b4- laAtahu, aor. yaluwtu; as also laAtahu, aor. yaliytu; He withheld him, or restrained him, and turned him, or averted him, from his course, purpose, or object. (S, K, art lyt, q. v.)
All~aAtu * : see All~aAt~u, in art. lt.

1 laAva * , aor. yaluwvu, inf. n. lawovN, He folded a thing: (IAar, IKt:) and twisted it. (IAar.) These are the original meanings. (IAar, IKt.) ― -b2- He turned a thing round twice; as a turban is turned round, and an A_izaAr. (TA.) ― -b3- He bound, or wound round, a turban. (K.) You say laAva AlEamiAmapa EalaY raA^osihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He bound, or wound round, the turban on his head. (S.) ― -b4- laAva Alwabara biAlfalokapi He wound the camel's hair round the whirl of the spindle. (TA.) ― -b5- AlA^asoqiyapu Alit~aY tulaAvu EalaY A^afowaAhihaA The skins that are bound and tied round their mouths. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- laAva, aor. yaluwvu, He (a man) went round about; syn. daAra. (S.) ― -b7- laAva
bi$aYo'K He went round about a thing; syn. TAf bh. (TA.) ― -b8- laAva bihi Aln~aAsu, and ↓ AlAv, The people collected around him. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b9- laAvato qarunFA mino quruwnihaA biAld~uhoni She surrounded, or, as some say, intermixed [one of her locks of hair with ointment]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b10- laAva, and ↓ AlAv, and ↓ AltAv, It (a plant, or tree, or herbage,) became tangled and luxuriant. (TA.) ― -b11- laAva, aor. yaluwvu, inf. n. lawovN, He rolled about a morsel of food in melted fat or the like. (K.) ― -b12- laAva, aor. yaluwvu, inf. n. lawovN, He chewed, or mumbled, a thing; syn. laAka; (K;) such as a morsel of food, &c. (TA) ― -b13- laAvahu AlmaTaru, and ↓ lw~vhu, The rain laid it, or mixed it, (i. e., a plant,) part over part. (TA.) ― -b14- laAva, aor. yaluwvu, inf. n. lawovN; (K;) or lawiva, [aor. yalowavu,] inf. n. lawavN; (L;) and ↓ AltAv, (S, K,) He was slow, or tardy, (S, K,) fiY Eamalihi in his work, (S,) or fiY AlA^amori in the affair. (K.) ― -b15- ↓ AltAv He (a camel) was slow, or tardy and languid. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b16- laAva Eano HaAjatiY He was slow, tardy, or tedious, in accomplishing my want. (TA.) ― -b17- laAva lawovFA mina AlkalaAmi He twisted his speech, and did not make it plain by reason of shame. (IKt, TA, from a trad.) [Similarly, fY kalaAmihi ↓ AltAv. (A.)] ― -b18- laAva He was slow in speech, and heavy in tongue. (TA.) ― -b19- See 8. ― -b20- laAva Ald~aAra, aor. yaluwvu, inf. n. lawovN, He kept to the house. (K.) ― -b21- laAva, aor. yaluwvu, inf. n. lawovN; and ↓ lw~v, inf. n. talowiyvN; He mixed, and steeped, or macerated, in water. (K.) ― -b22- laAva bihi, aor. yaluwvu, (inf. n. lawovN, K,) He took refuge in him; had recourse to him for protection or concealment: (S, K:) i. q. laA*a: (S:) accord. to Yaakoob, the v here is a substitute for the * of lAa*a. (TA.)

2 lw~v Alt~ibona biAlqat~i *
He mixed the straw with [the kind of trefoil called] qt~. (A.) ― -b2- lw~v He, or it, rendered water turbid. (S.) ― -b3- lw~v, inf. n. talowiyvN, He befouled, defiled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, besmeared, or bedaubed, (S, K,) his clothes with mud. (S.) ― -b4- See 1 and 8.

4 A^alowava see 1. -A2- A^alowavati AlA^aroDu The land produced fresh, or green, herbage, (raTob, as in some copies of the K, or ruTob, as in others and in the TA,) among that which was dry. So in the K: but in the L, as follows. Alwv AlS~il~iyaAnu The Sl~yAn dried up, and then produced fresh, or green, shoots: and sometimes the same verb is thus used with reference to the DaEap and halotaY and saHam: of the vumaAm, one scarcely ever says Alwv, but baqala; nor does one say of the Alwv Earofaj, but AdbY, and A_imotaEasa. (TA.) ― -b2- A^alavotu bihi maAliY I asked him to keep my property as a deposit. (K.) From All~awovu “ the taking refuge. ” (TA.) ― -b3- lamo yulivo, in a verse of El-'Ajjáj, He, or it, did not make to delay. (TA.)

5 tlw~v *
It (a garment) was, or became, befouled, defiled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, besmeared, or bedaubed, with mud. (Msb.) ― -b2- tlw~v biAloA^amori [app., He was confused, or perplexed, by the affair]. (Lth.)

8 AltAv * : see 1. ― -b2- It was, or became, collected together. (TA) ― -b3- AltAv; (S, K;) and ↓ lw~v, inf. n. talowiyvN; (L;) It (an affair, TA,) was, or became, confused, (S, K,) intricate, and difficult. (TA.) You say AltAvt Ealayohi AlA^umwuru The affairs became confused, and intricate, to him: (TA:) and AltAvt AlxuTuwbu [The affairs became confused]. (S.) ― -b4- Also, both verbs, (the former accord. to the S and K, and the latter accord. to the L,) It became wound about. (S, L, K.) You say A_ilotaAvato biraA^osi Alqalami $aEorapN (so in one copy of the S: in another, AltAv) [A hair became wound about the head, or tip, of the reed-pen: read, erroneously, by Golius, and Freytag, AltAv brA^s Alqlm $aEarahu]. (S.) ― -b5- He became strong, powerful, or vigorous. (K, TA.) ― -b6- He became fat. (K, TA.) ― -b7- He withheld, or restrained; syn. Habasa: (K:) [but it seems rather to signify he withheld, or restrained, himself; syn. A_iHotabasa; like ↓ laAva]. Accord. to the K, lw~v, inf. n. talowiyvN, signifies the same; but it is not so: it is the same as AltAv only as signifying “ it was, or became confused ”, and “ it became wound about. ” (TA.)

entryFree.key: Hal~a mino EimaAmatihi lawovFA A^awo lawovayoni

div2.entryFree:
Hal~a mino EimaAmatihi lawovFA A^awo lawovayoni *
He loosed, or undid, a turn, or twist, or two turns, or twists, of his turban. (TA, from a trad.) -A2- lawovN Strength; power; vigour: (S, K, TA:) as also ↓ luwvapN, [as in one place,] or ↓ luwovapN, [as in another]. (TA.) -A3- naAqapN *aAtu lawovK, and ↓ luwvapK A strong she-camel; a she-camel endowed with strength, or vigour: (TA:) or, the former, (L,) or the latter, (S,) a she-camel having much flesh and fat, (S, L,) with which she is bound round: (L:) or, as some say, stupid, unsteady, and hasty; syn. *At hawajK: (S:) or, the former, a bulky she-camel; yet her bulkiness does not prevent her being swift. (Lth.) ― -b2- rajulN *uw lawovK A strong man. (TA.) ― -b3- lawovN, (IAar,) or ↓ lawovapN, (As,) Resolution of mind, (IAar, As,) and strength of mind. (IAar.) ― -b4- lawotN, Evil, as a subst. (K.) ― -b5- lawovN Mutual suits, or demands, with malevolences, or rancours: (K:) one says, bayonahumo lawovN Between them are mutual suits, &c. (TK.) -A4- lawovN Offsets of palm-trees. (AHn.) -A5- lawovN Wounds; syn. HiraAHaAtN. (K.) -A6- lawovN Weak, incomplete, evidence; (Az, in Msb;) resembling what is termed dalaAlapN, (Az, K,) not complete, or perfect, evidence; so accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee: (Az.:) it is one person's giving his testimony to the fact of a slain person's declaring, before his death, that a certain person slew him; or two persons giving their testimony to the fact of there having existed enmity between them two, [i. e., the slain person and the person accused of slaying him,] or, of one's having threatened the other; and the like: it is from talaw~ava as signifying “ it was befouled, or defiled. ” (TA.) ― -b2- See lawatN, and luwvapN.

liyvN *
A certain plant (S, K) that winds about: the w is changed into Y on account of the kesreh before it. (S.)
lawavN * , or ↓ lawovN, (as in different copies of the S) Languor; flaccidity; in a man. (S.)
lawivN * : see laAy^ivN.
livapN * The gum, accord. to some, belongs to this art., because the flesh of the gums is bound (liyva) round the roots of the teeth. (TA.)
lawovapN * : see lawovN, and luwvapN.

lwvapN *
Languor, and slowness, or tardiness. (S, K.) ― -b2- rajulN *uw luwvapK A man slow, or tardy, and weak. (TA.) ― -b3- luwvapN Weakness: (IAar, K:) as also ↓ lawovN. (TA.) ― -b4- Weakness of judgment, and a repetition, or stuttering, (talajolujN,) in speech. (TA, from a trad.) An impediment in speech. (Msb.) ― -b5- luwnapN (IAar, M, K) and ↓ lawovapN (IAar, M) and ↓ lawovN (Msb) Stupidity; foolishness; paucity of sense. (IAar, M, K, Msb.) ― -b6- luwvapN A touch, or first affection, of insanity, or diabolical possession. (S, K.) ― -b7- luwvapN A state of excitement; syn. hayojN. (S, K.) -A2- luwvapN Abundance of flesh and fat, (S, K,) in a she-camel. (S.) [See lawovN.] -A3- luwvapN A piece of rag collected together, with which one plays. (K.)
liwaAvN * : see luwaAvapN.

luwaAvapN * and ↓ lawiyvapN A company, an assembly, or a troop, (K,) of men, and of other animals. (TA.) ― -b2- mina Aln~aAsi ↓ lawiyvapN A company, or an assembly, of people of different tribes; (S, K;) like labiyvapN. (K.) -A2- luwaAvapN One who, or a thing which, (Al~a*iY: in the TA, Al*r:) is befouled, or defiled, (yatalaw~avu) in anything. (K.) -A3- luwaAvapN and ↓ liwaAvN (the latter [in the CK luwaAvN] is with kesr, and is mentioned in the L, without the former, on the authority of Fr, TA,) Flour [of wheat, &c.]
which is sprinkled upon the table, beneath dough; (K,) to prevent the dough's adhering to the table. (TA.)
lawiyvapN * : see luwaAvapN.

lay~ivN * : see laAy^ivN. ― -b2- liHoyapN lay~ivapN (tropical:) A tangled beard. (TA.) ― -b3- A beard in which half-white hairs are mixed with white: so in the K; but correctly, in which half-white, or grizzly, hairs are mixed with black. (TA.)

entryFree.key: wayolN lil~aw~aAviyna Al~a*iyna yaluwvuwna maEa Albaqar A_irofaEo yaA gulaAmu

div2.entryFree:
wayolN lil~aw~aAviyna Al~a*iyna yaluwvuwna maEa Albaqar A_irofaEo yaA gulaAmu *
DaEo yaA gulaAmu: respecting these words, occurring in a trad., El-Harbee says, I think the meaning to be, those to whom various kinds of food are carried round about; from All~awovu, “ winding round ” a turban on the head. (IAth.)

nabaAtN laAy^ivN * , and ↓ laAvN, and ↓ lay~ivN, A tangled plant; (K;) a tangled and luxuriant plant: and in like manner, herbage: laAvN is originally lawivN, or laAy^ivN: (TA:) so also a tree. -A2- All~aAy^ivu (and All~ayovN, TA,) The lion: (K:) from lawovN “ strength. ” (TA.)

A^alowavu * A man slow, or tardy. (M.) ― -b2- diymapN lawovaA'u [A lasting, or continuous, and still, rain] that lays, or mixes, the plants, part upon part, (Lth, K, TA,) like as straw is mixed with the kind of trefoil called qat~: (Lth, TA:) but this explanation is disapproved by AM. (TA.) ― -b3- saHaAbapN lawovaA'u A slow cloud: such a cloud is the longest in raining. (AM.) ― -b4- A^alowavu Slow and heavy in tongue; (K;) slow in speech, and heavy in tongue: fem. lawovaA'u, [pl. luwtN]. (TA.) ― -b5- A man weak in mind, or understanding: from lawovN, as signifying “ weak, incomplete, evidence. ” (Msb.) ― -b6- A^alowavu, like A^avowalu, Stupid; foolish; of little sense; as also ↓ mulotaAvN: (TA:) stupid, foolish, or of little sense, and cowardly: pl. luwvN. (IAar.) ― -b7- Languid; flaccid: (S, K:) applied to a man. (S.) -A2- Strong; powerful; vigorous. Thus the word bears two contrary significations. (K.)

malaAvN * [A place of refuge; a refuge]. [You say,] A_in~ahu laniEoma AlmalaAvu lilD~iyfaAni Verily he is an excellent refuge for guests. (TA.) ― -b2- malaAvN (S, K) and ↓ milowavN (K) (tropical:) One who is a refuge to others; a noble chief; (TA;) a nobleman; (Ks, S, K;) whom others compass, and go round about: (Ks, S:) or so called because the command is [as it were] bound round him; i. e., because affairs are connected with him: (TA:) pl. malaAwivu and malaAwivapN and malaAwiyvu: (S, K:) the last used by poetic licence. (ISd.)
milowavN * : see malaAvN.
mulay~avN * A man (S) slow, or tardy, by reason of his fatness. (S, K.) [See also art. lyv.]

[
makaAnN mulaw~avN * and raA^osN mulaw~vN: see mulay~avN in art. lyv.]
mulotaAvN * : see A^alowavu.
1 laAjahu * , aor. yaluwju, (inf. n. lawojN, TA,) He turned it about in his mouth. (K.) ― -b2- [lAjt EynAh, His eyes rolled.]
2 lw~j binaA AlT~ariyqu * , inf. n. talowiyjN, The road became bending to us, or deviating from a straight course. (K.)

lawojaA'u * and ↓ luwayojaA'u [the latter the dim. of the former] A want; a thing wanted; an object of want: (TA:) from laAjahu as explained above. (K.) ― -b2- maA fiY Sadorihi HawojaA='u walaA lawojA='u A_il~aA qaDayotuhaA There was not a want in his bosom but I accomplished it. (TA.) ― -b3- maAliY fiyhi HawojaA='u walaA ↓ lawojaA='u walaA HuwayojaA='u walaA luwayojaA='u I have no want, [nor any little want,] with respect to him, or it. (Lh.) ― -b4- maAliY Ealayohi HiwajN walaA liwjN [I have no wants which it is incumbent upon him to supply: HawajN being a pl. of HaAjapN; and liwajN, irregularly, of lawojaA='u, in imitation of HiwajN]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also HawojaA='u, in three places.
luwayojaA'u * : see lawojaA'u.

1 laAHa * , aor. yaluwHu, inf. n. lawoHN, It (a thing) shone; gleamed; glistened. (S.) ― -b2- laAHa, (aor. yaluwHu, inf. n. lawoHN and luw^uwHN and lawaHaAnN; TA;) and ↓ AlAH; It (lightning) flashed slightly, not extending sideways in the adjacent tracts of cloud: (S, K:) or ↓ AlAH signifies it lighted up what surrounded it. (TA.) ― -b3- laAHa, (S, Msb,) aor. yaluwHu; (Msb;) inf. n. [lawoHN and] liyaAHN; (IAth;) It appeared: (IAth, Msb:) it (a star) appeared, (S, Msb,) as also ↓ AlAH, (S, K,) [it loomed,] and shone, gleamed, or glistened; (TA;) as also ↓ AlAH: (Msb, TA:) ISk says, laAHa suhayol Canopus appeared; (S;) and ↓ AlAH it shone and glistened. (S, K.) ― -b4- lAH, and ↓ AlAH, He (a man) came forth and became apparent. (A 'Obeyd.) ― -b5- laAHa liY A^amoruka, and ↓ tlw~H, (tropical:) Thine affair became apparent and manifest to me. (A.) ― -b6- laAHa Al$~ayobu fiY raA^osihi Hoariness appeared upon his head. (TA.) ― -b7- laAHahu, aor. yaluwHu, He saw him, or it. (K.) ― -b8- laAHa A_ilaY ka*aA, aor. yaluwHu, He looked at, or towards, such a thing; as a distant fire. (L.) ― -b9- laAHahu bibaSarihi, aor. yaluwHu, inf. n. lawoHapN, [so in the L,] He saw him, or it, and then he or it became concealed from him. (L.) ― -b10- See 4. -A2- laAHa, (S,) aor. yaluwHu, (TA,) inf. n. lawoHN (S, K,) and luwHN (K) and luwaAHN (S, K) and luw^uwHN and lawaHaAnN; (K;) and ↓ AltAH; (S, K;) He thirsted: (S, K;) or he thirsted in the slightest degree: (TA:) or he thirsted quickly. (Lh.) ― -b2- laAHahu, (aor. yaluwHu, inf. n. lawoHN, TA,) It (thirst, K, or travel, S, K, and cold, and disease or illness, and grief, TA,) altered him, (S, K,) and made him lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly; (TA;) as also ↓ lw~Hhu, (K,) inf. n. talowiyHN: or the latter signifies it (the heat of fire or of the sun) altered the colour of his skin: (TA:) or both verbs signify it parched, scorched, or burned, and blackened, his skin. (Zj.) Al$~amosu ↓ law~aHatohu The sun altered him, and scorched, i. e. slightly burned, and changed the colour of, his face; (S;) and in like manner fire, and the hot wind called samuwm; as also laAHatohu. (A.)
2 lw~H * , (inf. n. talowiyHN, TA,) He heated (S, K) a thing with fire. (S; see MA, and see 1.) ― -b2- lw~Hhu Al$~ayobu Hoariness altered him; (TA;) rendered him white. (K, TA.) ― -b3- See 1, and 4.

4 A^alowaHa See 1 throughout the first half. ― -b2- AlAH mina Al$~aYo'i, (inf. n. AlAHp, TA,) (tropical:) He (a man) was cautious and fearful of the thing. (S, K. *) -A2- AlAH bivawobihi, (L,) and bh ↓ lw~H, (Lh, S, L,) and bh ↓ lAH, (L,) (tropical:) He made a sign with his garment, (S, L,) from a distant place, taking the end of it in his hand, and waving it about, to make it seen by some one whom he desired to see it. (L.) AlAH bisayofihi; (S, K;) and bh ↓ lw~H, (K,) inf. n. talowiyHN; (TA:) (tropical:) He made a sign with his sword, (S, K,) and waved it, or moved it about, [for the purpose above mentioned]. (TA.) ― -b2- lw~H lilokalobi biragiyfK fatabiEahu (tropical:) He made a sign to the dog with a cake of bread, and he followed him. (A.) -A3- AlAH biHaq~aiYi He went away with, or took away, that which belonged to me. (ISk, S.) -A4- AlAHhu, (inf. n. A_ilaAHapN, TA,) He destroyed him or it. (S, K.)
8 A_ilotawaHa see 1.

10 AstlAH *
He sought, tried, or endeavoured, to see, syn. tabaS~ara, (K,) fiY AlA^amori into the affair, or thing. (TA.)

lawoHN *
A look; syn. naZorapN; [or rather a glance, or light or quick look;] like lamoHapN. (K.) -A2- See luwHN -A3- Any broad, or wide, and thin, thing, such as a board or plank or the like, of wood or of bone: (T, M, Msb, K:) pl. A^alowaAHN, and pl. pl. A^alaAwiyHu. (K.) A word of this kind has not a pl. of the measure A^afoEulN, because dammeh to the w is disliked. (Sb.) ― -b2- A^alowaAHN i. q. lawaAy^iHu, q. v.
― -b3- The scapula or shoulder-blade, (T, S, Msb, K,) when it is written upon, or inscribed. (T, Msb, K.) ― -b4- Any wide bone: (S, Msb:) or any bone of the body, except the bones called qaSab of the arms and legs. (Msb.) See also milowaAHN. ― -b5- lamo yaboqa minohu A_il~aA AlAlwAH (tropical:) There remained of him nothing but the wide bones. Said of one that is lean, or emaciated. (A.) ― -b6- lawoHu Alkatifi The smooth part of the shoulder-blade, where its projecting part (Eayor [so I read for gyr, in the L]) terminates, in the upper portion. (L.) ― -b7- lawoHN That [meaning a tablet] upon which one writes. (S.) ― -b8- katabonaA lahu fiY AlA^alowaAHi [We wrote for him upon the tablets, or tables]. (Kur vii. 142.) They are said to have been two tablets; but it is allowable to call two tablets AlwAH. (Zj.) ― -b9- All~awoHu AlmaHofuwZu, mentioned in the Kur, [chap. lxxxv. last verse, The Preserved, or Guarded, Tablet, whereon are said to be inscribed all the divine decrees;] (tropical:) the depository of the decrees, or willed events, ordained by God: (TA:) or i. q. A^um~u AlkitaAbi: or a light which appears to the angels, showing to them the things which they are commanded to do, and which they obey. (Msb.)

luwHN * (S, K) and ↓ lawoHN, (Lh, K,) but the former is of higher authority, (K,) and the latter is mentioned by none but Lh, (TA,) The air, or atmosphere, (S, K,) between heaven and earth: (S:) the air next to the higher part, or to the clouds, of the sky; syn. sukaAk: this is its meaning in the phrase laA A^afoEalu *`lika walawo nazawota fiY All~uwHi [I will not do that even if thou leap into the air next to the higher part, or to the clouds, of the sky]. (S.)

A_ibilN lawoHaY *
Thirsty camels. (S, K.)
layaAHN * : see liyaAHN.

$aYo'N liyaAHN * , (S, K,) and ↓ layaAHN, (K,) A white thing. (S.) The w is changed into Y because of the kesreh before it. (Fr, S.) layaAHN is extr.; for there is no reason for the change of the w therein into Y, unless for alleviation of the sound. (L.) ― -b2- Also liyaAHN and ↓ layaAHN Of a shining, or glistening, white hue. (L.) ― -b3- A^aboyaDu liyaAHN, and ↓ layaAHN, (tropical:) Intensely white. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also liyaAHN (S, K) and ↓ layaAHN (K) The wild bull: (S, K:) so called because of his whiteness. (S.) ― -b5- Also both words, The daybreak, or dawn: (K:) so called for the same reason. (TA.) ― -b6- laqiytuhu biliyaAHK I met him at the period of the afternoon called AlEaSor, when the sun was white. (L.)
law~aAHapN liloba$ari * , [Kur, lxxiv. 29, referring to saqaru,] Burning the [scarf-] skin so as to blacken it. (Zj.)

lawaAy^iHu $aYo'K * [pl. of laAy^iHapN] The parts of a thing that are apparent, and that show the signs thereof. (TA.) lawaAy^iHu and ↓ A^alowaAHN The external parts of a thing. (A.) lawaAHiY Al$~ayobi The apparent signs of hoariness, occurs in a verse of Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh, for lawaAy^iH Al$yb. (TA.) ― -b2- Als~ilaAHi ↓ A^alowaAHu Shining, gleaming, or glistening, weapons; such as the sword, (S, K,) end the like, (K,) and the spear-head; (S;) generally meaning swords, because of their whiteness: (ISd:) or, as some say, the cases, or receptacles, in which are the swords together with their scabbards and suspensory belts or strings, because made of boards. (IB.) 'Amr Ibn-Ahmar ElBáhilee says,
tumosiY kaA^alowaAHi Als~ilaAHi watuDo
HiY kaA@lomahaApi SabiyHapa AlqaTori
[In the evening she is like shining weapons, (so accord. to the S.) or like sword-cases, (accord. to IB,) and in the early part of the day, after sunrise, she is like the wild cow on the morning of, or after, rain]. IB says, that the poet means, in the evening she is lean, or slender, like a sword-case; but in the morning, like a wild cow, &c. (L.)
milowaHN * : see milowaAHN,

milowaAHN *
Large in the A^alowaAH, (K,) meaning [the shoulder-blades, or] any of the wide bones of the body: applied to a camel and to a man: (TA:) or having excellent and large AlwAH: (Sh, AHeyth:) and AlwAH is said to mean the *iraAEaAni [or two radii], the saAqaAni [or two tibiæ], and the EaDudaAni [or two humeri, or upper bones of the arms]. (TA.) ― -b2- Tall. (K.) ― -b3- Lean, lank, or light of flesh; or slender, or lank in the belly: (K:) applied alike to a man and a woman: also, a beast of carriage that becomes so quickly: (TA:) also, a woman that quickly becomes lean, or emaciated: (K:) pl. malaAwiyHu. (TA.) ― -b4- milowaAHN A beast (S) that quickly becomes thirsty; (S, K;) as also ↓ milowaHN (K) and miloyaAHN; (IAar, K;) the last extr., as though the w were changed into Y because of the kesreh which is near before it, and as though they had imagined a kesreh to the l. (ISd.) ― -b5- riyHN milowaAHN [A very thirsty wind]. (TA, voce nakobaA='u.) -A2- [A kind of decoy-bird. See raAmiqN.]
miloyaAHN * : see milowaAHN.

mulaw~aHN *
Altered by fire, or by the sun, or by travel, [&c.]: an arrow, before it is furnished with feathers and a head, altered by fire; and in like manner the iron head of an arrow or of a spear, or the like: (TA:) also ↓ mulotaAHN altered (K) by the sun, or by travel, &c. (TA.)
mulotaAHN * : see mulaw~aHN.

1 laA*a bihi * , aor. yaluw*u, (S, A, L, Msb,) inf. n. lawo*N (S, L, K) and liyaA*N (S, A, L, K) and liwaA*N (L, Msb, K) and lawaA*N and luwaA*N, (Msb, K,) He had recourse to it, (a mountain [&c.], Msb,) or him, for refuge or protection or preservation; (S, A, L, Msb;) as also bh ↓ lAw*, inf. n. liwaA*N; (A;) and bh ↓ AlA*; (Msb;) sought, or took, refuge in it, or him; (S, L;) and joined himself to him; and sought, desired, implored, or called for, aid, or succour, of him: (L:) he protected, concealed, defended, or fortified himself by it, (L, K,) or him; (L;) as also bh ↓ lAw*, (L,) inf. n. mulaAwa*apN (L, K) and liwaA*N; (L;) and ↓ AlA*. (L.) ― -b2- laA*a bihi, (L,) inf. n. as above, in the commencement of the art., (K,) It encompassed, or surrounded, it; (L, K; *) as also ↓ AlA*, (L,) inf. n. A_ilaA*apN. (L, K.) You say, laA*a AlT~ariyqu biAld~aAri, and ↓ AlA*, The road encompassed, or surrounded, the house: (L:) or, reached, or extended, to the house: (Msb:) and laA*ati Ald~aAru biAlT~ariyqi The house encompassed, or surrounded, the road. (L.) See also 3. ― -b3- laA*a biAlqawomi and bihim ↓ AlA*, He laboured, or strove, to overcome the people in any way; expl. by the words hY AlmdAwrp mn Hyv mAkAn. (T, L.) [Perhaps AlmdAwrp is a mistake for AlmudaAraAp; see 3: the same phrases being explained in the M by daAarAhumo: but there is a near resemblance between the significations of AlmdAwrp and AlmdArAp.]

3 lAw* Alqawomu * , (S, L,) inf. n. mulaAwa*apN and liwaA*N, (S, L, K,) with which talowaA*N is syn., (K,) The people had recourse, one to another, for refuge or protection or preservation; sought, or took, refuge, one in another; protected, concealed, defended, or fortified, themselves, one by another. (S, L, K. *) Agreeably with this explanation, (as some say, L,) liwaA*FA is used in the Kur, xxiv. 63: were it from laA*a, it would be liyaA*FA. (S, L.) ― -b2- See 1. ― -b3- lAw* bihimo, inf. n. mulaAwa*apN, He went round about them, or encompassed them. (Msb.) See also 1. ― -b4- lAw*hu, (M, L,) inf. n. mulaAwa*apN (K) and liwaA*N, (M, L, K,) He circumvented, or deluded, him; (M, L, K; *) syn. raAwagahu (M, L) inf. n. muraAwagapN. (K.) ― -b5- lAw*humo (M, L) and bihimo ↓ laA*a, and ↓ AlA*, (M,) He wheedled, beguiled, or deluded, them; syn. daAraAhumo. (M, L.) lAw* He eluded, and shunned, or avoided, thee: syn. raAga Eanoka, and HaAda Agreeably with this explanation, or as signifying mrAwgp, some render liwaA*FA in the Kur, xxiv. 63. (Ibn-Is-Seed, TA.) ― -b6- lAw*hu, (TK,) inf. n. mulaAwa*apN
(K) and liwaA*N, (L, K,) He acted contrarily to, or differently from, or adversely to, him; was, or became contrary to, or different from, or adverse to, him; (L, * K, * TK;) syn. xaAlafahu, (TK,) inf. n. xilaAfN. (L, K.) Agreeably with this explanation, Zj renders liwaA*FA in the Kur, xxiv. 63; saying that the meaning which he thus assigns to it is shown to be the true one by the words immediately following. (L.)

4 A^alowa*a see 1: ― -b2- and 3. ― -b3- AlA* bihi gayorahu [He caused another to have recourse to him or it for refuge or protection or preservation; to seek, or take, refuge in him or it; to protect, conceal, defend, or fortify, himself by him or it: or he protected, concealed, defended, or fortified, another by means of him or it]. (A.) ― -b4- AlA*t Aln~aAqapu AlZ~il~a bixuf~ihaA (tropical:) [The she-camel covered, or concealed, the shade with her foot]; meaning that the time of noonday-heat was come. (A.)

lawo*N * The side of a mountain; and its circuit: pl. A^lowaA*N. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- A side, or lateral part or tract, of a country or region: (A:) and of a thing; (TA;) as also ↓ lawo*aAnN: (K:) pl. as above. (A.) ― -b3- A place of bending of a valley: pl. as above. (L, K.) ― -b4- huwa bilawo*i ka*aA, and ka*aA ↓ bilawo*aAni, He, or it, is in the side of, or part adjacent to, such a place or thing. (L.) ― -b5- huwa lawo*ahu He is near to him or it. (L.)
lawo*aAnN * : see lawo*N.
lawo*aAniy~apN * , (as in some copies of the K,) or lawa*aAniy~apN, (as in others and in the TA,) Circumvention; delusion; syn. muraAwagapN. (K.) See 3.

malaA*N * and ↓ milowa*apN [the latter thus in the K and accord. to the TA; but in the TT, malowa*ap; and in the L, without the first vowel-sign;] A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, or concealment; a place of refuge; a refuge; (TA;) a fortress; a fortified place; a castle. (L, K.)
mialowa*apN * : see malaA*N.

xayorN mulaAwi*N * (tropical:) Little good: (S:) or good that comes not save after severe toil or labour: occurring in a verse of El-Katámee: you say, xayoru baniY fulaAnK mulaAwi*N The good of the sons of such a one comes not save after severe toil or trouble to procure it. (ISk, T, L.)
talowaA*N * : see 3.

lawozN * [The almond; or almonds;] the fruit of a certain tree; (Msb, TA;) well known; (A, Msb, K;) abundant in the countries of the Arabs; said by some to be a species of mizoj, which is that whereof the edible part is not attained save by breaking; by others said to be bruised, or brayed, mizoj; and also called qumoruwSN: it is of two kinds, sweet and bitter: (TA:) the sweet is of moderate temperature, beneficial to the chest and the lungs and the bladder, (by reason of its soft nature, TA,) and the eating thereof, shelled, with sugar, augments the marrow and brain, and fattens: the bitter is hot in the third degree, opens stoppages of the nose, clears away [the spots in the skin called] nama$, and stills pain, (K [but omitted in the CK] and TA,) when it [app. meaning its oil] is drunk, and when dropped into the ear; (TA;) and it relaxes the bowels, and causes sleep, (K, TA,) when the soles of the feet are anointed with it, and when it is introduced into the nose; (TA;) and it is diuretic: (K, TA:) it is an Arabic word: (Msb, TA:) a coll. gen. n.: (TA:) n. un. with p. (S, Msb, K.) -A2- [Hence,] All~awozataAni (tropical:) [The amygdalæ of the fauces; also called the tonsils;] two pieces of flesh in the two sides of the fauces. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The two sockets of the hips, where the heads of the thigh-bones are inserted. (A, TS, TA.)
law~aAzN * A seller of lawoz [or almonds]. (K.)

A^aroDN malaAzapN *
Land containing, (S, M,) or abounding with, (A, K,) trees of the lawoz [or almond]. (S, M, A, K.)

tamorN mulaw~azN *
Dates stuffed with lawoz [or almonds]; (Sgh, K;) the stones being taken out and lawoz put in their place. (TA.)
laA$a * an abbreviation of laA$aYo'a [Nothing]. It is generally used coupled, or connected, with a word of similar form; as in the saying AlmaA$u xayorN mino laA$a, which see in art. mw$. (TA.)
1 laASa * , intrans.: see 3. -A2- laASahu biEayonihi: see 3. -A3- laASa Eani AlA^amori He turned aside, or away, from the thing, or affair; he declined from it; he avoided it. (Aboo-Turáb, K. *)

3 lAwS * , (K,) inf. n. mulaAwaSapN, (M,) He looked to the right and left as though he desired, or sought, a thing: (M:) or he looked as though he were deceiving, or beguiling, to seek to obtain, or attain, a thing; (Lth, K;) as also ↓ laASa, inf. n. lawoSN. (Lth.) -A2- lAwShu biEayonihi, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above, (M, A, K,) He looked, (M,) or glanced, (A, K,) at him, or it, from the interstice of a door, (M, A, K,) and the like, (A, K,) or of a curtain; (M;) as also ↓ laASahu, (M,) inf. n. lawoSN: (M, A, K:) or the former verb has the signification here first given. (M.) ― -b2- lAwS Al$~ajara He looked (S, A, K) to the right and left (A, K) to see how he might come to the trees, (S, K,) to pull them up, or out, (S,) or to cut them with the axe, and to see how he might strike them, (K,) or to see how he might cut them. (A.) ― -b3- And hence, laAwaSaniY fulaAnu Eano ka*aA Such a one endeavoured to turn me by deceit, or guile, from such a thing. (A.) [Hence also,] maA zilotu A^ulaAwiSuhu Eano ka*aA, (M,) and Eanohu ↓ A^uliySuhu, (M, TA,) I ceased not to endeavour to turn him from such a thing; i. e. to endeavour to induce him to leave, or relinquish, such a thing; syn. A^udyruhu Eanohu: (M, TA:) and EalaY ka*aA ↓ A^ulaASahu, (S, K,) and laAwaSahu Ealayohi, (M, K, art. dwr,) he endeavoured to turn him to, or induce him to do, such a thing, (A^adaArahu Ealayohi,) desiring, or seeking, it of him. (S, K.) Hence the saying of 'Omar to 'Othmán, respecting the sentence declaratory of belief in the unity of God, (TA,) ↓ hiYa Alkalimapu A@l~atiY A^alaASa EalayohaA Aln~abiY~u Sal~aY A@ll~`hu Ealayohi wasal~ama Eam~ahu (S, TA) It is the sentence which the Prophet (God bless and save him) endeavoured to induce and entice his uncle to utter; (TA;) meaning Aboo-Tálib, (S, TA,) when dying. (TA.) And hence the phrase in another trad., EalaY xaloEihi ↓ wa A_in~aka latulaASu And verily thou wilt be urged with enticement, and solicited, to divest thyself of it. (TA.) [Said by Mohammad to 'Othmán. See the preceding words of the trad. voce qam~aSa.] You say also, A^ano A=xu*a minohu $ayoy^FA ↓ A^alaSotu, inf. n. A_ilaASapN, I desired to take from him, or of it, something; (M, * K, TA; [but in a copy of the M, in the place of A^aradotu, I find A^adarotu, which I regard as a mistranscription;]) as also A^anaSotu, inf. n. A_inaASapN. (L, TA.)
4 A^alowaSa see 3, in five places.

rajulN mulaAwiSN *
A man who behaves in a loving, or affectionate, and blandishing, or coaxing, and deceitful, or beguiling, manner. (A, TA.)

1 laATa bihi * , aor. yaluwTu, inf. n. lawoTN; (Msb, TA;) and aor. yaliyTu, inf. n. layoTN; (TA;) It (a thing, Msb, or anything, TA) clave, stuck, or adhered, to it. (Msb, TA.) You say, laATa Al$~aYo'u biqalobiY, aor. yaluwTu and yaliyTu, (Ks, S, K,) inf. n. lawoTN and layoTN, (K,) and liyaATN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The thing was rendered an object of love, and made to cleave, to my heart: (Ks, * S, * K, TA:) it clave to my heart; (TA;) as also bqlbY ↓ AltAT. (K, TA.) And h`*aA AlA^amoru laA yaliyTu biSafariY, (TA,) and ↓ laA yalotaATu biSafariY, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) This thing, or affair, does not cleave to my heart. (S, TA.) And ↓ laA yalotaATu biSafariY (tropical:) I do not love him, or it. (TA.) And
it is said in a trad., bivalaAvK ↓ mano A^aHab~a Al*~unoyaA A@lotaATa $ugolK laA yanoqaDiY waA^amalK laA yudoraku waHiroSK laA yanoqaTiEu (assumed tropical:) [He who loves the present world cleaves to three things; occupation that will not end, and hope that will not be attained, and inordinate desire that will not cease]. (TA.) ― -b2- laATa fiY AlA^amori, inf. n. laATN, (Sgh, K,) accord. to Lth., and if correct, like qaAlN in the sense of qawolN, (Sgh,) (assumed tropical:) He was importunate in, or with respect to, the affair: (Lth, Sgh, K:) because he who is so usually cleaves, or adheres. (TA.) ― -b3- laATa biHaq~ihi (assumed tropical:) He went away with, or took away, his right, or due. (TA.) ― -b4- laATahu, inf. n. lawoTN, He stuck it; made it to cleave, stick, or adhere; as also ↓ AlAThu, inf. n. A_ilaATapN; and ly~Thu. (TA.) ― -b5- [See also laATa in art. lyT.] ― -b6- laATa AlHawoDa, (K,) or laATa AlHawoDa biAlT~iyni, (S,) and laATa biAlHawoDi, (K,) accord. to Lh, but not known to ISd on any other authority, and deemed by him extr., (TA,) inf. n. lawoTN, (S,) He plastered the watering-trough, (S, K, TA,) and repaired it, and made it smooth, (TA,) with mud, or clay. (S, K, TA.) ― -b7- It is said in a trad., kaAnato banuw A_isoraAy^iyla ya$orabuwna fiY Alt~iyhi maA laATuwA, meaning [The children of Israel used to drink, in the desert,] what they collected, in the watering-troughs, from the wells. (TA.) -A2- laATa, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaluwTu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. lawaATN, (TA,) or lawaATapN with p; (Msb;) and ↓ lAwT, (S, K,) [inf. n., app., liwaATN and liyaATN, for it is said in the TA that liyaATN is syn. with liwaATN;] and ↓ tlw~T; (K;) He committed the act of the people of luwT [or Lot]; he did that which is excessively foul, like as the people of lwT did. (Msb.)

2 lw~Thu biAlT~iybi *
He smeared him, or it, much with perfume. (TA.)
3 laAowaTa see 1, last sentence.
4 A^alowaTa see 1.
5 talaw~aTa see 1, last sentence.
8 AltAT * : see 1, in four places. -A2- AltAThu: see 10. ― -b2- AlnAT HawoSahu He plastered with mud, or clay, for himself, his watering-trough. (K.)

10 AstlATwhu *
They made him to cleave, stick, or adhere, to themselves; they attached him to, or connected him with, themselves. (S.) ― -b2- AstlAThu He claimed him as a son, he not being his; as also ↓ AltAThu. (K.) ― -b3- AstlAT damahu He had a right, or just title or claim, to his blood; syn. Astwjbhu, (S, * TA,) and AstHq~hu. (TA.) ― -b4- AstlATwA They committed sins for which he who should punish them would be excusable, because they deserved punishment; as also AisotaHaq~uwA, and A^awojabuwA, and A^aEo*aruwA. (IAar.)

lawoTN * A thing cleaving, sticking, or adhering: an inf. n. used as an epithet. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] A_in~iY laA^ajidu lahu fiY qalobiY lawoTFA (assumed tropical:) Verily I feel for him, in my heart, a love cleaving thereto; as also layoTFA; (S, TA;) and ↓ lawoTapF; and ↓ luwTapF. (Lh, Kr.)
lawTapN * and luwTapN: see lawoTN.

[
luwTiY~N *
One who is addicted to the crime of the people of Lot; as also ↓ law~aATN: both used in this sense in the present day; but perhaps postclassical.]
luwTiy~apN * [The crime of the people of Lot]: a subst. from laATa in the last of the sense explained above: occurring in a trad. (TA.)

liyaATN * [originally liwaATN] Quick lime, or the like; syn. kilosN: and gypsum: (K:) because water-ing-troughs, &c. are plastered therewith. (TA.) ― -b2- And, (as being likened thereto, TA,) (tropical:) Human ordure; or thin human ordure; syn. saloHN. (K.)

[
law~aATN * : see luwTiY~N.]
huwa A^alowaTu biqalobiY * , (S,) and A^alowaTu alone, (A'Obeyd,) (assumed tropical:) He is more, or most, closely cleaving to my heart; (A'Obeyd, S; *) as also A^aloyaTu. (S.)

4 AlyA^t Aln~aAqapu *
The she-camel was slow. (K.)

liyaA='N *
A kind of white grain, resembling the Him~iS [or cicer arietinum], (K,) intensely white, which is eaten. (AHn says, I know not whether it [the plant] have, or have not, qTny~p [q. v.]. (TA.)

layaAbN *
A quantity of food less than what fills the mouth: (IAar, K:) or a spoonful, that is chewed, or to be chewed. (K, and said to be on the authority of IAar.) Mentioned by IM in art. lwb, and again in the present art. (TA.)

1 laAtahu * , aor. yalyitu, (inf. n. layotN, S,) as also laAtapu, aor. yaluwtu; or laAtahu Eano wajohihi; as also ↓ A^alaAtahu; (and A^alatahu; S, K, art. A^alt;) He withheld him, or restrained him, and turned him, or averted him, from his course, purpose, or object. (S, K.) The Rájiz says,
walayolapK *aAti dujFA sarayotu
walamo yalitoniY Eano suraAhaA layotu
[During many a dark night (or many a rainy, or wet, night, accord. to the reading in the TA, namely *At nadFY) have I journeyed;] and no hindrance hindered me from journeying during it: (S:) or the meaning is ― -b2- and no averting thing averted me, &c.; layotu being put for laAy^itu: or, nothing made me to repent, and say, layotaniY maA sarayotuhaA Would that I had not journeyed during it! or, no deficiency, nor any impotence, averted me, &c., accord. to the T. (TA.) ― -b3- laAtahu Haq~ahu, aor. yaliytu, inf. n. layotN; and ↓ A^alaAtahu; but the former is the more approved; as also A^alaAtahu and A^alithu; He diminished unto him his due, or right: [or defrauded him of part thereof.]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [xlix. 14,] laAyalitokumo mino A^aEomaAlikumo $ayoy^FA He will not diminish unto you, nor defraud you of, aught [of the reward] of your works. (Fr, Zj.) ― -b4- maA A^alaAnahu $ayoy^FA; as also maA A^alatahu (and maA A^altahu; TA;) He did not diminish unto him aught. (Fr, S, K.) In maA A^alatonaAhumo mino Eamalihimo mino $aYo'K, in the Kur, [lii. 21, q. v. in art. A^lt.] the verb may be from A^alata or from A^alaAta. (TA.) ― -b5- AlHaq~a ↓ bit~u A^uliytu in a verse of 'Orweh Ibn-El-Ward, signifies A^uHiyluhu and A^uSorifuhu [I passed the night putting away (from my mind the thought of) death: the poet having just before mentioned the death of certain of his camels]. (Sh, L.) ― -b6- In the following saying, AlHamodu lil~`hi Al~a*iY laA yufaAtu walaA yalaAtu walaA ta$otabihu Ealayohi AlA^aSowaAtu [Praise be to God, whom nothing will escape, (lit., who will not be escaped, see Kur xxxiv. 50, and 1 in art. fwt,) and —, and to whom voices will not be confused, or undistinguishable, one from another!], lA ylAt is from A^alaAta, a dial. var. of laAta, aor. yliytu, in the sense of naqaSa, and signifies unto whom one cannot diminish [aught that is his due], and whom prayer cannot be hindered from reaching: so accord. to IAar: or, accord. to Khálid Ibn Jembeh, upon whom nothing that any one saith can have any power; (expl. by lA yA^xd fyh
qwl qAy^l;) i. e., who obeyeth no one. (L.) ― -b7- laAta $ayoAF, aor. yaliytu, He concealed a thing that he knew, and told, or narrated, something different from it. (TA, art. lwv, q. v.) ― -b8- laAtahu, aor. yaliytu, inf. n. layotN, He expressed to him the news, or information, obscurely, or enigmatically, or obscured it to him, or concealed it from him: so accord. to As, and the like is said in the L: but accord. to some, the verb is laAtahu, aor. yaluwtu, q. v., in art. lwt. (TA, art. lwt) ― -b9- walaAta Hiyna manaASK, occurring in the Kur, [xxxviii. 2,] (S,) [there meaning, accord. to the general opinion, When (it, or the time,) was not a time of flight: in other cases, and (it, or the time,) is, or was, not a time of flight]. lAt is here likened to layosa; and the name of the agent is understood. (S, K.) So says Akh, accord. to J; but this is the opinion of Sb: so in the margin of some copies of the S. (TA.) Or lAt is originally lA; and the t is added, as in vum~ata [in the CK, vam~at,] (El-Muärrij, S, K,) and rub~ata. (El-Muärrij, S.) ― -b10- With respect to the proper meaning and etymology of lAt there are four opinions. First, that it is a single word, a verb in the pret. tense: and some say, that it is originally laAta in the sense of naqaSa, and afterwards used as a negative, like qal~a: so says Aboo-Dharr El-Khushanee, in his Expos. of the Book of Sb: others, that it is originally layisa; that its s is changed into t, and then the Y into A, because it is movent and preceded by fet-hah: so says Abu-r-Rabeea. Second, that it is two words, the negative lA, with the fem. t, added to make the word fem., as say IHsh and Er-Radee, or to render the negation more intensive, as is said in the Expos. of the Katr by the author of the latter work: and this is the general opinion. Third, that it is an independent word, not originally lys nor lA; as related by the sheykh Aboo-Is- hák Esh-Shátibee alone. Fourth, that it is a word and a part of a word, namely the negative lA, and t prefixed to Hyn; which opinion is ascribed to A'Obeyd [as is mentioned in the S] and Ibn-El-Taráweh: the former of whom argues in favour of this opinion from the fact that t is found so prefixed in Othmán's copy of the Kur-án; but this is no proof, because there are found in the writing of that copy things at variance with analogy. (TA.) taHiyna [however] occurs, without lAt, in the following verse of Aboo-Wejzeh:
AlEaATifuwna taHiyna maA mino EaATifK
waAlmuToEimuwna zamaAna A^ayona AlmuToEimu
[The persons who act affectionately in the time when there is none (other) that acts affectionately; and the feeders in the time when (it is said) Where is the feeder?] (S.) The general opinion is favoured by the following facts: that lAt is pronounced in a case of pause laAto and laAho: that it is written separately from Hyn: and that it is sometimes written laAti, with kesreh to the t, as is mentioned by Z, agreeably with the fundamental rule with respect to the concurrence of two quiescent letters [when followed by a conjunctive A]; whereas, were it a verb in the pret. tense, there would be no reason for its being written with kesreh: it is also written laAtu, with dammeh to the t: and both these variations occur in readings of the Kur-án: but laAta, with fet-hah to the t, is the most common. (TA.) ― -b11- With respect to its government there are also four opinions. First, that it has no government: that if a noun in the nom. case follow it, it is put in that case as an inchoative of which [as is mentioned in the S] the enunciative is suppressed; and that if a noun in the acc. case follow it, it is put in that case as an objective complement of a verb suppressed; which is the opinion of Akh; the meaning of lAt Hyn mnAS being, in the former case, lAHiynu manaASK kaAy^inN lahumo [A place of flight not existing for them; which does not imply that there was none for others; as lA here has the force of a particular, not a general, negation]; and in the latter case, the meaning being, laA A^araY Hiyna manaASK [I see not a time of flight]. Second, that it governs in the same manner as A_in~a; which is another opinion of Akh and the Koofees. Third, that it is a particle governing the gen. case; an opinion ascribed to Fr by Er-Radee and IHsh and others. Fourth, that it governs like layosa; and this is the general opinion; but IHsh restricts it by two conditions; that the two nouns which it governs must be significant of time, and that one of them must be suppressed. (TA.) [It is generally the subject, rarely the predicate, that is suppressed.] ― -b12- lAt [when it has grammatical government] does not occur without Hyn [or, as many say, some word syn. therewith, as waqot, &c.]. (S, K.) So says Akh, accord. to J; but this is the assertion of Sb; because the latter holds it to have the same government as lys; whereas Akh assigns to it no government [as explained above]. (IB.) But [it is said that] Hyn is sometimes suppressed, (in poetry, S, [or in prose,]) though meant to be understood; as in the following saying of Mázin Ibn-Málik, [respecting 'Abd-Shems, surnamed Makrooa, the son of Saad the son of Zeyd-Menáh the son of Temeem, and respecting Heyjumáneh the daughter of El-'Ambar the son of 'Amr the son of Temeem, (S, art. qrE,) who was enamoured of Makrooa,] waHan~ato walaAta han~ato waA^an~aY laki maqoruwEN [And she conceived a longing desire; but it was not a time for her conceiving such a desire. And how (O Heyjumáneh) should Makrooa be thine? See Freytag, Arab. Prov. i. 343 and ii. 525.] (S, K.) This, however, is said to be not poetry but a prose-example. (TA.) Moreover, it is observed, that lAt, in this instance, has no government, and that a word signifying time is not meant to be understood after it: [so that the meaning is, And she conceived a longing desire, but it was as though she did not conceive such a desire:] (MF.) for when lAt has government, the subject and predicate cannot both be suppressed. (AHei, MF.)
4 A^aloyata see 1.

layota * a word denoting a wish [signifying Would that —; I wish that —;] (S, K;) generally relating to a thing that is impossible; rarely to a thing that is possible: (IHsh, K:) governing the subject in the acc. case, and the predicate in the nom. case, (S, K,) like kaA^an~a (or [rather] A_in~a, MF) and its coordinates, because it resembles verbs in their force as words, [being composed of at least three letters, and the last being meftoohah,] and in their admitting most of the pronouns as affixes, and in their meanings. (S.) Ex. layota zayodFA *aAhibN [Would that Zeyd were going;] (S;) and layotaniY faEalotu ka*aA waka*aA [Would that I had done so and so.] (TA.) You say layotiY as well as layotaniY, (S, K,) like laEal~iY and laEal~aniY, and A_in~iY and A_in~aniY: (S:) but lytnY is more common than lytY; whereas lEl~nY is less common than lEl~Y. (TA.) You also say yaA layota O, would that —;.] As to the saying of the poet,
yaA layota A^ay~aAma AlS~ibaA rawaAjiEaA
meaning lanaA rawaAjiEa, [O, would that the days of youth were returning (to us)!] rwAjE is put in the acc. case therein as a word descriptive of state: (S:) or it is governed in the acc. case by a verb understood, as A^aqobalato, or EaAdato, or some other verb suitable to the meaning: so says Sb: (TA:) or lyt in the above verse may be used in the manner of wajadotu, [see below], (S,) for lyt is sometimes used in the manner of wajadotu [I found], (Fr, S, K,) in government, not in meaning, (MF,) as related by the grammarians on the authority of certain of the Arabs, so that it is doubly transitive, and used in the manner of verbs: (S:) you say, layota zayodFA $aAxiSFA [Would that Zeyd were going away, &c.]: (S, K:) this is done to give intensiveness: one says, for this purpose, layota zayodFA qaAy^imFA (Would that Zeyd were standing) putting both the subject and the predicate in the acc. case. (Msb.) ― -b2- layotamaA: see De Sacy's Gr. Ar. ii. 63. ― -b3- See also an ex. of lyt as a subst. voce sawofa.

liytN * The side of the neck: (S, K:) or the lytaAni are the lower parts of the two sides of the neck, upon which the earrings hang down, behind the two projections of the jaw-bones that are beneath the ear: or the parts of the neck beneath the
earrings: or the places upon which the cuppinginstrument is applied; AlmaHojamataAni: pl. A^aloyaAtN and lytp [but whether the latter be liytapN or liyatapN is not shown]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aSogaY liytFA He inclined the side of his neck. (TA, from a trad.)

2 ly~v *
He became related to the Benoo-Leyth. (A.) [See also 5.]

3 laAyavapu *
He did, acted, or dealt, with him in the manner of the lion: or he contended with him for the glory of resembling the lion. (S.) ― -b2- He parted, or separated himself, from him; syn. zaAyalahu. (TA.)

5 tly~v * and ↓ lay~ava and luy~iva He (a man, TA,) became like the Benoo-Leyth, or, like a lion, in desire; expl. by SaAra layoviY~a AlhawaY; (K;) and in zeal in the cause of his party: (TA:) he became like a lion; as also ↓ A_isotaloyava. (L.)
10 A_isotaloyava see 5.

layovN *
Strength: [like lawovN]. (TA.) ― -b2- All~ayovu (S, K) and ↓ All~aAy^ivu (K) The lion: (S, K:) said to be from layovN as signifying “ strength ”: accord. to Kr, from lawovN, as signifying the same: ISd says, that, if so, the Y is changed from w; but that this is not a valid opinion: yet Suh and several others agree with Kr: pl. luyuwvN, and, as some say, maloyavapN, like ma$oyaxapN and masoyafapN: (TA:) fem. layovapN; pl. layovaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b3- layovu Eifir~iyna The lion: (AA, S:) or an animal like the chameleon, that opposes itself to the rider; so called in reference to Efr~yn, the name of a town or district. (As, S.) One says A_in~ahu laA^a$ojaEu mino layovi Eifir~iyna [Verily he is more courageous than the lion, &c.] (S.) [See also art. Efr.] ― -b4- See A^aloyavu. ― -b5- layovN Eloquent: (K:) strong in dispute: in the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.) ― -b6- All~ayovu also A certain kind of spider, (S, K,) that hunts flies by leaping, or springing: (S:) a certain kind of spider [surpassed, or equalled, by] no beast, or creeping thing, in acuteness, and circumvention, and in leaping, or springing, with correct aim, and in rapidity of snatching, and in dissimulation; that catches flies: ('Amr Ibn-Bahr:) or the spider, AlEanokabuwt: (Lth:) or [a reptile] smaller than the Enkbwt, that catches flies. (TA.) -A2- layovN A land's having dry herbage, and being rained upon, and producing fresh herbage, so that half of it is green, and half of it yellow. (TA.)
liyvN * , signifying A certain plant that winds about, belongs to art. lwv, q. v. (TA.)
layovapN * A strong she-camel. (K.) See lawvapN.
layoviY~N * [Of, or belonging to, or resembling, a lion. (K.)
layaAvapN * : see luyuwvapN.
luyuwvapN * and ↓ layaAvapN [Lion-like courage]. (TA.)
lay~ivN * and lay~ivapN: see art. lwv.

A^aloyavu *
Courageous: pl. liyvN: (IAar, K:) as also ↓ layovN. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aloyavu Stronger, and more hardy: or strongest, and most hardy. (TA, from a trad.)
All~aAy^ivu * : see layovN.
miloyavN * [accord. to the K and TA; but in the L, ↓ mly~v;] Strong; powerful: (K:) or very hard; syn. $adiydu AlEArDp. (L.)

mulay~avN * : see miloyavN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A strong stallion; likened to a lion. (A.) ― -b3- mulay~abN Fat, and broken, or trained, to obedience; syn. samiynN mu*al~alN. (TS, K.) [See also art. lwv.] ― -b4- makaAnN mulay~avN, as also mulaw~avN, A place having dry herbage, and being rained upon, and producing fresh herbage, so that half of it is green, and half of it yellow. (TA.) ― -b5- raA^osN mulay~avN, as also mulaw~avN, A head of which part of the hair is black, and part white. (TA.)
mulay~iyvN * [A camel] full [of flesh, and] abounding with wabar, or wool. (TS, K.)

1 layosa * a word denoting negation: (S, A, K:) it is a verb in the pret. tense, (S, A, K, Mughnee,) having no other tense, (Sb, S, M, Msb, Mughnee,) nor a part. n. nor an inf. n.; (Sb, M, Msb; *) of the measure faEila; (Mughnee;) originally layisa, from which it is contracted by the suppression of a vowel, (Sb, * S, M, * K, Mughnee, *) being found difficult of pronunciation, (S,) [i. e.,] to render it easy to pronounce, (K,) like Ealoma for Ealima, (Sb, M,) the Y not being changed into A (Sb, S, M) because it is imperfectly inflected, being used in the pret. form for the present, (S,) [i. e.,] because it has no future, nor part. n., nor inf. n., nor derivation, wherefore, not being perfectly inflected like its coordinates, it is made like that which is not a verb, as layota: (Sb, M:) what shows it to be a verb, (S, Mughnee,) not a particle occupying the place of maA, as Ibn-Es-Sarráj and some others after him have asserted, (Mughnee,) though not perfectly inflected like [other] verbs, (S,) is their saying lasota and lasotumaA (S, Mughnee) and lasotumo (S) and layosaA and layosuwA and layosato [&c.], (Mughnee,) like as they say Darabota and DarabotumaA and Darabotumo [&c.]: (S:) we have not determined its measure to be faEala, because this is not contracted; nor faEula, because there is no verb of this measure with Y for its medial radical letter, except hayuw^a; but lusota has been heard; so, accord. to this form, it may be like hayuw^a: (Mughnee:) the Benoo-Dabbeh say lusotu and lusonaA in the sense of lasotu and lasonaA; and some of them say lisotu: (TA, art. lws:) but Sb says, that the Arabs did not say lisota, like as they said xifota, because lys is not perfectly inflected like [other] verbs. (M.) [There is also another opinion respecting its origin, which will be mentioned in the course of this article.] It [is generally a particular (not a universal) negative, and] denotes the negation of a thing at the present time; (M, Mughnee;) [i. e.] it denotes [thus] the negation of its predicate: (Msb:) and has the same government as the verbkaAna and its coordinates; (S;) governing the subject in the nom., and the predicate in the accus.: (S, Mughnee:) as when you say, layosa zayodN qaAy^imFA [Zeyd is not a person standing]: (Msb:) and by means of the context, it denotes the negation of a thing at a time not the present; as in the saying of El-Aashà [respecting Mohammad],
lahu naAfilaAtN maA yugib~u nawaAluhaA
walayosa EaTaA='u Alyawomi maAniEahu gadaA
[He has bounties the bestowing of which is not on alternate days; and the giving of to-day will not be a preventer of it to-morrow]; and [sometimes when it is followed by a verb, as] in the saying, layosa xalaqa A@ll~`hu mivolahu [God has not created the like of him, or it.] (Mughnee.) But it differs from its coordinates in that the prep. bi may be prefixed to its predicate: as in the saying, layosa zayodN bimunoTaliqK [Zeyd is not going away]; the b being a means of the verb's being trans., and also corroborative of the negation: and one may optionally not introduce it, because one may do without the corroborative, and because some verbs are trans. sometimes by means of a prep. and sometimes without a prep., as Ai$otaqotuka and Ai$otaqotu A_ilayoka. (S.) It also differs from its coordinates in that its predicate may not be put before it: for you may say muHosinFA kaAna zayodN, but not muHosinFA layosa zayodN: (S:) or some allow this latter; but others disallow it. (Ibn- 'Akeel on the Alfeeyeh, section on kAn and its coordinates.) It is also used as an exceptive particle, (S, M, Mughnee,) in the place of A_il~aA; (S, Mughnee;) in which case [also] its subject [which is understood] is in the nom. case, and its predicate in the accus.: (S:) you say, jaA='aniY Alqawomu layosa zayodFA [The company of men came to me, except Zeyd]; as though you said, layosa AljaAy^iY
zayodFA. (S, M: but in the latter, instead of jA'nY, we find A^ataY; and instead of AljAy^Y, we find AlA=tiY.) You may also say, jaA='aniY Alqawomu layosaka [The company of men came to me, excepting thee]; but the separate pronoun, A_iy~aAka, is here better. (S.) When the predicate after it is connected with A_il~aA, as in the ex. here next following, Benoo-Temeem make it in the nom. case: thus they say, layosa AlT~iybu A_il~aA Almisoku [It is not perfume, except musk; meaning, nothing is perfume except musk]: which has been resolved is several ways; some holding AlTyb to be the subject of lys: but its being peculiar to the dial. of Temeem refutes the explanations here referred to: some, again, hold lys to be here used as a particle; and so in the saying layosa xalaqa A@ll~`hu mivolahu, mentioned above. (Mughnee.) Sometimes it is used in the sense of laA Alt~aboriy^api [the lA which denies in a general manner to the uttermost, i. e., universally, or totally]; as is said in the K, except that in all the copies thereof we find waA_in~amaA put by mistake for warub~amaA: (TA:) [so in the saying in the Kur, ii. 194, layosa Ealayokumo junaAHN, which is the same as laA junaAHa Ealayokumo in verse 235 of the same chapter, meaning, There shall be no crime, or sin, chargeable upon you]. Sometimes, also, it is used as a connective particle, (Mughnee,) in the sense of lA so used: (TA:) as in the saying [of a poet],
A^ayona Almafar~u waAlA_il`hu AlgaAlibu
waAlA^a$oramu Almagoluwbu layosa AlgaAlibu
[Where is the place of flight when God is the pursuer, and El-Ashram (meaning Abrahah) is the overcome, not the overcomer?]: which has been resolved by supposing AlgAlb to be the subject of lys, and the predicate to be suppressed; the latter being said by Ibn-Málik to be an annexed pronoun referring to El-Ashram; so that the meaning is layosahu AlgaAlibu [the overcomer is not he]. (Mughnee.) It is said (M, K) by Fr, (M,) and also by Kh, (TA,) that the original of layosa is laA A^ayosa; (M, K [in the latter of which I read A^awo A^aSoluhu, as in several copies of the K, or rather A^awo A^aSoluhaA, as corrected in the TA, instead of A^awo maEonaAhu, the reading in the CK];) and this, says Fr, is shown by the saying, jiy^o bihi mino A^ayosa walayosa, i. e., [Bring thou him, or it,] from where he, or it, is, and is not: (M:) or AiytiniY mino Hayovu A^ayosa walayosa i. e., [Come thou to me, or probably, the right reading is AiytiniY bihi bring thou to me him, or it, (as I find in a copy of the K, in which bh has been added in red ink, and in the A I find A_iyti bihi,)] from where he, or it, is, and he, or it, is not: (K:) or the meaning is, minE Hayovu laA wujoda [from where there is no finding; or no being found, or no existence; or no power, or ability]: (K, * TA:) or A^ayosa means mawojuwdN [found, or existing], and laA A^ayosa [means] laA mawojuwdN [not found, or not existing], and is contracted [into layosa]: (K:) [but the last rendering of Ays and lA Ays seems to be taken from an explanation, not literal, of another saying; maA yaEorifu A^ayosa mino layosa he knows not a thing existing from a thing not existing.] Aboo-'Alee relates, that Sb said, jiy^o bihi mino Hayovu walayosaA [Bring thou him, or it, from where he, or it, is and is not]; meaning, walayosa, the fet-hah of the s being made full in sound, on account of the pause. (M.) In the saying of a certain poet,
qado rus~ati AlHaAjaAtu Einoda qayosi
A_i*o laA yazaAlu muwlaEFA bilayosi
[Wants have been forgotten as old things (so rus~at is explained in the M, as used here, in art. rs,) with Keys, since he ceases not to be addicted to the use of the word leysa], it is made by him a noun, and declined. (M.)

1 laATa bihi * , aor. yaliyTu, inf. n. layoTN: see laATa bihi in art. lwT, in three places. ― -b2- maA yaliyTu bihi Aln~aEiymu A state of ease, or plenty, or enjoyment, does not suit him, (AZ, K.) -A2- laATa AlqaADiY fulaAnFA bifulaAnK, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) The judge classed such a one, as an adjunct, with such a one; put him on a par with him; or made him to be as though on a par with him; syn. A^aloHaqahu bihi. (K.) It is said in a trad., of 'Omar, kaAna yaliyTu A^awolaAda AljaAhily~api biA=baAy^ihimo (tropical:) He used to class the children of people of ignorance, [the pagans,] as adjuncts, with their fathers; syn. yuloHiquhumo. (TA.) [See also laATahu in art. lwT; and see 4.]
2 lay~aTa see 4.
4 AlAThu * , inf. n. A_ilaATapN, He stuck it; made it to cleave, stick, or adhere; (TA;) as also ↓ ly~Thu, inf. n. taloyiyTN. (K, TA [but only the inf. n. is mentioned.])
layoTN * : see lawoTN: -A2- see also liyTN.

liyTN * is a pl. of ↓ liyTapN, (S, K,) as also liyaATN and A^aloyaATN; (K;) [the last being a pl. of pauc.; or rather, liyTN is a coll. gen. n., of which liyTapN is the n. un.;] and signifies The bark, rind, or peel, that adheres to a tree: or, accord. to Az, that is beneath the upper bark, rind, or peel: (TA:) or the covering, exterior part, skin, peel, rind, bark, or the like, of anything: (K:) and particularly, of a cane, or reed; (L;) or this is termed ↓ liyTapN; (K:) or this last word signifies a piece, or portion, of the exterior part of a cane, or reed; (S, L;) or a sharp piece thereof, mentioned in a trad. as used for cutting the throats of sparrows: (TA:) also, of a spear-shaft; (L;) or this, too, is termed ↓ liyTapN: (K:) and of a bow; i. e. the upper and exterior part thereof, that is oiled and made smooth; (TA;) or the exterior part of a bow is termed ↓ liyTapN: (K:) and of a [beetle of the kind called] juEal: (TA:) and of anything that is hard and strong; and ↓ liyTapN signifies a piece, or portion, of the exterior part of any such thing. (L.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) The skin: (K, TA:) pl. A^aloyaATN. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The external skin; or exterior of the skin: as in the saying, rajulN lay~inu All~iyTi (tropical:) a man soft in the external skin, or exterior of the skin: also meaning (tropical:) soft to the feel. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Colour; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ layoTN (K) and ↓ liyaATN: (TA:) and particularly of the sun; as also ↓ liyaATN. (TA.) You say, huwa A^anowaru mino liyTi Al$~amosi (tropical:) He is brighter than the colour of the sun. (TA.) And A^atayotuhu waliyTu Al$~amosi lamo yuqo$aro (tropical:) I came to him when the redness of the sun had not departed, in the beginning of the day. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) What appears of the sky. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The natural disposition, or temper. (K, TA.)
liyTapN * : see liyTN, in five places.
liyaATN * : see liyTN, in two places: -A2- and see also art. lwT.
A^aloyaTu * : see A^alowaTu.
